product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: These cameras are great for the price. You can have the camera email you whenever motion is detected or set it to record continuously. The quality of the color picture is good. The camera will reset automatically if the power goes out, and no PC is needed other than initial setup. Once set up, you can unplug and move it from room to room. Just plug it back in and it goes back online. Only thing that would make it better is if you could mount it outdoors. But set it up by a window and it records outside activity just fine.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
It definitely works. It took me a while to figure out how to hook it up via wi-fi, but I found a youtube video that had a very simple explanation. I followed the instructions that came with the camera, and downloaded the software for it. The instructions were very easy to follow. The only thing I had to do that is not mentioned in there is once the wi-fi router info (name, password) are programmed in the camera, unplug the camera and then take out the ethernet cable. After that, plug the camera back in and the wi-fi should take over. If you let the camera reboot and leave the ethernet cable in, it will take over and you won't get a wi-fi connection.

I tried to call their customer support. It was difficult to understand the person I was talking to and they wanted me to download software on my computer so they could have access to my computer in order to help. I was not comfortable with that, and did not continue the call. And as said, I was able to figure it out. If I can do it, anyone can. I'm no computer expert and it was easy. Just a little online research to help!!!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I spent numerous days trying to get this set up.  Tech support was able to get it on the network but, blamed carrier (internet provider) for port forwarding not working.  Changed carriers and it still does not work.  Very difficult!  Great while at home on the network.  Great pan and tilt, does not zoom as promised though unless on a smart phone, and night vision is good.  Only 1 way audio not 2 way as promised.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Not sure why there are any negative reviews. I struggled to connect this camera on my own  and finally gave up. I called support, it was super fast, they configured my camera properly and I can now log in from anywhere and check my home from my iPhone. I love this product and their technical support department. i do not work for foscam, I am a consumer and I could not be happier. Thank you focam!!!!!!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
We use this camera at home to keep an eye on our eye as opposed to a baby monitor. Advantages are being able to use the iPad or any one of our phones along with the Foscam app to watch him.

The regular image during the day is great, infrared is also pretty good. Mind you, its not HD both ways but still serves its purposes and has a pretty nice image. My wife and I were impressed.

The only thing I would have changed is the interface to set it up. It's very "old school" for lack of a better explanation. Needs to have some sort of Setup Wizard to make installing it on your network a breeze. Luckily my tech skills are almost top notch and I can manage but for others who aren't, might be a pain in the neck. DDNS needs to be simpler allowing people to just set it all up through a Foscam app perhaps or through their site. DDNS basically means being able to view it even while away from home so long as its connected to your network.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I called for support on Saturday morning and although the wait was long (~60 minutes) when I finally did reach someone (Ralph Mendez) he was very helpful.  We ran through the quick diagnostics and determined that the camera was dead and I should email Foscam for an RMA replacement.  This is the second replacement in 4 months.  The cameras are nice if they stop failing.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: This camera works great and the tech support was fabulous. Will be purchasing two more cameras. Would recommend this camera. Cameras picture is perfect.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I love the ethernet connection.

I use the free IP Cam android app.

If you don't want to fool with port forwarding to see your cam remotely, set up PPTP VPN on your home pc, then connect through VPN and access your camera "locally" (like 192.168.1.x, or whatever IP address your camera has on your home network) even when you are away from home. For more security, but quite a bit more complex to set up, use OpenVPN (free).

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I bought a $200 surveillance camera that connected to my VCR several years ago, I always wanted something that connected to my laptop to allow me to record in digital format. This was my dream come true. Plus it's remote viewing AND you can control the position of the camera. I LOVE IT!

I've only had it for a couple weeks but it's been great. Let me preface that I haven't tried to use it past my cable modem, i.e. outside my local router. That's a cool feature as well, but not what I need.

I pulled it out of the box, connected it to my router, installed software and BAM! I had access to the camera. Then I configured for wireless and put the camera in the front window and had remote control. It was very easy. If you can set up a router, you can set up this camera (at least for local viewing).

I've been recording my property for the past two weeks and I love it. How nice not to have to use a VCR to review video.

I have a question however, is there a way to schedule recording aside from motion detection or alarms? This is my only issue to date. I'd like to be able to record while I'm away and schedule it. I can always use some macro that clicks on record, then clicks off record and schedule that on my computer.

There were a few issues setting it up, namely it didn't initially say what the admin password was in the manual which it later revealed. Also, I hide the SSID on my router and I had to give that up to use this camera. I wasn't happy about that, but at least it's password protected.

Also, the IR night vision is amazing, but you really can't use it through a window which is what I wanted.

Overall 5 stars. For $80 this made me very happy. Just what I wanted. I may get another for the backyard! Good quality so far.

WARNING: If you have an older router, I had a Cisco wireless-G router, this camera will mess up your router. When I turned on the camera and then turned on my computer, the computer would not recognize the router. I replaced the router with a new wireless-N and it works like a charm now.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: We've installed two of these at a local business and were really pleased with the versatility of this little camera.  The audio works great as long as you aren't too far from the wireless gateway and the ability to pan and tilt the camera remotely was a huge BONUS for our customer.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: So the Foscam requires a bit of technical knowhow, but it works great! We are able to use all our devices for viewing and controlling it. Android users beware: you will need to use the default password. Maybe it's just me, but the android app will not recognize the new user ID-PW I gave our cam.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: 6 months in and infra-red lights are starting to fail
review_body:
I thought this was a great product - (a little quirky on the software front for Mac) but generally decent enough.
Now, 6 months later I'm not so sure. Only 2 of the infra-red lights work when the device is plugged in, the rest intermittently - which also might explain why I've been getting so many false positive motion alarms even on low sensitivity.

Going to try for a replacement with Foscam seeing as its under warranty.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
We use this in our house to watch our babies. These cameras were VERY easy to set up. I can watch and control from every apple product in our house from iPad to iPhone to iMac.

Night vision is great. I had concerns about the small red lights being bothersome. They don't really emit any light that would bother you. Our two and a half year old toddler doesn't even notice.

Would highly recommend and buy again.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I have just got this setup so this is preliminary.

The Good:
Good quality video at standard def; not the surveillance video crap.
Good controls especially for the money.
If you go to the Foscam us / tools-support site there are a bunch of useful videos on setup. Don't bother with the CD just download the latest software.
The video setup instructions could be better, they are complete but not well done in places and a little tedious. However; a big improvement over the written instructions.
Excellent pan and tilt range.
Nice long DC cord for power.
Includes a flexible mounting bracket.
Easy to put together and in service.
DHCP is now off by default.
If you know the camera name or IP you can just use that in the browser to get to the camera and not mes with the IP camera tool.
[update]
Works fine with my Kindle in 'phone mode so should work with any Android device.
[\update]

The Bad:
Needs DC, there is no battery option. There are battery to AC converters but they cost more than the Foscam.
Takes up bandwidth on your 2.4GHz network--apparently will not work on the 5GHz band.
No way to program a scan. e.g. start at the bottom of the stairs scan up then scan horizontally down a hall or even just limit the scan travel. (A little unfair given the price price point.)
Need to get the camera running to determine the driver to use.

The Ugly:
No zoom (again given the price point not really expected.)
Plastic mounting bracket appears frigale.
To avoid power cord problems and eliminate the drain on WiFI bandwidth you can run Power over Ethernet cable to the camera. You need to run one line in any case.
[update]
The SW supplied with the camera is limited and you need something like the [[ASIN:B008YD80KC Blue Iris Professional - Supports Many IP Camera Brands Including Foscam and Agasio, Zone Motion Detection, H.264 Compression Recording,E-mail And SMS Text Messaging Alerts!]] software to get all the features you would like to have.
Audio on non-IE browsers requires a obscure plug with limited compatibility.
As the camera gains up (IR mode) the screen blinks and gets grainier.
IR limited to ~100m to see something is there and ~50M to see what.
Outside in bright sun you can see a large object (garbage truck) as recognizable at ~200M, and that something is there at 1000M. But while you can see a person at ~60M there is no ability to recognizable faces beyond ~10M.
[\update]

So far I haven't done any distance tests nor tried remote viewing on a 'phone. I'm strictly using the camera for remote surveillance when I am home. (Critter problems.)

I will update after more experience and testing.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Great viewing camera not for newbies!!!
review_body:
I bought The Foscam after reading how to install it first on Amazon, Foscam forums, best of all Youtube!
The software included is not great at all I switched it with another that i dont even use also.

But on my phone I use tinyCam Monitor Pro works great.

Now as for the set up of the camera on my network using AT&T with 2wire gateway I found out this is not for newbies. I found great videos on Youtube on how to set it up.

There are many steps with every router being different, before you buy do your research on your network first and router.

Again NOT FOR NEWBIES!!!

No problems at all for 8 months 24 hours a day in Houston with the cameras sitting in front window and one in my garage the heat and cold has had no effect, the dirt and dust in my garage has no effect.

P.S. I never even talked to customer service at all try Amazon forums, Foscam forums, or Youtube first.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I purchased this camera to use as a baby monitor for my newborn son. It's now a year later and I can say I am 100% happy with this camera and highly recommend it. We use it on our iPad with the Foscam Pro application - this application is only a couple $$ and it's worth it. My mother-in-law is able to log in through her browser as well and watch her grandson sleeping or playing in his room. The resolution is more than adequate and I always have a clear picture whether it's nighttime or during the day. The IR functionality works perfect. I was actually amazed that I could see as good in the dark as I could. I even went into the room to make sure it was pitch dark. The ability to pan around the room and have two way audio makes it even better. Once you have this camera set up you will love it.

So the cons. I'm a techie and the set-up of this camera took quite a bit of research, going through forums, and watching videos. I have AT&T and at the time there wasn't much documentation on how to set this up for my specific router so I had to go through trial and error. A year later I'm sure there's better documentation available then there was for me. You need to know what you're doing as you have to go into the configuration of your router and make modifications. For viewing your camera away from home use [...] - it's free. As long as you have the patience to set this camera up or know someone who will set it up for you, it's absolutely worth it. Remember, Google is your friend.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: This was an AMAZON Warehouse Deal $10 off because of open box. After setting it up by the numbers the wireless camera does not work, it only works with a cat 5 cable plugged in. The camera does not work with two way audio either. The Mic on the camera works but the speaker does not. Not even with an exterior speaker plugged in.  This camera is inside my front porch and it would have been nice to have 2 way audio. The audio was tested with four different PC's with the same outcome. When I try to talk to the camera all I get is a broken reverberated squeal. The video works well on all four PC's. This is a learning experience- don't buy open box electronics!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
We use this camera as a baby monitor, not as a home security system.

Pros:
Very clear back and white picture as well as color
Night vision works well
Can talk through camera

Cons:
Doesn't turn a full 360 degrees or all the way down
It has to be plugged into the network instead if being wireless. Which causes it to be a hassle to move. But I like to be able to see my baby breathing so it's worth the extra hassle.

If you can wire this device I would highly recommend as a baby camera. If your going to use it wirelessly, I'd get something else.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Set up is VERY nerve racking, especially when proper instructions/set up cd are not sent along with the product! Once I got the picture ready for view, the camera offers a decent pan range of the area being observed. This is the big downside: it is supposed to record movement and it doesn't, I'm supposed to be able to view camera images away from home and I can't. It is supposed to save images into a file folder on my computer and it doesn't. And I'm guessing it doesn't because there wasn't an instruction manual sent and a set up CD to go along with it. It is a waste of $60. I can only view AT HOME, which is sort of pointless because I can just get up and look out of the window. I'm really not happy with this product.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: IP Cameras are the way to go - very worth the setup hassle
review_body:
Quick overview -

After returning 2 cameras that I was trying to set up to use as a baby monitor, I finally found what I was looking for. Every other camera that tries to connect thru Wifi is slowwwwwwwwwww. It would take 10-15 seconds for the camera to pop up when I set up the far more expensive "Dropcam" when I was in my own home on the same network, and I believe they take up a ton of your bandwith. Foscam loads in an INSTANT from home. It seems to always be connected, making me feel much better unlike the other monitors that seem to connect whenever they feel like it. The image even loads in less than 5 seconds at my work guest server, which is the definition of INCREDIBLY slow. I was pretty amazed about that.

Plus, Dropcam and other cameras had way way way less features in their app store as they only have THEIR app, it didn't pan/tilt, and they charged $10 a month if you wanted to record with it. And the notifications were terrible. Foscam has NUMEROUS apps on both Iphone and Droid, so you can test out many of them until you find the one that works for you (even has dedicated baby monitor apps with sound graphs and such). I use my old Droid phones as monitors now. Two-way talk works better than I think people give it credit, as the other 2 more expensive monitors I had sounded about the same or worse I thought. Plus, if you want, you can hook up a mini speaker to the camera since it even has audio jacks in the back.

One thing I haven't heard people say - I thought the camera was pretty big. It was bigger than the others for sure (won't fit on a window sill), but it does come with a mount if you want to hang it on the wall somewhere. But, you can buy 2 for the price of 1 of the other ones, and I like how much it can pan around the room a lot more than I thought I would.

Setup -

For those that want to use this just to view when you are at home (like as a baby monitor), setup is a piece of cake. The install instructions have been updated it seems since many of the youtube postings (search "awkwardhamster foscam" and you'll find a ton of them), but they still help, so if you are feeling overwhelmed just watch those 15 min vids before doing anything and it will definitely help. To install from the CD, I clicked the 3rd folder (03_Central Management Software), then connected the camera power and ethernet cable, then opened the windows folder (01_For Windows OS) and it found my camera. Double click on it and follow the youtube video instructions to continue.

As for setting it up to view from anywhere - yes, this was a royal pain in the arse. It SHOULD have been a lot easier as there are pretty good step by step instructions on how to do it via those youtube videos and even the instructions that come with it... however, for me, it just simply didn't work at first.

The host site would just show it as not connected even after doing everything. After getting really pissed for about 20 minutes... POOF, the site just magically worked. At first I tried creating a no-ip.info address, and after that failed, the newer ones have their own website you can use if you enable it in the DDNS options. But... that one didn't work either.

So I tried modifying like 30 different IP numbers, port forwarding numbers, changing passwords... all failing. Then, I don't even know what I did or how it happened, but I tried it again, and BOTH redirecting sites worked. I guess some of these server things just take time to load. I'd recommend creating the no-ip host site, set up the port forwarding numbers, then going out for dinner and coming back before trying anything.

Other Camera Comparisons -

Every other non-IP camera out there costs as much as it does because they try to make it "simple." Once you figure this one out, I find it even simpler. You just have to remember/write down a few IP numbers, create some passwords, andonce you have it all, you can put them into your phone apps and forget about them for the time being. The thing that bothered me most with the other cameras is that none of their apps had a "sound bar" so that if the volume on my monitor is low, I could still see that the baby is crying because it would have those red bars showing up like a traditional monitor. IP cameras have plenty of apps that will do just that, and worlds more that I have yet to discover such as recording and taking pics and whatnot.

I very much like my new toy, especially for under $100. The End.once you have it all, you can put them into your phone apps and forget about them for the time being. The thing that bothered me most with the other cameras is that none of their apps had a "sound bar" so that if the volume on my monitor is low, I could still see that the baby is crying because it would have those red bars showing up like a traditional monitor. IP cameras have plenty of apps that will do just that, and worlds more that I have yet to discover such as recording and taking pics and whatnot.

I very much like my new toy, especially for under $100. The End.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Would be 5 stars if connection didn't drop or reconnected quicker
review_body:
This camera packs a lot of features for the price. The night vision and pan and tilt features alone would make it a huge leap up from the last time I shopped around for wireless cameras, about 5 years ago.

The one serious drawback that drops this down from 5 stars to 3 for me, and might make it useless for other use cases, is that the connection drops out frequently and the power then needs to be reset for it to be usable again within a practical time frame. Dropping the connection in and of itself may or may not be the camera's fault. I do have it set up at the opposite end of the house from my router and a few other devices drop off my wireless network sometimes too. However, of those other devices which do lose their connection, they seem to detect this quickly and automatically reconnect within a few minutes. The Foscam camera will stay disconnected for hours. The camera definitely drops its connection much more frequently than any of my other devices (and many of my devices don't drop it at all), and it should really try to reconnect on its own much more quickly.

Resetting the power does cause the camera to reconnect to the network, so it is still of use to me since I am using it as a baby monitor and am therefore home and able to reset it when needed. I imagine this wouldn't work so well if you wanted to use it as a security camera when away from home. But for me, I've decided that the night vision and price make it worth the hassle of resetting. I've come up with a few workarounds to ease the pain.

First, I bought this remote controlled power switch so that I could turn the camera on and off from another room and not need to open the door and wake the baby:

Woods 32555 Outdoor Remote Control Outlet Converter Kit
[[ASIN:B001Q9EFUK B001Q9EFUK]]

Second, the camera seems to cut out less when I simply view a snapshot image rather than leave the video feed running. I wonder if a lag in the videofeed might cause the server on the camera to get backed up to the point where something dies. The snapshot is available at the URL \\"/snapshot.cgi\\" on your camera's website.

Third, in conjunction with using an image snapshot instead of the video feed, I have also installed and use the \\"Tab Auto Reload\\" Firefox add-on. I then put the snapshot in its own Firefox window and set it to automatically reload every 10 seconds. That has been good enough so far and should presumably be less demanding on the camera's web server.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
The only good things I will say are: It looks cool. It has very good low-light (black and white) operation. It's easy to install, except for the audio. It's cheap.

Bad things: Even though it advertises a 300,000 (640x480) pixel resolution, the actual resolution is probably about 76,800 (320x240) so the picture looks very fuzzy when you display it at 640x480 size. I suspect that the base image is only 320x240, and that software is used to increase the pixels without actually increasing the optical resolution. (It's just like using digital zoom on a digital camera as opposed to optical zoom.)

There are no built-in recording options, so all you can do is look at it in real time. Options are almost nonexistent which is probably why setup is so simple. I sent mine back.

My review is based on my experiences I have with 13 other network cameras I have of various types.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Beware of a hardware problem introduced on newer Foscam cameras
review_body:
Summary: Foscam is manufacturing and selling cameras with a known manufacturing defect. If the camera is pointed at a scene with too much detail (trees, grass, wood grain, window screen, etc) the camera will fail by either freezing, displaying black or rebooting. This defect was introduced as the result of a sensor change in December 2012. It was first reported by users to Foscam in May of 2013. Foscam publicly confirmed this manufacturing defect as the DSP in December 2013 and they also put a repair procedure in place. This procedure involves shipping the newly purchased camera to a distributor in Texas for repair. I've personally sent two cameras in for repair; the first repair took 15 days and required a significant amount of effort to process including a BBB complaint. The second repair took 18 days to turn around and was processed easily. Oddly, the serial number of this second camera changed before/after the repair so they seem to have sent a different camera instead of repairing. Regardless, the camera now works. Other users have reported varying amounts of friction when attempting to process these repairs.

This DSP problem is widespread among Foscam cameras. Many users potentially have cameras with the defect but do not observe the effects because the camera is not pointed at a scene with enough detail to trigger the fault. Other users may observe the defect but incorrectly identify the problem as cabling or other networking gear. At last check, 423 faulty cameras have been reported in the Foscam forums. These forums detail this defect extensively, and also offer a DIY solution for users brave enough to open the camera up and fab a custom USB cable to interface with the DSP. This forum thread can be found by doing a web search for \\"MJPEG Cameras hanging rebooting based on image data.\\" The defect is reproduced by many users with a variety of Foscam models.

A review has been posted to each of these confirmed models. This includes Foscam models 8904, 8905, 8906, 8910, 8916, and 8919. However, be aware that the defect may exist on additional models as well. Amazon is aware of these details being documented on multiple reviews for different models. Please see the update at the bottom of this review for more information regarding this.

Foscam currently claims that all cameras purchased from specific retailers as of November 2013 have the issue 100% resolved. Unfortunately, the forums show 111 faulty cameras reported from 11/1 through 12/10. To be fair, some users have reported purchasing non-faulty cameras and hopefully this will continue. But other users (as of February 2014) continue to report new cameras from these specific retailers with the defect. Unfortunately, purchasing a Foscam camera continues to be a gamble.

There is a relatively simple way to verify if a specific camera has the DSP bug. The Foscam web GUI has the option to capture a snapshot. Faulty cameras that have the DSP bug are not able to capture a snapshot greater than ~60K. If a camera is able to capture a snapshot above this threshold then it does not have the bug. If the snapshot is smaller than 60K then the current scene does not have enough detail to verify if the bug is present. The camera will need to be pointed at a more complex scene and tested again until a snapshot greater than ~60K is achieved or failure is observed. Faulty cameras that have been repaired by Foscam can also capture above the ~60K threshold.

I do not recommend buying this camera, or any other Foscam MJPEG camera unless you want to gamble with this known and confirmed freezing/black/rebooting problem. Based on the quality of support I recommend staying away from all Foscam cameras in general. They are inexpensive, but your time and sanity are worth a far greater value.

:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::
::::Foscam posted a response to this review. If you are seeking additional information, my comments on the response are below::::

Foscam US, thank you for the response. I have been close to this issue since the defect was first brought to Foscam's attention in May and this is the first public acknowledgement that I am aware of. Previously this had only been acknowledged privately through email/phone. As there are currently 62,997 views on this topic in the Foscam forums and over 400 reported faulty cameras I'm glad that there is now an \\"official\\" acknowledgement of this defect.

I do contend with some of the statements you provided as these statements do not match the current experience from actual users.

----------------------------------
Foscam US - \\"all cameras currently sold by Foscam US through the Foscam US website as well as through Amazon.com direct and the Amazon store \\"Foscam Digital Technologies LLC\\" have the issue 100% resolved as of November 2013\\"
----------------------------------

This is simply not true. Users continue to report faulty cameras from these sources. It is also worth noting that several times over the last 7 months Foscam support told users (privately over email/phone) that the defect has been fixed and newly purchased cameras will function correctly. Regardless of these statements by Foscam, users continue to report defects. Data from 11/01 through 12/10 shows that 111 additional faulty cameras have been reported since November 1. Time may show otherwise, I hope it does, but currently this statement is simply not true.

----------------------------------
Foscam US - \\"Furthermore, Foscam US (not the manufacturer which is Foscam China) is willing to replace any cameras free of charge (shipping cost covered both ways) which are suffering from this defect\\"
----------------------------------

This is also simply not true (unless this policy very recently changed). I have 50+ emails back and forth with Foscam support detailing exactly how difficult it is to process the repair. My experience was not unique, as other users have reported similar experiences. Since 8/23 there have been 7 BBB complaints; overall the BBB gives Foscam a D rating. However, if these policies have recently changed then I applaud the decision to reverse Foscam's previous policy. (Amazon Review Update: Credit where credit is due, my second repair was processed smoothly so this process may indeed be getting easier)

Bottom Line:
1) Foscam's response claims that cameras sold from specific retailers have the issue resolved as of November 2013. This is simply not true based on consumer reports.
2) The response also claims that Foscam US will replace faulty cameras free of charge. If that is true, then that is a change in policy and a step in the right direction. However, many users outside of the US are also reporting faulty cameras. Unless the manufacturer (not simply a US distributor) steps up to repair the cameras, then these international users are still without a repair solution for their faulty cameras. Foscam the manufacturer needs to assist users in correcting this defect.

--The referenced data and user experiences above are detailed in the Foscam forums and from the BBB.--

:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::
:::: Update Regarding Multiple Reviews ::::

On 2/17 a version of this review was pulled-down from the Foscam 8919 listing. I asked Amazon to review the removal. Amazon performed a review (Megan, Kath and Kai specifically) and relisted the review unmodified on 2/20. In an effort to preempt any future problems I have modified some reviews for other affected Foscam models to point to the full details on this review. However, to be clear, Amazon approved the relisting as-is. Thank you to Amazon for taking the time to have humans evaluate this review in the context ofmy other reviews and to relist. It is always good to see a system/process that works as intended.ial manipulation by Foscam.

Update:
It has now been two months and I (and other users) continue to communicate with Foscam. The cause of this error was likely a sensor change that was introduced by Foscam in late 2012. It took several months before this hardware change trickled into the consumer market. The reason that Foscam has been unable to reproduce the problem is because they have been testing on older lab units; this problem only exists on units that have been manufactured since implementing the sensor change in late 2012. The forum thread mentioned above currently contains 82 cameras documented with this problem and 14 RMA's where the replacement cameras have also exhibited the same problem. One of Foscam's resellers has sent them a camera that exhibits the problem, but Foscam has remained silent on confirming any of the testing results from this specific camera. As it currently stands, the faulty cameras are likely still being produced and Foscam continues to fail in providing a solution for current/future owners. The bad news is that it took months for the hardware change to make it into the consumer pipeline. If Foscam ever decides to actually fix this issue by changing the sensor, then it will likely again take months before the new functional hardware makes it into consumer's hands. Even then, there will probably be pockets of old hardware still trickling out to consumers.

Update 2:
After 39 e-mails back and forth, I just recieved a confirmation from Foscam of this hardware problem. The e-mail is below.

\\"For the issue that MJ cameras reboot when light is too bright and the environment is very exquisite, our engineers find the reason and provide the solution. The reason for this issue is that if the environment is special (light is very bright and has many grass and trees), the picture size may beyond the DSP buffer. It can solved by flash the the DSP driver of the sensor board. Please contact your reseller to have repair.

Have a nice day!\\"

It is unclear if Foscam plans on continuing to manufacture the cameras with the DSP bug or if they will begin reflashing the DSP as a part of manufacturing. Based on their track record, if they do plan on making a change I doubt it will be any time soon. To correct the problem current cameras need to be shipped back and the DSP must be flashed. It is good that Foscam has confirmed the problem and can provide a fix for ambitious current camera owners. But, I think we are going to continue to have new users purchasing faulty hardware and identifying this problem for a significant amount of time.

Update 3:
This update will repeat some if the information already available in the quick summary up top. Foscam has now provided a repair solution. However, they have also claimed that Foscam (the manufacturer) is not responsible for the repair of this manufacturing defect. Foscam claims it is the individual resellers, in this case Amazon, who are responsible for repairing the cameras. I wholeheartedly disagree with this, but that is Foscam's stance. Users in the forums have compiled the steps of this repair procedure together along with a list of required parts/cable as a DIY project. The DIY repair will likely void your warranty on a brand new camera, but it is good to know that this option exists. The end result of this issue is that the defect has been confirmed by Foscam and a repair solution has been provided. But, they claim no responsibility in actually performing the repair. Foscam has been the definition of difficult through the entire process and so I do not recommend buying any Foscam cameras. I recommend finding an alternative even if it costs a little more money, your time and sanity are worth it.

Update 4:
On 2/17 this review was pulled-down from the Foscam 8919 listing. I asked Amazon to review the removal. Amazon performed a review (Megan, Kath and Kai specifically) and relisted the review unmodified on 2/20. In an effort to preempt any future problems I have modified some reviews for other affected Foscam models to point to the full details on this review. However, to be clear, Amazon approved the relisting as-is. Thank you to Amazon for taking the time to have humans evaluate this review in the context of my other reviews and to relist. It is always good to see a system/process that works as intended.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Great Camera!  Here are detailed setup instructions:
review_body: This camera is great for use as a Baby Monitor.  I used it with the FoscamPro app on my iPhone and iPod Touch, which with the audio on will run in the background so you can still use your phone, or just lock the screen and set it next to you.  It works great with the latest Firmware and Web UI updates on my PC in Chrome and IE.  It also works great my iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch in the Chrome and Safari apps (although I use the FoscamPro app normally).    The instructions for the camera aren't very good though, and the software is completely unnecessary.  Instead, manage it all through your web browser.  Here's detailed instructions:    1) Do NOT install the software on the CD.  2) Look on the bottom of the camera and write down both \\"MAC ID\\" numbers listed.  One should be on a sticker that says your default username and password (also write down), and the other is probably on a sticker with the serial number listed.  The first is your Wireless MAC ID, the second is your wired MAC ID.  3) Connect the camera by Cat-5 wire to your router, and plug the power cord in.  Let it boot up.  4) Login to your router via internet browser on your computer  4a. If you don't know how, Google your router's name online to find the typical IP address and password - a common IP is: 192.168.0.1 with a blank username or username of \\"admin\\" and the password is usually \\"admin\\"  4b. Use Airport utility if using an Apple router  5) Navigate through your router's settings to find the IP address assigned to your camera.  6) Login to the camera at that IP address via web browser (e.g. \\"[...]\\" where the \\"192.168.0.15\\" is the IP address and the \\"80\\" is the port number...80 is default, you can change it)  6a. Go to Device Management  6ai. Basic Network Settings:  6aii. Check \\"Obtain IP from DHCP Server\\"  6aiii. Choose a HTTP Port (any number 4 digits long)  6aiv. Uncheck \\"Network Lamp\\" (turns off one of the 2 blinking LEDs on the back of the camera)  6av. Click Submit  6b. Go to Wireless LAN Settings  6bi. Check \\"Using Wireless LAN\\"  6bii. Enter your network SSID (the name of your network)  6biii. Choose your encryption type  6biv. Type your network password  6bv. Click Submit  7) Go back to your router's settings and navigate through the settings to find the \\"DHCP Reservations\\" or \\"Address Allocations\\" settings.  7a. If all the devices are listed, find your camera.  It should be listed twice now, as it's connected wired and wirelessly.  Give both of them a reserved IP address.  7b. If your router assigns IP reservations by MAC ID, then type in the wireless MAC ID your wrote down at the beginning, and assign it an IP.  Do the same for the wired MAC ID.  7c. Either way, write down the IP address you choose for both.  The whole point of this is that when you log into your camera you'll need the IP.  If you don't set a reservation, every time the router or your camera restarts you'll have to look up the new IP address.  This way it'll be the same forever.  7d. Apply your settings and restart the router.  7e. Remove power from your camera and don't reapply power until after the router is fully booted.  Feel free to put your camera where you want it, whether it remains wired in or you unplug it and use it wirelessly.  8) Once everything is back on, re-login into your camera at the IP address you specified (e.g. \\"[...]\\" where the \\"192.168.0.15\\" is your IP address and the \\"80\\" is your port number)  8a. If the stickers were swapped, you may have to try the other IP number (wired vs wireless), sometimes they are backwards.  8b. Alias Settings - Set a name for your camera if you want  8c. Date&Time Settings - Set it for where you are  8d. Users Settings - Set up usernames and passwords and restrictions if you like (I recommend changing it from the default username and password)  8e. ADSL Settings, UPnP Settings, DDNS Service Settings, MSN Settings, and FTP Service Settings can all be left alone - Advanced users can set as required.  8f. Mail Service Settings - you can put in your email address and check \\"Report Internet IP by Mail\\" so whenever your internet provider changes your external IP you get an email with the new one (this is mainly if you want your video stream accessible outside of your home)  8g. Alarm Service Settings - Self Explanatory  8h. PTZ Settings - Leave alone unless the Pan and Tilt feature is too fast or slow for your preference.  8i. Upgrade Device Firmware - For update Firmware.  Go to Foscam's website, and find Firmware updates in their Support area.  The website guides you through updating.  8j. Backup & Restore Settings, Restore Factory Settings, Reboot Device, and Log - Self explanatory  9) If you want to access it from anywhere, there are a bunch of setup instructions on Foscam's website that are specific to your type of router.  I don't have this set up, so I'm not much help here.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

On the android we are using IP CAM VIEWER PRO and on the Iphone we are using Foscam Surveillance Pro.

We have ordered 2 more of these which came today and I will write a separate review on those.

Update:

Did not realize that this was for all my cameras so I wanted to add the feedback since I setup the others. We now have 3, 2 working and 1 being returned and replaced as the unit is bad.

The 2 working ones are all setup and work great together and I can view both in both android and iOS apps!!!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: A day in the life of my dogs!
review_body:
I have two little dogs at home and I like to be able to watch them when I'm away, I just want to make sure they are okay. (Yes I am one of those over-protective pet-mommies!) I originally bought the Cisco WVC80N but since it didn't pan or tilt I had to buy 4 just to cover half of the blind spots in the room and my dogs like to wander, so at $100 each that was getting too expensive, plus they didn't have 2 way audio, just one way and no night vision. Then I saw this Foscam and since it had good reviews I decided to give it a try. I absolutely love it!

Setup was a breeze and I had it working in under a minute (i'm a bit of an electronics geeks so this may not be an average time estimate).

The interface is easy to use and gives you multiple options to access the camera feed based on the browser you are using. I've tried it with IE, Firefox, and Chrome and IE gives you the most features (due to ActiveX) but I swear the resolution is better with Firefox (this could be because the image is slightly smaller and so it just appears better quality).

I'm not overly thrilled with the Foscam Android app, as it didn't have controls to move the camera but it does have the 2 way audio. However there are plenty of other IP cam apps out there that you can use to control it, I use IPCamViewer Basic.

The audio isn't the best, there tends to be feedback when you try to use the microphone while listening to the audio through speakers but its clear enough that my dogs seem to recognize my voice. I used it during a recent thunderstorm to calm my dogs while I was at work.

The highest resolution the camera has is 640x480 which isn't the best but its good enough. There is a higher resolution camera from Foscam (I think its the 9810?) that looks like this one for $100 more but for my purposes, and probably most peoples purposes, this resolution is fine. Even in night vision mode the resolution is still pretty decent (at least for a networkcamera). And by the way night vision mode is awesome! I can easily make out my little pups when they are hiding in the dark corner when the world outside gets too scary.

Overall I can't say enough good things about this camera. I highly recommend it, for its price point I think its one of the best on the market. Though a warning to all pet parents who have nosy animals, make sure you put it up high. When I first got the camera (before I mounted it) I set it on a high table and one of my dogs found it and started sticking his face into the camera and even now that i've mounted it I find him frequently staring directly into the camera. :-)

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I received this camera as a gift from my wife. We wanted to be able to check in on our puppy while we are at work (nerds, I know!). This camera is under $100 and has so many features! I get a clear feed on my laptop, iPad and iPhone! I can control the direction the camera point remotely. It has \\"night vision\\" which is cool (if not creepy). It is wireless so we can hook it up anywhere somewhat near an electrical outlet. The only two improvements that may be available in other models would be a zoom lens and full HD quality. But I do not need those features myself.

TWO IMPORTANT NOTES:

1) Setting up this camera for remote access on the internet can be DIFFICULT. It requires you to do advanced setting on your home router that you probably are not comfortable with. I would recommend doing a Google search for Foscam + your router's brand/make. You will find specific instructions out there (maybe even in a video format) that will show you exactly what settings you need to change. If your ISP assigns you a dynamic IP, you will also need to sign up for a service like No-IP.com provides. So, again, that's more \\"pain in the butt\\" setup for you. Once you get past the setup, the thing works GREAT!

2) If you are using an iPad/iPhone to view the video feed, download the app \\"FoscamPro\\". It cost maybe $5 but it is SO much better than trying to watch via Safari. That $5 price does get you the app on both your iPad and iPhone if you have both.

Overall, I really like what I am getting from this camera and would definitely buy another if we need it.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Well made unit. Good color quality. Too bad it has to work with port forwarding. Not easy for a layperson to figure out.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Great camera all around. Got stuck during setup, called Tech Support, spoke to Andrew, who was amazingly knowledgeable and got me setup in probably 5 mins! Couldn't be happier!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Good quality, good software, audio in only when using a pc which was unexpected but logical. Comes with wifi which is great.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I have to say after doing a lot of research on wireless IP cameras, I finally chose this one and am quite pleased with it and all of the features. This is my first IP camera and bought it mainly to watch the interior of my home while I'm away. Setting it up was a bit tricky. The included CD disc is a bit worthless as it does not install anything on your computer, you must find the file you want then load it. I have found that you really don't need the disc to setup your camera. What you do need is a good understanding of your routers menus and interface and port forwarding. To use this as a wireless camera and to remotely access it via the internet or a smartphone or tablet app, you need to set up the IP address of the camera and the router followed by the port assigned to the camera, which is done manually via your routers setup. After many hours of tinkering, I finally got everything working with the internet and the foscam app for my android devices. Setting up the email alerts was easy once I figured out that I had to reset camera to factory defaults, start over and then setup email. Foscam support says that Gmail is not supported but it is and works fine with this model. After all of the learning curves, this is a great camera and I will be buying a few more.

Pros:
Good picture
Low light settings work very good
Remote access

Cons:
Very tricky to set up at first
Audio is sketchy

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

review_body:
I got this camera last week in hopes of getting a "Higher Quality" wireless camera; I was wrong. I do like the color and clarity of this camera, but it keeps rebooting when I connect to it remotely. During this reboot, the camera does a full range of movement test which takes about 45 seconds. I have 2 WansView cameras (bought on Amazon) that were half the price and have been working well for a while. The thing I don't like about them is the firmware isn't updated and Customer Service is non-existent.

Now, the reboot issue was there out of the box, I upgraded to the latest firmware, still happens. Customer Support says it's a known issue. I ask, if it's known, why not address the issue, No Reply.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
So I purchased this as a baby monitor. The instruction manual is a little confusing but you can get through it if you have some knowledge of LAN architecture. You can pick this up by googling it pretty quickly I guess.

However, the reason I'm returning this poor product is that it does not support audio for Mac users! They did not mention this until I found out by wasting an hour mucking around with the camera, then going online and finding many other users with the same problem. I read on a forum that Foscam were \\"working on a solution\\" but it \\"may take some time\\".

The fact that Foscam will not tell you about the shortcomings of this device is ridiculous. Foscam are a bunch of swindling, greedy gutter trash who I would like to see go out of business only after the owners have invested all of their personal assets in the company, thus leaving them with next to nothing. It gives me sinful quantities of pleasure to imagine that the IRS then does an audit and finds they have incorrectly filed their taxes, meaning they owe penalties that ultimately land them in jail.

In jail, they may look up while their heads are held against the shower floor and see the Foscam security cameras silently panning away from the villagers riding their new town bike, the guards ambivalent to their plight.

Unfortunately for me, there appears to be a willing customer born every minute.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I got the camera in just a few days.  I already had one so I knew what I was getting.  The cameras are easy to set up.  I am using them for an alarm system in my home.  I like the fact they are cheap, and you don't have to pay a monthly service fee.  When I arm them they send me pictures in emails, which come to my phone, of what is setting them off.  Also, I have them hooked up to my android so I can watch the video live if I want to.  They work perfect with your android, so you can do everything you want from anywhere, including arming them if you forget to arm them before you leave home.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Perfect for what I needed - ...and I'm very picky
review_body:
This thing was a bit of a bear to get set-up on port forwarding (so you can control it from anywhere). Here's the "easy" way, which are the exact notes I took when the engineer next door helped me set it up:

Set up the camera like it says with the software. (easy - anyone can do it)
Purchase the $30/year DNS service it suggests (It says you don't have to, but I can't figure out how not to use DNS.com)
Add Port Forwarding on your router (Google the IP address and admin password, then just type IP in your browser)

Camera - says Indoor, but we'll see how long it lasts outdoor because the IR can't see thru glass, and I want it to watch my driveway. I put it under the eve so hopefully it lasts until we sell the house. I have to move and don't want to leave this place sit empty without cameras. Leaving my router, and taking all my computers. Leaving 3 cameras as sentries.

GREAT audio and video and snapshots, email alerts, auto-recording (makes a AVI file under your documents). Neighbor bought hi-end outdoor one that does same thing for about $500, and this one was $89-ish?

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Way too much effort to get working and spotty performance since. Will come on once, then just stop working. Regret the decision to buy this for sure.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Recently there is a nasty bug with this and possibly other models of foscam cameras that causes it to constantly reboot when the image contains a lot of detail and/or bright light. Essentially this problem makes the camera unusable if you have it pointed outside in daylight, but depending on the image data it could affect other image subjects as well.

It's still not clear if this will be able to be fixed, since foscam hasn't officially commented on the matter.

Potential buyers, you might take a look in the foscam support forum to see if this has been resolved before you buy. If you use a search engine with \\"foscam technical support forum\\" you should be able to find the forum.

I'll amend this review if this fatal flaw is fixed, but for now, minimum stars since I've been stuck with an unusable camera with no recourse from support.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:

UPDATE-----After purchasing BlueIris software the camera(s) perform fine. product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I received the camera in the mail and placed a call to Foscam tec support to help set it up. Calvin Harris with Foscam was my tec support guy and he walked me through every step to get it working perfectly. It was very easy with his help.

After waiting 2 hours for a total of four phone calls I finally gave up.  Product works good on my in-house local network but does not work over the internet that was not what I bought it for.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Novice says: Works OK but setup is tricky & no sound on Mac
review_body:
Update Nov 2014: I got a gift of another one of these last year for Xmas, but did not get around to installing it until today. Long story short, it works just like the other two I own. Still annoyed with this company for all their fake reviews, so I'm sticking with my devalued 2-star review.

Original review:

Just received mine today. Ordered via Amazon (sold and fulfilled by Amazon). Foscam now states that they do consider Amazon to be an authorized reseller, so at least that is an improvement from the past.

My computer is an iMac running OSX 10.8.4. My router was made by Netgear.

Setup:
-I followed the instructions and plugged the camera into my router with ethernet wire supplied. Plugged in power cable also.
-Installed the IP Camera Tool software (provided on the CD) onto my iMac. Logged into the camera via the software and everything looked good. Next, I needed to unplug the wire to set it up for wireless use on my home network.
-First step of \\"specifying an http port number\\" other than 80 was fairly simple. Keep in mind that I really don't know what they mean by all the \\"port\\" talk. I just followed the instructions and everything went smoothly at this point.
-My internet service supplier (Comcast) gives me a \\"static IP address\\", i.e. it always stays the same number no matter when I use my computer. So I could skip all of the DynamicIP Address stuff. I think that made it a lot easier for me.
-At this point, the badly written installation manual makes it seem like you might be done, but no. Onward...
-Next step was \\"port forwarding\\", whatever that means. The tricky thing here (for novices) is that the manual just says \\"login to the router\\". Uhh...what the hell? How do I do that?! No instructions. (At this point, the techy people reading this review are slapping their foreheads and/or getting a cramp from laughing).
-I finally figured out how to get logged into my Netgear router by going to Netgear's website.
-Then I followed the instructions to setup \\"port forwarding\\".

At that point, I could get on the internet and go to the correct URL (they explain how to figure this out) and see the camera's view. Everything worked ok.

Before I went any further, I used the IP Camera Software again to change the password for the camera. (the default is no password which did not sound very secure).

So far, so good. Only problem is that when you use a Mac computer to view the camera, you can not hear any audio. After doing some research on the internet, there seems to be no way to solve this problem at this point.

BUT the good news is that if you use the iCam app on your iPhone or iPad (like I do) then you will be able to hear the audio and see the video as well as control the pan/tilt of the camera.

So for me, everything works fine, but it was a bit of a headache to set it up. The installation manual needs a thorough re-write by a NATIVE ENGLISH SPEAKER who tests the process each step of the way. Note that this is different than getting a native English speaker to brush up the grammar on the badly written manual. There needs to be a much simpler logic and flow written into the installation manual. Amazing that Foscam can not figure this out yet after thousands of complaints on Amazon.

Finally, I just want to say that I feel there are hundreds of fake reviews here on Amazon for this product. Typically they are short, give 5 stars, and mention what great tech support they received from Mary, Lisa, Juan, etc. Another Amazon reviewer mentioned that it appears these fake reviews are being done by Foscam's tech support staff overseas. I am not sure if these allegations are true, but they sound genuine to me. In my view, if this is true, these fraudulent reviews must be stopped and past ones must be deleted by Foscam/Amazon. This is serious unethical behavior! Minus one star on this review as a penalty.

Summary, it's a 4 star product with a 2 star installation manual for an average of 3 stars, BUT minus one star for unethical fake reviews allegedly by Foscam tech support staff. Total = 2 stars.e star for unethical fake reviews allegedly by Foscam tech support staff. Total = 2 stars.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Foscam 8910W IP Camera (bought 2 cameras via a sale coupon sent by a friend). I had a bit of a learning curve setting up the first camera over ethernet, then finally figured out the dsl modem settings and have used both cameras successfully from within my local area network WiFi. I work on Macs and found the supplied IP Camera Tool didn't reveal my camera id's at all. After searching for more information and a little trial and error succeeded at identifying the cameras. Now a month or so later decided to setup the 'Mail Alert' settings to no avail after several attempts. I did some searching online and not finding correct settings for using Apple iCloud SMTP server finally resorted to contacting Technical Support at Foscam via their website. I spoke to Andrew and he helped me to download the proper remote access software tool. He was then able to guide me through the correct settings for my email and server settings, all within about 15 or 20 minutes. I must say the tech support from Andrew at Foscam is fantastic and I highly recommend his help. A simple call by way of their toll-free phone number will connect you if you too are having any questions or need remote help. These cameras are truely amazing, certainly for their capabilites and considering the cost...amazing product and extremely good tech support.[[ASIN:B006ZP8UOW Foscam FI8910W Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with Two-Way Audio and Night Vision (Black)]]

Andrew,

review_headline: Bad issue with light sensitive on motion alarm
review_body:
I was using this camera for security but found out I kept getting motion alarms when the sun goes in or out from behind clouds. I set the sensitivity to every setting but they keep going off. I also check the box for motion compensate but no effect, still alarms. I emailed the company and they said yes it was very sensitive to light changes and will set off the motion alarm. I was going to use these models (F18918W & F18910W) for security when out of town but can't due to constant alarms when the sun goes in or out.
I would not recommend this product due to the motion alarm issue.
If you use this product at night it might be OK.

review_body:
Pros: Easy to set up. Plug it into your network, log in, change settings, and you're good to go. No software install was needed, everything is web based. Picture is great for what I wanted it for. Night vision works good. Self explanatory as far as the web interface is concerned. Mount it came with worked great. Mounted a good 60' away from my router through a couple walls and don't have any signal issues.

Cons: Haven't been able to get it to record video to my hard drive yet. File never shows up.

Overall: Works like I wanted. Lets me keep track of the living room and front door and pan around the room. Would give 5 stars if I could get the video to record properly.

review_headline: A waste of time and money
review_body:
This was the most frustrating purchase I have made. I am a gadget freak, and love ALL kinds of setup challenges. Not this one. The wired connection works Ok, but I didn't buy it for hooking up to a wired connection. The Wireless connection has been a nightmare. I have tried everything, I mean everything. The camera just doesn't connect to my router (it does detect it though), I have watched all kinds to videos, and read forum discussions. Nothing worked.

I have a D-Link camera that I purchased subsequently, and while challenging to setup as well, I was able to set that camera to work on WiFi in a fraction of the time I have spent on this Foscam.

Avoid at ALL costs, unless you like getting frustrated by a total lack of usability.

I had a friend (IT guy) come help but he could not getting set up either.  I sent foscam an email and got little help with a statement about the router signal exceeding 50ft.  I bought two 9dbi antennas and that didn't help.  Because it took so long to 'TRY' to set them up, I can not return them for a full refund.  Bottom line... it should not be that complicated to set up, I am not completely computer illiterate but could not figure out how to get these to work.  I never called technical support because I work all day.

review_headline: Simple install, not the best resolution

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: For the price, this is a great product. Yes, you do have to be able to make changes to your network if you want to access it from the web, but there are several articles that describe how to do this. The video and audio quality are very good. The only thing this camera lacks is a zoom capability, which of course, would make it cost more. I would buy a Foscam again and I would recommend them to others.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

review_body: Support from FOSCAM tech Andrew was wonderful. His explanations were clear; he even explained how to access the camera through my new smart phone. I never could have set up the remote access without his support; he took over remote control of my computer and had the camera working in no time. Great little camera and great tech support.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Motion Alarm email does not work
review_body:
I have emailed more than 20 times with their customer support, and they will not even review the setting screen shots they requested.

I have set up the camera correctly. When the camera boots up, it sends me an email telling me that the camera has reset and is back up. So I know the email settings are correct. The camera software does note when motion is detected, as can be seen from the device status tab. But it will NOT send an email informing me of the alarm, neither motion nor sound alarms.

I even returned the camera and the new one exhibits the same flaw.

As this is a crucial feature, I have to give the camera no more than two stars.

Try again, Foscam.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: The Best IP PTZ Cam I've Owned
review_body:
I bought my FI8910W almost a year ago (July of 2012) and it was my second one of the type. The first was a Foscam clone with the same features as this for about 1/3rd less. Quality of video is similar but setup on the Foscam is easier.

In almost a year, it has never failed and I've never had to contact support. I view my cameras on the Mac, Windows 8, iPad, iPhone and Android tablet using free or very low cost software.

I'm here today not just to leave this review but to buy another one. I use them for security cameras and to monitor my 86 year old mother-in-law who lives alone four miles away. I'd gotten used to being able to check on her. We just moved her to another house and I haven't moved the camera yet. This morning I found that she didn't answer an automated phone call I set up to remind her to give her dog his epilepsy pill. So I called her only to get a busy signal. So I drove over to find the phone knocked off the hook and her reading a book. If I'd had the camera set up again, one click would have reassured me that she was OK.

These cameras a great for that use. If you need razor sharp HD recording for evidence in criminal cases, no... nothing in this price range will suit. But if you want to have a reliable way of checking on a room, this is very hard to beat.

The best feature is the night-vision. The infra-red LEDS do a great job if lighting up a wall over 20 feet away. In fact, it is difficult for me to distinguish between interior night vision and daytime video in one of the rooms (there's no much color in the room.)

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: The sound on the app is not stable but all-in-all I would buy it again. Decent quality video and I like the ability to watch on my iphone.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
My wife an I opted for this camera instead of one of the normal baby video monitors mostly because of price, and also because of the flexibility of configuration. If you're not at least somewhat savvy with networking, and IP protocols, this might not be the device for you, but the instructions are pretty straightforward, so if you're willing to learn a little networking, you can do all kinds of fun stuff with this camera.

The foscam app that's on the Android / iOS marketplace is complete crap, so don't use it as a purchase point. The web interface works just fine on mobile devices that have a fairly current browser (Chrome on Nexus 7 works great).

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I needed to monitor my sick wife remotely and this unit fits the bill and at the right price. I first connected the camera directly to my router via the supplied Ethernet cable, installed the camera s/w that came with it on my Windows 7 system and followed the easy instructions in the manual. It gets an IP address from the router and in my case decided to use a fixed mode (preferable to DHCP as the number will never change). It also asks you for a port number (you pick a number between 1000 and 20,000) which is used later for monitoring from outside your own house network. Write down the IP address of the camera and the port number that you have chosen as you will need it later.

I then disconnected the camera from the router, unplugged the power cord and rebooted it. I was then able to place the camera anywhere in the house and see the video on my laptop using a browser. All the camera needs is a power outlet. I added an add-on to my browser and was also able to hear sound from the room where the camera was located and was also able to talk to anyone in the room - with significant delay, but very useable. The is basically a web server. From the webpage that you receive from the camera, you can move the lens left ant right and up and down. If there is not enough light in the room, you can also turn the Infrared mode on. What you see is a B&W image, even if it is in the middle of the night with the room completely dark. I then tested it using my laptop running Windows Vista and it worked fine. No s/w to install, all you use is your browser (IE, Firefox, Chrome or Safari which you point to the IP address of your camera (more on this later). It also works fine from mobile devices like iPhones, iPads, Android tablets and Android phones. I tried them all. The only things missing from the iOS and Android devices is the audio as no plugin is available for those devices.

There are many other services that you can setup (like sending you an email in response to motion or sound in the room). These are not described in the little manual that comes with the camera but are fully described in the User Manual found online for this camera. You can change all these setting from the same web screen where your video shows up.

My next step was to add the ability to view the video stream from outside my home network. This setup is well described in the online User Manual. It is simple but involves you logging into your router and set up "Port forwarding" to route traffic coming to your router for this port to go to the internal IP address of your IP Camera.. The support section of the FOSCAM website has lots of information on how to do this. Once you have done this, you can use your IP Camera from anywhere in the word by browsing to http://ww.xx.yy.zz:#### where ww.xx.yy.zz is the IP address for your incoming house connection and #### the port number that you have chosen when you set up the camera and when you set up the port forwarding.

This camera is for indoor use only and has worked very well for me. You can have multiple cameras in your house, each one having its own port number and internal IP address.onse to motion or sound in the room). These are not described in the little manual that comes with the camera but are fully described in the User Manual found online for this camera. You can change all these setting from the same web screen where your video shows up.

My next step was to add the ability to view the video stream from outside my home network. This setup is well described in the online User Manual. It is simple but involves you logging into your router and set up "Port forwarding" to route traffic coming to your router for this port to go to the internal IP address of your IP Camera.. The support section of the FOSCAM website has lots of information on how to do this. Once you have done this, you can use your IP Camera from anywhere in the word by browsing to http://ww.xx.yy.zz:#### where ww.xx.yy.zz is the IP address for your incoming house connection and #### the port number that you have chosen when you set up the camera and when you set up the port forwarding.

This camera is for indoor use only and has worked very well for me. You can have multiple cameras in your house, each one having its own port number and internal IP address.
