review_body:
The camera isn't the best image quality ( but, it is pretty decent ), but for cost...I'd say it's the best bang for your buck.
Also, customer care is patient and will resolve issues for you. Shout out to Leo!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: The Fi8910w  is a reall nice camera and the support has been excellent. I had trouble with the remote connection and called the company. I made contact with Leo and he was great and helped with all of my problems. I would recommend this camera and company to anyone.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I originally bought 4 Foscam F18910W cameras via Amazon Prime for about $80.00 each. Itried to set them up myself and after 2 weekends of dealing with my internet provider, I gave up and sent them back. I then called Foscam directly because i really needed these cameras to work. I ended up re-purchasing the 4 cameras theough Foscam for about $100.00 per camera but these cameras came with unlimited tech support. Once Foscam tech support started working on my cameras they immediately realized I had a bad router. That information could have saved me two whole weekend of working on this. In about 4 hours tey had all 4 cameras up and running and also helped my wife setit up on her I phone. That was 2 years ago. Last week we moved into a new home and brought our 4 Foscam cameras with us. I figured I would call Fascam and they would nt remember us but I was wrong. They took my name and set an appointment for Jeez to call us back at 4pm and he did (twice)! I could not beleive how patient and how much time they spent with us. It took them about 4 hours total to set it all up. During the call my wife even commented \\"I can't beleive they are apending so much time on us\\" and that is when I decided to give them a great review (something I rarely do). On a scale of 1-10 I am about a 5 when it comes to technology and I would recommend that anyone considering these cameras to seriously consider thier tech support. I would recommend the camera to anyone and the tech support excellent. Thanks Jeez for all your help.

VG in Texas

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: camera is great, and customer service (by telephone) was super helpful!  they walked me through installation very patiently and were able to remote into my computer to help -- highly recommended!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I bought this camera to use as a baby monitor in place of the SECOND Summer TV monitor that took a dump. It was relatively easy to setup, although the IP scanner tool included on the software CD doesn't seem to work with Windows 7. I had to get the IP address from my router's DHCP client list. Aside from that, setup was pretty easy and went according to the included instructions. Foscam's website has some pretty decent step by step instructions on topics such as port forwarding so you can view your camera via internet as well as on your local network.

The power cord that comes with it is comically short for a device that is almost certainly going to be mounted high on a wall or from the ceiling. Thankfully, Foscam sells a 10' extension for \\"only\\" $15.

I can't figure out why they decided that the ring of LEDs around the lens should emit visible light. They are supposed to be IR LEDs but they are clearly visible. That could be just some of the light filtering through from the ridiculously bright LED status light on the back of the unit. Neither is so bright as to keep my daughter up so I guess it doesn't matter but it seems poorly thought out.

The camera moves very quietly. I can't hear it at all, except through the application. It does make an audible click when switching to/from night vision.

The mounting hardware was present and adequate.

The camera's firmware offers a great degree of control.

I would strongly recommend this camera to friends.

I'd also recommend the Tinycam Android ap if you want to view the camera on an Android mobile device. You can simply view it through a browser but the ap provides way more control and is more user friendly, I think.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: A rock-solid IP camera at a reasonable price
review_body:
I was looking for an inexpensive camera to use as a baby monitor. There were a few key features I was looking for. I wanted the ability to watch from my Android smartphone and from a computer, and I wanted it to connect to my network via WiFi. This camera has these features and a few extras that have come in handy. This camera seems to be very well built, it has already survived a couple of toddler induced incidents. I have the black version, which has almost like a satin rubber finish to it. I think this finish will help to prevent scratches, but time will be the test there.

The setup of this camera requires a computer. You can use either Mac or PC for this, I used a Mac. For the initial setup, you need to plug the camera directly into your wireless router. Then you put the included CD in your computer and run the program to locate the IP of the camera. Once you have the IP address, the rest of the setup is done in your browser. This is where you'll join the camera to your wireless network. It was pretty straight-forward for me, but I can understand where some people could get confused. The language used in the setup is very technical and does not offer any explanation of the technical terms. There is plenty of help online if you have any questions about the technical terms and what they mean. I didn't have any problems throughout the setup and I had the camera up and running in about 10 minutes.

There is no included Android/iOS app with this camera, but there are hundreds of IP Camera apps that work with it. My wife has been trying the iOS apps out on her iPad and has found there are lots to choose from. Same goes with my Android smartphone, there are literally hundreds of IP camera apps. The browser interface is not flashy, but definitely gets the job done. There is very little lag when viewing on any of my devices, I'd guess less than 1/2 second. I'm pretty impressed with this aspect, I thought it would be a couple seconds behind at a minimum.

The night vision feature is incredible on this camera. It is important to note that the IR leds used for night vision will glow a soft visible red light, so it is easy to spot the camera in the dark. The night vision is so good, you'd swear there is a light on in the room. I have noticed that during the daytime, the night vision has trouble deciding when to turn on. But I don't really plan on using this during the daytime, so this does not concern me.

The pan/tilt feature is something I didn't think I'd use, but I have used it to track my daughter's movements in her bedroom after converting her crib into a toddler bed. The pan/tilt motor is pretty quiet, but it is audible. The range of motion is very large, much more than I need for a little bedroom.

There are a few features that I do not plan on using. You can set up email alerts when motion is detected, as well as upload images so you can see what triggered the motion. You can also record video from the camera to a DVR or FTP, which can also be triggered by motion. Since I'm not using this camera for security purposes, I don't really have any intention on using them. But I can definitely see where they could be useful in other applications.

I've had this camera running for about a week and have had no problems so far. I am very pleased with this camera and I'm thinking of getting another to put in my garage for security purposes. If I had to find a fault with the camera, it would be that the web-browser interface is a little clunky and looks like a website from the late 90's. I would highly recommend this camera to anyone looking for an IP camera that can be viewed on a smartphone, tablet, or computer. I can't imagine why anybody would spend more on a camera when this camera appears to have everything most people need.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Cannot get a better camera for the value!
review_body:
In the past I had bought a Foscam camera and it was just an overall bad experience so I was leary when it came to getting this model. However the low pricetag on goldbox pushed me to give them another try. I'm glad I did. This camera from time to time goes on sale for just under $70. First of all, the picture is what you'd expect from an IP camera. While not HD it's quite good. I watch my cats on my Android phone when I'm out and about. Robert Chou produced a great Android app called IP Cam Viewer Pro. Buy it, it's a smooth running app. He has added just about any camera model you can imagine to the driver list.

Pros of camera:
1)Nice quality video
2)Pans and tilts smoothly
3)Microphone actually works
4)Is fairly easy to setup if you have moderate networking skills
5)Wireless N (very nice feature for a low cost camera)
6)Excellent night vision (the feature that made me upgrade to new camera)
7)Range of motion is great

Cons of camera:
1)From time to time it has a couple second loss of control. Camera just goes unresponsive then comes right back like nothing was wrong. I run mine on wireless N network. This is really my only gripe and why I took one star off. With all the great things this camera does it's not a deal breaker in any way. It doesn't happen enough for me to worry about.

Overall, this camera cannot be beat for features and cost.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I purchased 4 of these cameras late in 2011 and have been using them since then. The cameras are very good quality. Foscam's service is awesome. Technical support returned my phone call within 20 minutes to help me install them! The service technician was very informative and helpful and successfully set up all 4 cameras for me to view both on my computer as well as via an app for Android on my phone.
I highly recommend Foscam for all your security camera needs. I have not been disappointed in any way with the cameras or Foscam's excellent service.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: This camera works very well. The picture is very clear. I use it to check on my dog. I have found out that he spends nearly all of his time sitting at the front door looking for us to come home. It's great to be able to pan the camera.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Ok so I NEVER write reviews.. not my thing but that being said I had to say How PERFECT these monitors are!!! Wait cameras.. I downloaded the 5$ app from foscam works PERFECT!! Make sure you figure out port forwarding.. I am a mom on a budget and wanted video monitors for multiple rooms, this was the PERFECT answer! It can do a whole bunch of stuff but I haven't figured it all out yet!! Also I only know I can listen to one room at a time, which is fine as the other rooms are close to m room. Hope this helps!!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I purchased this camera to be able to see my daughter while I'm at work. I wasn't able to understand the directions (didn't have the patience?) to set up port forwarding or whatever to be able to view remotely, so I called Foscam US for help. I have to say it was the best thing I could have done since Albert logged on to my system remotely, got everything configured correctly and saved the settings/DDNS site address to my Notepad. I have read where some doubt the validity of customer service claims but I made this purchase on Amazon and even tried to get help from my router support (who's instructions supposedly bypassed the firewall or something yet still didn't work).
The reason I'm giving the camera only 3 stars is because the tilt/pan doesn't seem to be working as it did initially (I've had it less than a week). If I hit the left or right directional arrow more than twice it pans all the way to the opposite side with no way to stop it. I have maneuvered the camera so that it's in a position that is functional but I dread any future adjustments.
02/13/13 I'm very frustrated that a plugin is required to add audio but there's no further explanation nor any information on either the forum or user manuals. In fact there are many similar questions asked on the forum, most without answer.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: For the price, you can't go wrong
review_body:
Foscams get a lot of bad rep for several things like constant rebooting and the such. I have four and while this particular one was a gift to a family member, I can attest that for the bang, this is the best camera on the market. Pan and tilt more than make up for the 640x480 picture resolution they provide. Plus, if you plan to monitor via a remote device like a cell phone, you don't want an HD video feed.

I have also found that a lot of the complaints about these cameras are mostly \\"user\\" caused. Improper set up and use of the router are the number one causes of complaints. How do I know this? Because I was one of them that constantly complained about the camera. Then, I decided to do some schooling on networking and found that most of my woes were self-inflicted because I wasn't \\"doing it right!\\".

While these are Wi-Fi cameras, I strongly recommend wiring them if they are going to be used for serious surveillance. Main reason being is that there are so many things that can interfere with Wi-Fi and cause it to either fail or become very week. The use of a microwave oven that is between the camera and your router is one of the main causes for camera \\"loss of signal\\". Again the camera gets blamed when in actuality, it's physics to blame. Florescent lights also interfere with Wi-Fi. Many homes use these now to save on power.

These are also indoor cameras but I am using two of them outside. So far, no problems. I do have them in a place where they are not exposed to direct moisture. They are under an eave and in a carport. This winter, so far, they have seen temps in the teens and still functioned properly. Do not use them outdoors without risking damaging them as my results may not be the same as yours. :)

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Great Camera. Easy to Install, Pain to setup networking
review_body:
This camera is really good.
Pros:
Easy to install (however haven't found time to explore 2 way sound and recording). Easy to use. The best way to install is to either use the included CD or in my case i saw this guy's video on youtube, profile name was Ackwardhamster. He has given a great explanation, step by step instructions to setup the camera. Clarity of the camera is great and it covers a very large area.

Cons:
Networking was a pain but eventually worked for me. Since I use the AT&T 2Wire router, I looked up port forwarding and found a video by a guy with profile wiseguy775 on youtube. Just like the guy explained the ip address of the cam should be forced 192.xxx.1.60, to be outside the range of the router which was .64 to .253
Then i was able to port forward, but it was not working for me. I used various ports like 777, 8060, 8070. None of these worked. Eventually one of my friend told me to use 19732 and somehow it worked for me. Didnt do anything different except a different port number and it worked great. So try this port, might work for you.

I used youtube since I actually always do that first, though I have to say the CD was really easy to use, at least to get started.

review_body:
Decided to pick up one of these cams after my car was hit in front of my house. For those of you giving this cam a low rating because you failed to set it up wireless, DO SOME RESEARCH. While i am a computer tech, the overall setup was NOT hard for those who will take the time to READ the manual and/or RESEARCH on the internet. The manual, google & youtube are your friends.

Also, someone mentioned you have to pay for services to be able to view your wireless cam externally (away from your home network, at work/mobile phone) this is NOT accurate. Once setup wirelessly, if done correctly you can view externally without paying as everything is handled through your wireless router...not sure what others are claiming about this.

I've only had the cam for a few days, but i am very impressed with the overall quality...for less than $100 you can't beat it. I will most likely be picking up another for the other side of my house. If anyone has questions and/or would like to see the one i have setup live (which took all of 20minutes if that) let me know...

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Not So Hard To Set Up
review_body:
These cameras are amazing! Until I started doing some research, I had no idea these cameras each encompassed a tiny computer and web server! My mind was still back in the day when analog video went down a wire.

I studied the reviews of this camera here on Amazon for a couple of hours, trying to figure out where most of the snags and pitfalls were, in advance of ordering. For example, here is a handy tip from another user: \\"If you want to use the preset camera positions you MUST first uncheck the \\"disable preset\\" box in the PTZ menu under Administrator.\\" You could spend hours trying to figure out the 'presets' without that little tiny tip. Thank you! Once I compiled a list of things like that that were likely to go wrong, and fixes for them, I ordered two cameras.

It took me a couple of hours to get two of these set up, with my bare-bones knowledge of IP's, routers, and networking.

You have to take the setup step-by-step, and test between steps! Don't try to do it all at once! Once you get one function working, proceed to the next level. There is a lot of useful information written in straight English on the Foscam site, so I hardly looked at the manual.

The little program they supply called 'IP Camera Tool' is incredibly useful in getting things set up.

I did NOT use the CD. I just downloaded the latest firmware from Foscam, and updated that on the cameras once they were hooked up (one at a time) thru the ethernet cable. There are two parts to the firmware, a \\"System Firmware\\" and a \\"Web UI\\" firmware. Update both. My cameras were one version behind.

I was able to get video through the ethernet cable in a couple of minutes. I set mine up as fixed IP's so their IP addresses would be a different numerical series than computers, but you don't have to do that if you don't know how. Wireless setup was easy; once you set the IP, enable wireless, and reboot (the camera), you should pull the ethernet (NOT the power) cable. The cam should then communicate by wireless after a minute or so. Once the wireless was working, it was easy to set the motion alarm. Once I got the motion alarm going, I had the system start emailing images to me (had the camera trained on a busy suburban street). In order to test the email settings, you have to hit SUBMIT before you hit TEST, another little tip. And when you see the mysterious words \\"Network Lamp,\\" that particular function turns the blinking green network light on the back of the camera on and off.

Pretty soon I was getting more email messages than I could stand, so I set up a FTP service to a website I own where I can store the pictures.

If you use Internet Explorer you are home free, you can view an array of cameras with one login, and monitor sound, too. I don't like Internet Explorer, I use Firefox, so right now I have to login to each camera for live viewing. There are plenty of free or cheap monitoring solutions out there. Last night I tested out iSpy which seems to do the job of monitoring multiple cameras for not so much dinero. Once I get it all figured out, I will settle down on a permanent monitoring solution. But at first, you will just monitor through your Internet Browser.

Setting up port-forwarding for worldwide-internet-viewing was pretty darn easy considering how much jabber there is in these reviews about it (You need to use a proxy, or go to the coffee shop, to test port-forwarding...I couldn't get it to work until I logged in with a proxy...found that tip on Amazon, too!).

Everything is crystal-clear, with no noise. The night-vision will light up a large room.

Seriously, if you have no concept of what an IP address is, or you don't know how to access your router (and you don't want to learn), you should avoid messing with these cameras. If you just want to run these on your own local network, and you know a little, the complaints about difficult setup are way overstated.

These cameras are an outstanding value, but research carefully to understand the limitations before you buy one.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: EASY, i don't see why people are so -
review_body:
Okay, First I will start with my opinion that I really dislike when people give a tech product a negative review and call it things like worthless, or broken simply because they don't have simple know how on setting up the tech, even something easy as a wifi network at home.

Here are the facts:
IT WORKS!!: I used the set up manual, followed directions, and I was up online; first with a wired connection via ethernet cable, secondly with wireless through my wifi network.
IT'S EASY!!: Following the straight forward directions I was able to be up and running in minutes!

Here is the twist, which in no way is the products fault.. I needed to have a port forwarding service, which you know of if you've been reading these reviews. Without this service I could only observe my camera's feed through my home network and only on my home network.

Do you need to pay for a subscription service? no! "NO/IP" has a free basic service with no special features that let me accomplish my requirements for a home IP camera. At first my connection wasn't working after the simple DDNS setup on NO/IP but that was my internet service provider blocking the connection through a firewall. I found online a PDF with instructions from my ISP giving me exact directions on how to allow the camera to operate freely on the network. I then typed the info from the instructions, rebooted the camera, and I WAS UP AND RUNNING.

If connected to wifi, the new forwarding adress would not work, if not connected to wifi and running on 3G, the forwarding address WOULD work.

BOTTOM LINE, MORAL OF THE STORY, I had everything I needed completed in less then a few hours!. The initial camera set up, IN MINUTES!

I was also able to set up my gmail account to send me an alert email if motion is detected on my camera, and was able to program which days and times to send out these alerts.

The IR feature works great, and the pan and tilt works great too, only downside is no zoom feature which would have been a perfect addition. The software is barebones and does the job, and I also installed an easy set up Iphone app for remote monitoring called "IP Cam Viewer" which only cost a few bucks, no subscription fee.

Four stars to start, will be five after getting some use time in.

WHO CARES ABOUT THE AUDIO? Not meilt works great too, only downside is no zoom feature which would have been a perfect addition. The software is barebones and does the job, and I also installed an easy set up Iphone app for remote monitoring called "IP Cam Viewer" which only cost a few bucks, no subscription fee.

Four stars to start, will be five after getting some use time in.

WHO CARES ABOUT THE AUDIO? Not me

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: How can one not give this five stars?
review_body: I was very reluctant to jump into the home security market via a \\"do it yourself\\" protocol. As a facilities manger that works with high end SD and HD cameras on sophisticated software, I was well aware of the potential cost factor with a home video surveillance setup. Yet I trusted Amazon reviewers, all of them from 5 star to 1 star and made my evaluation. I took the chance.  I purchased one of the FI8910W cameras bundled with the Blue Iris software to give it a shot.  Here is what resulted from that initial purchase....  I have since (within a week) purchased two more of the FI8910W cameras and three of the FI8905W outdoor cameras because I was that satisfied! Yes, they are only standard definition, but they fit my budget and give me a substantial peace of mind while in town or out of town (with the Blue Iris software for PC and the app for iphone/iPad).  All I can add is that if you have a tiny bit of tech know how, you can set this up and feel a bit more comfortable knowing that you installed a really good working, reliable, and cost effective means of monitoring your home. I cant speak for the Foscam tech suppport because I have not had a need to utilize such, but I can say that I am incredibly pleased and saving pennies to try a HD Foscam camera.  BTW, the Blue Iris software supports a multitude of cameras aside from Foscam models.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Very nice product... Tech Support is horrible!
review_body:
I am very pleased with this purchase. After a big SNAFU on the shipping part (UPS accidentally sent my package to China), I finally got what I ordered.
The camera is a nice buy for the price. The iPhone app I'm using is the CamViewer; it does a great job and best of all, its FREE!

Now for the not so great part...

The instructions are not that best, but will get you through the set-up. I called tech support because I'm having issues connecting from outside my LAN.
My ISP only have a handful of blocked ports, so I know that the port I'm using isn't being blocked. So after a 45 minute wait on the phone, a guy answers and states that he's not technical enough to assist me. So he got my contact info and said that someone will call back in approx 30-45 mins. Someone did call me back and remoted in my PC, went through the same process I've already done and she came to the conclusion that my ISP is blocking that port (which they were not) and stated that she can't do anything until that port is open. She didn't even try and troubleshoot. It was a complete waste of my time that I'll never get back.

I think you're better off using Google to find answers than calling their tech support; just my .02

review_body:
In security aspect it's very important logging the actions that took place. Specially the videos

This videocam offered \\"FTP\\" and \\"Streams & records live video & audio\\".
That's tricky, It only record videos when you are watching the place at that moment and by using Internet Explorer (WTF!)
And FTP only stores pictures (yes pictures, in JPG format)

So be very aware of that.

The only way to store videos is using Internet explorer running on Windows.

Unless you want to spend all your time watching your place in live mode, there is no way to consider this a useful surveillance camera

The other browsers only allow to watch live videos and move the camera.

Very tricky, and I lost my money.
Too bad.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
This is a very good, inexpensive camera that works as advertised. My only complaint is that as others have pointed out, the manual is poor. If you are comfortable changing settings on your router, you probably won't have any trouble with it.

The manual is written by someone who's native language is not English. How hard can it be to hire someone to read through the manual and change the language so that it is clearer?

The CD that comes with the camera contains an installation video. That too, was made by someone who's native language was not English. The video suggests using dyndns.com if you have a dynamic IP address. The written manual says you can use a service provided by Foscam. The written manual is correct, Foscam's service is all that you need.

I installed this using a Mac and had no problems, but as I mentioned above, you really need to be comfortable changing network and router settings to get through the manual. There is a Mac specific version of the manual that contains Windows screen shots and it talks about Windows 7 and Vista!

I hope their technical support is good, because some people will need it!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Good cam, easy setup - (Using AT&T Ewire)
review_body: The Foscam is quite a decent little camera for the price. If you're looking for something to monitor your home or business while you are away, this is a good option.    Pros:  - Price  - Ease of Set up  - Smart phone and tablet support  - Great night vision  - Capable of panning (looking left, right, up, down)    Cons:  - No zoom    It's essentially plug and play so it's very easy to set up. I had a live camera feed on my home network within minutes. Getting access to the camera from the outside (like from your work PC or iPhone) is a little more challenging but not too difficult. The Camera feeds are hosted through myfoscam.org and they give you a 3 year account with purchase.I'll add that I was very surprised by the quality of the infrared night vision. My kitchen was pitch black at night but the feed was crystal clear.    AT&T Uverse EWIRE SET UP:    I have AT&T Universe at home so I had to figure out how to access my router and forward the port assigned to the camera so I could view the feed remotely via the internet or my iPhone. The controls for AT&T routers can be accessed by typing 192.168.1.254 into your browser when you're using the network (this means you have to do this while at home, it won't work if you try doing it from work).    From there you need to find the FIREWALL option and then click \\"pinholes and DMZ\\". Step 1 says to select a computer and shows you a list of devices on the network. Find the ipcam and click it. On step 2, click \\"add a new user defined application\\".  For an app name, just type \\"Foscam\\". For protocol, make sure TCP is selected, and where it says \\"Port(or range)\\", type 80 in both the \\"from\\" and \\"to\\" fields. Leave the other fields blank and click \\"add to list\\" then click \\"back\\".    The name \\"Foscam\\" should now be viewable in the Application list. Select \\"Foscam\\" and click the \\"add\\" button. That should associate port 80 with the camera and allow access to the camera feed from outside of your home or business. Now click \\"Save\\".    To test, just type your_cameras_name.[...] into a browser and you should get the login screen asking you to type the cameras user name and password.    One quick note, if you changed the port number for the camera, say to port 88, then your camera's address will become your_cameras_name.[...]    SMART PHONE ACCESS:    There are quite a few apps to choose from for viewing your camera feed on your smartphone but the best free one I manged to find was CamViewer. It was easy to set up and works great. It's comletely free, but if you want to enable sound, it costs $3 to do so.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

I've even gone as far as installing an IP cam monitor on my smartphone and it also works flawlessly.  I will certainly recommend this to friends and family and when I move I'll be picking up more for my overall home monitoring needs.  Amazon does it again.  Thanks!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: The camera works great...just installed it in my outbuilding as a security measure.  The only thing I disliked about this product was that the initial setup was pretty tricky.  The instructions were decent, but not great.  I was actually suprised when I successfully configured it because it required a lot of tinkering.  I agree with the other reviews...the IP Cam Viewer by Chou is the best...I tried 2 free ones and one that I bought and they all stunk.  The IP Cam app is far superior.  Overall, this is a great buy...I'm very pleased and would buy again.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I bought three of these cameras and I'm about to buy a fourth.  These cameras work flawlessly and an excellent buy for the price.  For mobile monitoring I use IP Cam Viewer Pro for the Android by Robert Chou.  You can get the same app for the iPhone.  I also use the Blue Iris Pro program with a dedicated PC for motion sensing all cameras with email image alerts.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Very solid value and surprising quality for the price
review_body:
This is a great little camera as long as you are realistic about what it is. I got one a few weeks back on special for around $70 and even at regular price it is very surprising how well this works. It took a few hours of fighting with my airport extreme router to properly forward the ports, but getting this forced me to learn how to do it and and fixed my Synology Diskstation's remote access at the same time. People who fault this product because of difficulty in remote viewing are just wrong! ANY device attempting to do this WILL have the same issues. It's not a Foscam issue.

The quality is adequate in absolute terms and outstanding if judged in the context of what this unit costs. I have it setup on an Android phone, iPad and mac. I use tinycam Monitor Pro for Android and Foscam's app on the iPad. Tinycam is better. The camera pans quickly and has a huge range of movement. There is no optical zoom, but both the Android and iPad apps lets you pinch to zoom. The 2-way audio does work but is not great. Think bad-webcam audio. Probably ok for monitoring but it would be torture to have a lengthy conversation.

Look - If I owned a business I wouldn't buy a bunch of these and expect hi-def, facial recognizing security, but for putting a few of these up around the house while you're out to give you peace of mind or to monitor pets, I think they're perfect. They do make a higher def version as well and if I see one of those on special I may spring for it. A little crisper image would be nice and optical zoom would make this perfect.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Great camera with NO support for https (encrypted) password
review_body: The camera is Fantastic!! works great, good quality, night vision, etc... a bunch of great features packed in this fairly small camera, but it doesn't make sense to not be able to access it from outside your home network using https, instead one has to use http which can make it pretty easy for someone to gain access to your user and password

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Camera was easy to setup, having network experience, made it a breeze. I can see it being difficult for those who are not network or tech savvy. But I thought the quick setup guide was pretty thorough. After 5 minutes, we were up and running. We're using this as a puppy cam.

Likes:
Easy to setup for those familiar with port forwarding and advanced configs
Pan/Tilt
Nightvision
2-Way Communication
Packaged well and like the CAT5 cable it comes with
Works well with Android App "IP Cam Viewer"

Dislikes:
Web interface looks bland, old
Box states Wireless N, clearly the device I have, does NOT support Wireless N. Luckily it's something I don't mind
Presets don't seem to save for me, after reboot, have to calibrate again.

All in all, I would purchase another one, or another smaller profile FOSCAM.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: This product can be quite complicated. It is NOT plug & play. There are many configuration options. The software requires extensive knowledge of settings and the language that goes with knowing Wireless Routers, HTTP, FTP Servers, WEB Servers, IP configurations. The Quick Start Guide is somewhat of a tongue-in-cheek, poorly translated-to-english, not easy to follow version of an originally Asian/China written guide. Grammar, wording & sequencing are a bit odd. I have seen this many times before, so reading between the lines is necessary.  I have written & currently support multiple company web sites & maintain a Windows 2008 R2 network for a company of 35, so Im somewhat familiar with what it takes. If you want to record activity from installed cameras, logic says you need to move or copy those recordings "off premises" to be reviewed later. Why? Because if your property is being stolen or destroyed, so are the recordings if they are only being stored locally, on premises on a computer in the house or office. Its like any good backup. So an FTP off-site or "cloud" is necessary to protect your files. If your just using the cameras to monitor rooms, or family activity, they would be fine. Read and take your time or you will find yourself being overwhelmed by technology. You will find trial & error the norm.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Last week I received a dual pack FOSCAM FI8910W's that I ordered through AMASON.

The Foscam FI890W is a wireless (802.11 B/G/N) network camera that is packed with features normally
found in more expensive IP cameras.

It has pan and tilt capabilities which means that instead of having a fixed view in one direction like
some of the other cameras, you can pan and tilt it so that you can see what you need within a 300 degree
range and 120 degree tilt angle. Minor con here is there is no zoom feature, which would be nice to have,
but not a necessity. One other observation is that the motor drive is extremely smooth and quiet.

Next, it has night vision provided by a dozen IR LEDs that provide up to 25 feet of night vision. I tried
this and it works quite well and is much better than several other cameras I have worked with in the past.
Camera placement is also a factor to consider especially if your neighbor has bright outside lights.

It should be noted that the camera has a resolution of 640×480 which at first I considered a possible con.
But I found the picture quality quite good even in full screen mode. The camera appears to employ good
quality optics for this price range.

The FI8910W also allows for motion detection, and is very simple to use and setup. It is triggered by
anything that moves in the cameras field of vision. This could be a con for some users as some may want
to select specific areas to monitor motion or set up a higher motion range so that the family dog does not
trigger the device. This can be overcome by using other monitor software such as iSpy.

The camera has two-way communication capabilities through a built in microphone and speaker. The sound
quality is good from the camera speaker. Con here is when speaking using the built in microphone is very weak.
You may want to add a quality microphone or speaker utilizingthe built in mic/spkr jacks located on the back of
the unit to improve sound and voice quality.

You can do remote viewing via a web page or an app for your iPhone or Android phone. To test this, I used my
Samsung Galaxy Note and a free app called Foscam Remote which worked well. There are many other apps out there
that work as well.

For sound, motion or both you may setup the supplied software to send an e-mail alert. It supports sending an
e-mail with pictures and IP address of the device which, if clicked on opens your web browser to view device
in real time even on your phone.

If you need to view the camera outside your network via a web browser, you will have to setup port forwarding
on your router so you can locate the camera via your WAN's IP address. If your WAN does not provide or have
a static IP address, I used no-ip.org to track my dynamic IP address because it was free and dyndns.org is no
longer providing free accounts.

Set up is easy for someone who has experience with this type of camera to set it up on a network and make it
work outside your network via a web browser. Novice users may find themselves at a slight disadvantage, but
should be able to get up and running by utilizing the provided software and documentation. If not, then there is
plenty of documentation and videos located on their website that should be able to help. YouTube has many videos also.

The best thing about this camera was the price. You get all of this for less than $200 (double pack). That's a
great price for a two camera bundle that has so many capabilities.

Take a long hard look at the Foscam FI8910W. It is a very capable camera when compared to other cameras in its price
range that is relatively easy to set up and use. From a cost and performance standpoint, it may well be hard to beat.
I plan to buy several more in the near future to complete my system.

review_body: I got this camera to remotely monitor my condo.  I have an app for my iPhone/iPad that allows me to log in and check anytime of day.  Plus the  camera is setup to turn on when motion is detected and send a series of email pictures to me.  It's a nice feature but BEWARE since the camera has a tendency to false alarm when light levels change.  Despite sensitivity adjustments in the software I have yet to be able to resolve this issue. product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I've been using it for only a short time, but it's working well so far. Getting it set up to work within our wireless network was a piece of cake. Setting up port forwarding so that we can view from elsewhere was more difficult, but that was due to my own limitations. A friend entered the settings in the router software in a few minutes.

I'm able to access the camera from my laptop away from home and also from the CamViewer app on my iPhone. The picture is clear and I'm able to see well even in complete darkness with IR turned on.

Although I was able to follow the instructions in the manual, it is poorly written and could stand a good re-write.

Listen, I won't bore you with all the details. As a doctor, I know when to keep it short. Suffice to say that my story is not new. Classic man suspects maid of stealing money, man installs camera, man catches maid talking negatively about him, man fires maid, tearful call to the INS story. But I will let you in on a secret. Anyway, I have bought dozens of these now for the east wing, and I am even thinking of hiring a man full time to watch the footage. I don't like making maids scream and cry and beg, p.s., and this camera has a very good zoom also.

The end.
Dr. Roman G.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: You get what you pay for. But be technical to set it up
review_body:
I always read reviews with a grain of salt. I don't know whether to trust people's opinions or if their frustration unfairly influence their ratings. I don't understand everybody's complaint with these cameras. I love the ones that I received. I'm disappointed that you cannot disable included DyDNS service. I'm also frustrated that it doesn't support SSL. But for 60 bucks apiece I think they're great.

I agree the setup wasn't simple but only because users don't have the proper skill sets to complete the process successfully. Don't blame the product for your inabilities. They're definitely not for a novice user. An amateur could figure it out if they were so inclined but they do take a technical skill set (or) patience & willingness to configured properly.

And people who complain that you have to connect the cable or the configure the wireless have no clue what they're talking about. I'm a network engineer and I can't think of a single wireless product that doesn't require a wired connection for initial configuration. You can't expect the wireless camera to guess which wireless network and password it's supposed to use. Again don't blame the product.

Great for the value. Don't expect miracles for $60 but I was impressed compared to other ip based cameras I've used for the money.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: If You Value Your Time, Don't Buy This
review_body:
This thing is a piece of junk. It does not work as specified and the instructions are poorly written by someone who is clearly not a native English speaker. I could only get wireless to work without encryption. Countless others online had same problem or couldn't get wireless support to work at all. I'm an IT professional with decades of experience, yet I found myself continually frustrated. The web interface is shoddy.

You might get lucky and find that a subset of the features work for you, but my advice is that if you value your time, don't waste your money on this thing. I spent quite a few hours trying to get it to work correctly and then gave up and returned it to Amazon.

UPDATE 4/2/2013 - I pulled it out of a closet and tried it with a new wireless router. Wireless does indeed work now. However, despite this new capability, my opinion of the camera stands. Bad design and execution.

I bought this foscam as a test for monitoring my kids at home when I'm not and ended up purchasing 5 more after I used the first for a week. The setup is simple. The picture is good. Just a note on the setup, I had quite a bit of problems with getting to the camera over the internet, but not because of the instructions. I have a VoIP device between the modem and router that was blocking all inbound traffic. After I finally figured that out, setting up the camera for remote viewing was simple.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Hard to setup, only worked for 1 day.
review_body: I had read the reviews and decided I was willing to work through the installation issues. It was not easy, but I eventually got it on the wireless network. I was working on our firewall to get it visible from outside the network when the camera started rebooting. It would run for couple of minutes, just long enough to connect to it and see a picture, than the camera would reset itself. Returned for refund. Too expensive to put up with that kind of stuff.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
[[VIDEOID:mo2KEQM3MLW1L9B]]i just got mine and set it up. it definitely is NOT a plug-n-play camera. after using the helpful videos (awesome explanations) from the companies website, setting it up was a breeze (but having just the slightest insight in how your home network functions will definitely help). over all a really good camera for the price.

i have an all mac network, down to the airport extreme. which means its a plus and a minus. it was definitely a good thing when it came to the set up videos. they guy gave brief but thorough explanations and went through set up in more than one type of gateway/router. the downside to using a mac is there is no audio when viewing camera online. however if you use foscams mobile app you get full control of all functions plus the two-way audio feature. the down side to the app is that it cost $6. as a busy person if you just need to view cam through a mobile device then it is perfect and well worth the price.

the only other thing, it's smaller than what i thought. which is a good surprise it sets up anywhere the power cord can reach.

*UPDATE* the very next day i caught the exterminator rummaging through our pill cabinet. great quality picture and sensitive microphone. well worth the investment. comparable cameras sell for $250 and up

*UPDATE* it's been a few months. and i moved to a different place. the camera has held up good. remembering what i learn about port forwarding from the initial installation, made setting up the camera fairly simple. i moved it from the ceiling to the top of the lampshade on an end table, its so out in the open people hardly ever notice it. i only have the one, but i plan on buying a few more and possibly purchasing the blue iris software to see how the whole system works. the picture is good and microphone isn't the best but for the price it's great.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
For the folks here that are concerned about setup, it's pretty easy if you know how to use your router. Here's how it works:

1) Toss the installation CD in the trash, it is basically only used to identify the IP that the camera is on (easy to figure out from your router)
2) Plug the camera into your router using the ethernet cable (mine was provided)
3) From a web browser type in the IP address the camera came up on (should be easy to find from your router's status page)
4) From your web browser, you should now be able to tell the camera about your wifi network via the camera's configuration page.
5) Unplug the ethernet cable and reboot the camera.
6) From your router, grab the MAC address to the camera (now connected on wifi) and permanently assign it the IP it came up on
7) If you have a domain set up, give the camera a name so that you don't have to remember the IP address. (optional)
8) You can now put the name (or local IP) into your web browser whenever you want to access the camera.

At this point you have the camera set up on your local network. You can add users, set passwords, etc. all from any internet browser on your local network. If you want to open up connections from outside your network (like, say from your phone over 3/4g), you need to establish port forwarding to the camera.

Be aware that if you don't have a static IP from your ISP that your IP may change, and you may need to update it (via various methods, some of which can be automated) in order to access the camera from outside your local area network.

It really is very straightfoward if you know how to use your router. If your router software is difficult to use (as mine was), flash your router with dd-wrt to make it useful.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
This is one of the best finds on Amazon. My wife and I use this to keep an eye on our 11 month old while sleeping. Using apps from the Apple App Store (and I'm sure they're on Android as well) we can connect flawlessly and see our son. The camera supports full pan and tilt, tilting from 12:00 to about 4:00 and I believe it will make a full 360 turn, or close to it.

The initial setup is done via ethernet to setup user accounts and network settings. After adding it to your wifi network, it will always connect when the power is disconnected.

The IR lights are powerful enough to see in complete darkness clearly and the automatic sensor will turn them off when there is enough light in the room. The IR LEDs switching on and off can be a bit loud, especially in twilight conditions while the camera struggles to find the best lighting however this can be turned off.

The software also supports user accounts and group security which is nice if you need to grant view only or operator access to someone.

I do wish the power cord was a bit longer, roughly 5-6 feet or so.

Overall, great security camera or baby monitor, would certainly buy again without hesitation.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: The wireless is bugged, and support doesn't get back to you.
review_body:
This camera has great video quality and sound quality. Unfortunately, it has too many bugs in my opinion to be ready for prime-time.

Firstly, the web interface of Foscam.com does not permit you to download the drivers for the camera. This is highly annoying. You provide your e-mail address, and then you get an e-mail from Foscam with the links to download the drivers. Go to Foscam.com and hit downloads on the right. To make matters even worse, my camera shipped with firmware version \\"11.37.2.48.\\" This is disappointing to me because after giving my e-mail to them the download link they sent back was for \\"11.37.2.46\\" -- two iterations the predecessor to what the camera shipped with. That means that they don't update the download links and that the camera is effectively unsupported from the manufacture. I'm suspicious that this is part of the Foscam game: cheap disposable cameras that are primarily changed in just firmware. It doesn't seem like from the reviews there is much of a difference between the 8910W and the 8918W. And, on that note, who seriously decrements the model number when update the model?

Foscam marketing, and support: 1.

So, why would I care about the firmware anyway? Well, turns out Foscam models have a long standing issue with WPA2 and AES. Not sure why, or what the problem is. It's all closed-source proprietary trash from China, but the problem is there. Just search the internet for \\"wpa2 + aes + foscam\\".

Q/A: 2

Now onto what most people care about, if you wire the camera up to a router you'll get pretty good performance and control out of it. The colors are decent and the I/R is pretty reasonable too.

Picture quality: 4

Still can't recommend this camera. It comes with a bunch of features but the ones that I'd find useful it does very poorly. It's reminiscent of a first-generation LG product from 2005.

I love checking on my animals during the day. Motion detection works great. As does the IR. Hearing the audio also works great but using it to talk through it does not. It either feedsback horribly or is too low for anyone to hear.
Zoom would be nice.
Setup was easy using the manual. I also like that you don't have to have a domain to see it over the internet. Fpscam provides you with a built in subdomain using their domain. And it works like a charm.
I am very pleased though the audio would be nice as would the zoom.

Update April 2013

Still very happy with the camera. The two way audio does not work without plugging in external speakers AND an external microphone. Otherwise it works very well picture is great and controls are handy. The coverage is fantastic.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Good Camera for the money but installation instructions are horrible.
review_body:
I bought this camera based on good amazon reviews despite the horrible reviews regarding installation. I gave it a try because I consider myself relatively savvy when it comes to technology in general. I figured I would simply return it if I cannot get it to work. I was close to returning it but I finally got it to work after tinkering with it for several days and reading online forums, videos and such. Most people would probably just give up since it is so frustrating.

The Good:
1)Good value for the money.
2)Decent video/picture quality.
3)Generally works as advertised once you get it working.
4)You can view the camera right away in your own network. The problem is when trying to view it remotely which why most people want to buy this in the first place.

The Bad:
1) Horrible installation instructions for viewing it remotely!

This camera comes with it's own free DDNS account (free for 3 years) at xxxxx.myfoscam.org BUT IT DOES NOT WORK! I tried it but I cannot get a successful DDNS connection.

The instruction video tells you to use DYN DDNS but that service is no longer free. Besides, foscam has their own so why not have instruction on how to set that up. I ended up using the free no-ip.org ddns which is fine since it is still free. I hope I don't have to pay for at least 3 years. The instructions in general is just very confusing and the accent of the lady on the instruction video is so annoying. What the hell is a rooter?

2) Audio is bad. It works to a degree but it picks up too much noise. I don't care for the audio feature so I don't really care.

Overall, I think it is a good product and a good value despite the installation headache. I would not recommend it to someone who has a hard time getting computers/gadgets/technology related things to work. This camera would be for people who are computer savvy and like to tinker.

If you decide to get it,buy it from Amazon so that you can return it hassle free if you cannot get it to work.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Baby monitors cost too much, come with lousy screens and cameras and we can't see them on our smartphones, tablets or desktops. IPCamera could be the ultimate solution for someone looking for a flexible baby monitor, here is my experience:

The Camera:
* The picture quality is good for the cost, significantly better than the Summer Infant video monitor it was replacing
* Dark picture quality is exceptional
* The camera itself is larger than most packaged baby-cams though for us that didn't matter
* The speaker in the camera is weak so sending audio to the camera is a gimmick that doesn't work well
* The built in web monitoring tools are weak though you likely won't use them much

Setup:
This is an IP Camera and does little or nothing to help the tech novice. If you know your way around a router and are willing to spend some time reading then it is easy enough to figure out (see the excellent info in the review from R.Tickle). To fully setup this camera you need to know how to do the following:
* Log into your router to find the cameras IP address
* Assign a static IP address
* Setup port forwarding on your router

If you don't know what those things and aren't interested in learning then then this may not be the product for you.

As a baby monitor:
The challenge here is finiding the right app for your device. For iOS \\"Baby Monitor for IP Camera\\" is perfect and will do everything your out of the box solution does and more. Android is a stickier problem to solve, \\"IP Cam Viewer Pro\\" seems to be the best option out there but it isn't ideal for things like overnight audio monitoring. I hope the options for both iOS and Android improve in the coming months and I expect they will.

The advantages of having the monitor on all our \\"smart devices\\" (we use iPad, iPhone, Android and Kindle Fire) as well as the ability for me to see my little one wake up when I am at my desk at work are huge wins for me. You can also capture stills or video right to your device which is something I wish I had many times with the out of the box monitor. Overall I believe an IP Camera is the best monitoring solution for any tech savvy parent, the benefits massivley outweigh the downsides.

ONE BIG DRAWBACK. Using an IP Camera means that the monitor is stuck at home or will need to be setup on another wireless network to make it work. If you plan to travel a lot with your child and want your monitor to travel with you then I would suggest buying a cheap audio only monitor to suppliment this. You can also use it to get around some of the Android app shortcomings for overnight audio monitoring and it gives you a decent travel option.ork are huge wins for me. You can also capture stills or video right to your device which is something I wish I had many times with the out of the box monitor. Overall I believe an IP Camera is the best monitoring solution for any tech savvy parent, the benefits massivley outweigh the downsides.

ONE BIG DRAWBACK. Using an IP Camera means that the monitor is stuck at home or will need to be setup on another wireless network to make it work. If you plan to travel a lot with your child and want your monitor to travel with you then I would suggest buying a cheap audio only monitor to suppliment this. You can also use it to get around some of the Android app shortcomings for overnight audio monitoring and it gives you a decent travel option.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Good camera. Setup is easy, although not so if you follow the documentation.
Do *not* rely on the "test setup" for email. It never works, although the email notifications do work
if your settings are correct. Just enter settings and try it out.
Video and photo quality are very good.
Motion detection is ONLY for photos, one at the moment of detection and then 2-4 every second or so.
You have to buy add-on software to do video motion detection and recording. (e.g. blueiris, xprotect, etc...)
Wireless setup is a snap. Just remember to plug it in to a DHCP-enabled network *first* via a physical cable, get the IP, then reconfigure as desired from the web console.
Have not gotten audio to work, as I'm not a Windoze user, and that seems to be required.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

We downloaded a free app from the app store for our iphones and kept track of our cat day and night while we were gone. I am considering to purchase more to see the whole house.

However, be aware that the set up is not user friendly. The instructions only cover a few routers and you will have to dig through the internet in forums and see how to set it up for outside the house. I never contacted Foscam but I did get frustrated with it and got it done after I left it sit and came back with a fresh mind.

This camera is great. Enough said.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Pleasantly surprised!  (used as a baby monitor)
review_body: I am using this camera as a baby monitor to keep an eye on my child when they are sleeping (and for later one when playing in the room alone).  I do not use the audio monitoring as I already have an audio monitor in place with a handset.  The night time vision range and the wireless range of the camera is far beyond what I had expected at this price.  It really can see all the way across my nursery in pitch black without even straining.  The ability to monitor my child from my laptop or my iphone has been wonderful.  The ability to control the camera to scan the room or adjust the angle will be indispensable once we hit the toddler phase.  You can even view your child via this webcam when you are not even in state.  We've been able to give family members a link and password to peek in on the little one.  I really couldn't be happier with this purchase.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

Hardware seems to be fine. All functions explained in the manual also but foscam needs to improve after sales support.

silent motor

Cons:

no sensible phone apps

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I already had one Foscam in our garage and wanted another for inside the house when we are away on trips.  I purchased this from Amazon.  It had slightly newer firmware which has a much improved web interface.  Camera performs just like the older one except for one thing.  The camera on the one I received will not switch to night vision.  I see the LEDs on but the image is almost black.  I can make out items a few inches away but that's it.  I have gone through the Foscam troubleshooting but it still won't work correctly.  I have emailed Foscam but after 4 days no response.  Very disappointing.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Had to apply 4 firmware updates before it would work, image quality is just ok. It's worth $75, but not much more. Ended up returning it.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Ordered two of these, 1 worked great the other had faulty IR
review_body:
Ordered two of these when they were on sale. One worked perfectly, the other worked great, but the IR only had a range of about 1 ft. Fortunately Amazons quick returns process had me with a working replacement 1 day later.

Image quality is great. The firmware upgrade is a little cumbersome, but for the price I paid these were great value.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Foscam FI8910W is a fine camera. Easy to use and understand interface, provides great visuals, and basically lives up to expectations.

Installation required assistance. Had trouble with recorded files and tech support set it up remotely. Problem is it's not explained clearly what they are doing at that point so you continue on still not understanding what was wrong to begin with. But if you are in a hurry, it's a done deal and all systems are go.

Overall this piece of equipment is worth purchasing and using as it provides fully to its purpose - giving peace of mind. I would certainly recommend it.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: One of the best IP cams out there
review_body:
I have never used an IP camera before, and was looking for an expensive one to get me started. I researched about multiple options out there, and finally settled for this one on Amazon (the deal price of $68 helped!). Must say, I have not been disappointed.
The camera is great, though it took some time to figure out how to get the external name to work. It does come with 2 years of free DDNS service (you will need this if you do not have a fixed IP address) though you can equally use the 'publish my IP address by email' option. I prefer the DDNS service, and it works well.
Great pan and tilt, great night-vision. The app to use this on an android phone is not that great, but there are other apps that work equally well on this camera. Accessing from Internet Explorer is not a problem, though cannot get sound with Chrome.
If you have not used an IP camera before, I would recommend this one. I'll go a step further - if you need help setting it up, write me a note and I can help.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Understanding the value of this wireless webcam
review_body: You will not go wrong with this camera. It will however require some common knowledge about your wireless network and or how to hard line it in via usb. Mine has been up for a couple of months now and has a great picture. Workds on home wireless , remotely via web sie and even with free down load of phone app.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Some care needed to set up but seems to work
review_body:
First - the camera seems well put together and not bad quality. It is not HD but the pic quality is ok and the IR does work well.

Second - I have a 64 bit W7 machine and this is not what you need to setup this camera. The IP camera Tool shows nothing under 64 bit systems and also if you goto 'basic setup' and try to enter your IP addresses manually it will say 'Illegal params' when you submit. I believe this is because the camera does not understand 64 bit packets etc. Eventually I did cotton onto this (after trying dozens of other measures such as no security on the wifi hub) and tried an XP 32 netbook I have. The IP camera tool found the camera and it took 5 mins to get the camera working. You do need to let it reboot when submitting changes and then unplug it so it reboots again but then it does work. I have remote access working (I think) but yet to do the email notifications which is what I really want working.

I have also to say that my wifi Hub (BT Home hub 2.0) didn't really help - port forwarding is not very easy to fathom.

I will update this review when I have done more - just to say that all indications are that it does not work with 64 bit windows.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Love the cameras!! 2 stars because of No Tech Support
review_body: I was going to buy all my cameras from amazon, but Foscam said they gave free telephone support etc..  WELL, THAT NEVER HAPPENED! This is from their web site (Please note: In order to receive Free Telephone Technical Support as well as our US Based 1 Year Replacement Warranty, you must purchase directly from Foscam.us) SO I DID. I tried to reach them by phone 7 times, left messages, NO ONE ever called back.  I also emailed at least 10-12 times, again NO response.... I think the cameras are wonderful & I have actually recommended them to 6 other business friends, BUT I do warn them that they may not get any help what so ever, and they still haven't as far as I know.  How sad, imagine how many more cameras would sell if they actually responded like they say they will, even every other time we contacted them.  I bet sales would at least DOUBLE. Foscam, you have a great product, please give people the support you promise.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
We raise animals, and wanted to be able to keep an eye on them when they were getting ready to give birth. Decided to give this camera (2 of them actually) a try. They arrived a day earlier than expected (another good job by Amazon!). The items came with everything you need to get started. The "Quick Installation Guide" was simple and easy to understand. Start with the unit "wired", make the connection with the router, then install the software, and make the connection wirelessly. I use MAC filtering for security on my network. Both the wired and wi-fi MAC addresses are printed on the base of the unit, so... no problem.

Wired... They are outstanding. Image is clear, color is very good, 2 way sound is good as well. Wireless... The farther they are from your router, the harder it is for the router to "detect" the camera and the less responsive they are to commands (pan, tilt etc), and movement becomes choppy. (Which is to be expected) The location of my cameras are in covered animal shelters which are well beyond the far end of our (3000sf) house (opposite side of the house from the router's location). I was bummed at the choppy performance at that distance. So before I returned them as not suitable for my application, I thought I'd give something a try. I purchased a Belkin Dual-Band Range Extender and added it to my home network. I placed it at the opposite end of my house (closer to the camera's location) and ta-da... they work perfectly!

These cameras are wireless b/g/n compatable, and the software allows for the monitoring of up to 9 cameras at a time. I like that we can access the cameras from our computers and/or smartphones. The only thing that I don't really like about the software is that it makes you "Log in" each time you want to view the cameras. I want to be able to click an icon on my desktop and view my cameras. Their configuration has you click their icon, double-click the IP address, click a log-on "Submit" button, and one other button before you get to the image itself. (A bit of an inconvenience) I guess I could solve this problem by assigning the camera a static IP address that is outside my router's DHCP assignment range, and place a shortcut to that IP on my desktop.

Overall, we're pretty happy with the purchase. They do what they're supposed to do, and that's all we were looking for when we purchased them. The price was reasonable, and they really help us out. Like I said at the beginning "So Far... So Good!"ddress, click a log-on "Submit" button, and one other button before you get to the image itself. (A bit of an inconvenience) I guess I could solve this problem by assigning the camera a static IP address that is outside my router's DHCP assignment range, and place a shortcut to that IP on my desktop.

Overall, we're pretty happy with the purchase. They do what they're supposed to do, and that's all we were looking for when we purchased them. The price was reasonable, and they really help us out. Like I said at the beginning "So Far... So Good!"

review_body: Product arrived as described. Appears to be built well. Had difficulty setting up-and a rep from Foscam (Simon) returned my call about 2 hours later and remotely set up the cameras for me. Thank you Simon!!!! Please note that this camera will require a power source (outlet). Also...it was fairly easy to get it up and running using the Cat5 cable (supplied). However, I spent over 2 hours trying to get the cameras to communicate with my modem before calling tech support...and then it was a 2 hour wait for callback. It will take \\"some doing\\" to do all the steps to make the cameras viewable from my Droid (port forwarding, etc.). Not a quick and simple process...therefore-please do your research and watch videos on Youtube before and after purchasing so you will have an idea of what you will need to do in order to get these to work for your particular application. The written instructions supplied (and the instructions on the included CD) are not as detailed as they should be. I actually purchased mine direct-and AFTER the technician solved my issues he asked if I was a member of Amazon and if so would I post an honest review-and thus I have. This is my first product review and I hope it will help someone.
