product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Decent camera, gets the job done most of the time
review_body:
First, this will be a long review as I am including a setup tutorial below.

Second, I don't believe most of the reviews on here are real. I'm pretty sure all of the reviews that call out specific customer service reps are fake. Those users only have reviews for one item - this camera.

Now, on to this camera. I was looking at video monitors for my baby's room and was just baffled at how some companies could justify charging 2-300 dollars for a video monitoring system. I looked into network security cameras and settled on one I felt met my needs for a far lower price. I think the price they ask for this is fair.

Notes:
The plastic of the camera feels a bit cheap and flimsy, but once it is mounted, I am comfortable with it and sure there will not be a problem
It is larger than I expected it to be.
The camera occasionally reboots for an unknown reason.

I will say that this camera probably will not be easy to set up for a lot of people. I feel like you need to have a medium-high level of tech understanding to get this running on your own.

Here is a detailed list of what I did to set up the camera which can be used as a tutorial. This is Windows specific.

In-Home viewing (Inside my home network)
- I ignored the CD that came with it. I find that most of the time the software provided by the company doesn't get in to the level of detail I prefer when setting these things up.
- Plugged the camera in to the wall, then attached the provided network cable to the camera and my router.
- Checked my router for the assigned I.P. address and MAC address of the camera
- Entered the camera's I.P. address and port number (I believe it was 22) into my web browser (I use Chrome), a la xxx.xxx.xx.12:22.
- Logged in as Admin and started going through settings.
- Clicked \\"Alias Settings\\" to change the camera name. I called mine BabyCam. When you are logged in to the camera, this will appear as the title in the tab you are viewing as \\"Device(BabyCam)\\".
- Date and Time settings. Set it to Central time and picked time.nist.gov as the time server to sync to.
- Users. I added two additional users, one for me and one for my wife. Note that you CAN NOT change the admin password when you are logged in as Admin!
- Went back to my router and added a static I.P. for the camera. The exact process varies depending on the router you have, but the basic concept involves entering the MAC address of the camera and the static I.P. you want the device to have inside your network. I arbitrarily set the address to xxx.xxx.xx.49 and saved the setting, which restarts my router.
- Disconnected then reconnected the power plug to the camera. This causes it to connect to the assigned I.P. address you just created.
- Navigate to the new I.P. address you set up. In my case this is xxx.xxx.xx.49:22.
- Log in to the camera.
- Navigate to the \\"Basic Router Settings\\" tab.
- Uncheck the \\"Obtain IP from DHCP Server\\" box. We want to tell the camera which I.P. to use.
- In the \\"IP Addr\\" box, enter the I.P. you specified as static in your router settings.
- Enter your subnet mask. Most cases this is 255.255.255.0. To be sure, you can type \\"cmd\\" in the Search box of the Windows Start button to open a command prompt. Type \\"ipconfig\\" and hit enter. Subnet mask will be buried in the results, usually 4-6 lines from the top of the result output.
- Gateway and DNS Server should be set to your router's IP address.
- Enter a port number you want the camera to use. This can be any number, really. You don't want it to collide with anything else on your network, though, so pick something weird. I used the year of my birth and added a 1 to the end.
- Leave \\"Network Lamp\\" unchecked. Keeps that pesky green light on the back of the camera from flashing in your baby's room.
- Click \\"Submit\\". Your camerawill restart.
- Once the restart is complete, go to the Wireless LAN settings and set up your wireless router properties if you plan to use the camera on your wireless network. When you submit, the camera will restart again.
- I ignored the ADSL, UPnP, and DDNS settings tabs. I set up dynamic DNS stuff on my own using [...]. Use the comment section if you want instructions on this.
- I also ignored the rest of the settings. Since I am using this for a crib monitor I don't really want a zillion motion-detected pictures taken. Babies move a lot. ;-)

To change Admin password, log out of the camera interface, then log back in as one of the new users you set up. Change the admin password, then save. Camera will reset.

At this point you should be able to use the camera wirelessly anywhere in your house and access the camera feed from any device in your network by using a web browser and navigating to the camera's I.P. address and port number, logging in, and clicking \\"Live Video\\".

For viewing on a mobile device, download one of many apps available in the Play store (I use an Android device). My app of choice is IP Cam Viewer Lite. This does not mean it is the best. :-)

Good luck. Happy to answer questions in the comments section.e the camera on your wireless network. When you submit, the camera will restart again. - I ignored the ADSL, UPnP, and DDNS settings tabs. I set up dynamic DNS stuff on my own using [...]. Use the comment section if you want instructions on this. - I also ignored the rest of the settings. Since I am using this for a crib monitor I don't really want a zillion motion-detected pictures taken. Babies move a lot. ;-) To change Admin password, log out of the camera interface, then log back in as one of the new users you set up. Change the admin password, then save. Camera will reset. At this point you should be able to use the camera wirelessly anywhere in your house and access the camera feed from any device in your network by using a web browser and navigating to the camera's I.P. address and port number, logging in, and clicking \\"Live Video\\". For viewing on a mobile device, download one of many apps available in the Play store (I use an Android device). My app of choice is IP Cam Viewer Lite. This does not mean it is the best. :-) Good luck. Happy to answer questions in the comments section.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I've had the Foscam FI8910W camera for only a few days now, and I didn't get to explore all its features yet, but here is my feedback on the features which I tried so far:

Pros:
- Really reach feature set:
> pan/tilt motion remotely controlled - works nicely from both computers and iPhone/iPad, although continuous scanning (both vertical and horizontal) works more reliably than moving stet-by-step.
> infrared LEDs for surveillance in the dark work beautifully
> two-way sound is also nice

- Connectivity to my home wireless network worked flawlessly.
- Doing port forwarding and connecting to the camera from the internet (mostly from my iPhone when I'm away) worked very well. It was the first time I did such a thing, but I do consider myself reasonably technically savy, and I learned a good deal doing it.

- Besides using the free dynamic DNS host service provided by Foscam themselves (which is very nice of them to provide) to deal with the ever-changing IP address from my Internet Service Provider, I also signed up with [...] for a similar service, but this one allows me to automatically include the IP port on which I set up the camera (different from the default 80), so I don't have to type :XXXX at the end. It also allows me to have an easier to remember host name for the camera.

- I liked that you actually don't have to install any software to connect to the camera remotely: once you have it set up, you can use a browser from any computer or mobile device, which is very cool.

- The camera looks really good: nice texture and shape, looks like good quality, very silent when it moves.

- Amazingly good price (<$80) for the features and quality.

Cons:
- The printed manual that came in the box is quite sketchy. The full User Guide on the CD has a lot of good information, but it's written in very approximate English. Mind you, English is not my mother tongue either, but I tend to become suspicious of a product when it comes with a badly written (or translated) manual. Having said that, I've read some totally useless manuals in the past, and this is NOT one of them: you can actually follow the instructions despite its language shortcomings.

- There is one feature which seems somewhat important and it hasn't worked for me so far: you are supposed to be able to define 8 predefined directions of view, and then just click one to have the camera pan/tilt to look in than preset direction. It just didn't happen for me, so I'm going to contact their tech support to see how to make it work. UPDATE: I got this feature to work! It turns out that it is disabled by default, and you need to turn it on in PT settings. The manual doesn't mention it, but if you go through the options in the web UI you can find it.

- I went to the Foscam website looking for firmware upgrades (hoping that they might fix the problem above), but the link they give doesn't allow you to download anything: instead they ask you for your email address to send you upgrades, and they graciously warn you that they are going to spam you with future product offers at that email - no way to opt out of that. Searching the web for firmware upgrades, I just found a bunch of complaints from people who applied an upgrade only to have their cameras stop working, so now I am not that eager to upgrade anything now.

Features not yet tried:
- Setting up email alerts and motion/sound alarm. Will try it soon and update the review. UPDATE: I just tried it, and it was really easy setting it up to send motion alarm emails to my gmail account, following the snapshot from the manual. For some reason the first 3 tests failed, but then it started working. The manual doesn't explain this, but the alert emails are actually very nice: they contain 5 or 6 snapshot frames taken a few seconds apart, so you actually get an idea what is going on even before you connect to the camera. The email also contains a clickable link to the camera, so it's very easy to get the live video and audio feed. Pretty cool!
- Setting up multiple cameras. If the alarm works, I am going to buy at least one more camera. UPDATE: given that the alarm works, I guess I have no choice but to buy another camera now :-)

Bottom line: this is a really good product, with very few (and minor, imho) shortcomings. I would definitely recommend it.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I did not purchase this item from Amazon. I purchased the white version of this item, same model number, from a different source on sale. I actually got two. I put one in each baby and toddlers room.

It took a couple hours going through their online videos at the foscam website to get this going. I am running a Mac computer so I believe it is a little more difficult but I could set one up again in about ten minutes.

You have to hook these cameras up hard wire ethernet to the computer first, which they provide, to initialize them or something and then you can do the wireless thing. The picture is very decent and I have them hooked up using the small antennas. Mine came with both small, about 4 inche or so long antennas and some that are like a foot long. Both cameras are within 12 feet of my router.

I didn't have much success using my apple time capsule because the last update got rid of some things that the instructional videos go over. An updated instructional video would be nice. I ended up using the main FIOS router

Anyway, there are plenty of mount options. I mounted mine upside down and then checked the settings for flip and horizontal or something so that the picture is normal looking on my computer.

I am happy with these and the pan/tilt feature. I would have preferred a zoom feature as well but I did not look closely enough at the description. They are kind of large in a bedroom if you are worried about looks.

Here are the bad things. If you have a mac, you can't put more than one camera in one browser window at a time. It is not a supported feature. If you run windows, you can have multiple cameras tiled in one browser window. It isn't a deal breaker for me but it is annoying. The other annoying thing is that the Windows system has more options and has the listening function and speaking function from the computer and Mac does not. There is a claimed work around for two way audio with Mac but I have been unable to get it to function. The way I get around it is that when I am using chrome, I just have a tab at the top for the baby's room and one for the toddler. I click it and it opens a window and I press another option and the video pops right up.

Either way, the infrared lights are more than bright enough in total darkness to see everything. There are presets in the software that allow you to pick a spot and then just go back to it by selecting the number of the preprogrammed spot. You can move the camera all around and then just press the number and it zooms back to your spot. The speed at which it can go vertical, horizontal, etc is all individually adjustable.

The microphone is extremely sensitive. I can hear the baby breathing from about six feet away maybe 7.

It is normally a color camera until it gets too dark and then it becomes black and white. the infrared Leds can be turned on or off from the computer or phone app

My favorite function I believe is the operation from my android phone. I am using Ip Cam Viewer basic (actually upgraded to pro for $4, I forget what extra features there are) and I can pull up both windows on my huge galaxy note 2, 5.5 inch screen at one time. There are many camera apps out there. All you have to do is put in the correct IP address and port. Pick your favorite app. You have to select one window though if you wish to hear that particular camera microphone or do any panning, scanning, tilt, etc. This application allows full control over the camera and has preset locations as well. Both the computer and the android app allows automatic up/down constant scanning, or left right or kind of a zig zag pattern.

My wife and I don't go out much due to the kids. The last few times we have gone out we put both kids down to sleep at night, and have the 15 year old babysit. He really only has to be there in case they wake up or there is a fire. So while I am at the restaurant that most likely has free wifi, I have my phone with its kickstand open an I am able to view my children live to see what is going on. If the toddler starts to get up and take his diaper off to pee all over I can call my son and have him intervene. Or perhaps the baby is crying too much and I am able to hear this. I can easily operate the cameras to move wherever. I mention free wifi because I believe this live camera feed with chew up your data pretty quick on your phone plan

It is great piece of mind so that we don't have to open the bedroom door to check on the kids and risk waking them up.

As far as the cameras go, they do seem kind of flimsy. They are definitely not outdoor cameras and I have no idea how long the motors will last.

I would look for something smaller and maybe a little more rugged next time along with something that has a zoom feature.

FYI, one of my cameras does work with the two way audio and one can only be used to listen to the baby's room: it will not amplify sound from my android phone when I select that option. I don't know why and it isn't terribly important at this point.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Confusing set-up and no tech support
review_body:
I was excited to buy this camera as a baby monitor after reading a bunch of positive reviews on both Amazon and other sites. I knew that the tech set-up would be a bit challenging. After several hours perusing the manual I've been able to set up the camera and view on my computer but only if the camera is connected by ethernet cable to the router; I can't figure out how to connect (and validate) the wireless connection between the camera and my router (a Linksys WRT160N). A call to Foscam tech support routed me to a voice mailbox that was already full.

The product manual is poorly written by someone for whom English is not the native language - it is full of typos and confusing syntax. Foscam would do well to improve their manual and tech support.

I'm going to give this some more time but right now it looks like I'll need to return the product - very disappointed.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Bought 4 of these cameras (directly from Foscam.US) and all are having wireless issues. Even sitting 3 ft away from the router with the large 9db antennas, the cameras struggle to connect. If and when they do connect, the wireless performance is very poor. I have tested my network and have strong signal in the areas the cameras are placed.

After allowing remote access to their support staff, the support person was not able to get them to work reliably. He indicated that they are having a lot of issues with the current firmware (11.37.2.48). He even downgraded the firmware to the previous version and still couldn't resolve the issues. I was told to return them for replacement. I will give the replacements a chance but if they have the same issues, they'll go back and I'll look elsewhere. They are pretty good cameras if they are hardwired to the network, but are useless running wireless.

review_body: It is not hard to set up. And the quality of the photo received through email is good. I am glad to monitor my home from office now.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I purchased this camera after a lot of searching around for a good, inexpensive, and highly rated IP Camera, and I have to say that so far I am not disappointed. I’ve seen a lot of reviews on here about setting up the camera and how it can be difficult, but I had no problem setting it up. Foscam’s website has a great Q&A section that I recommend checking out if you have any questions since the question you want an answer to will probably be on there. Highly recommend!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Kate from technical support was excellent.  Within a couple of minutes she was able to have my camera up and running.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Kate, The technical support that I received was excellent and i really like the Foscam camera...I am very happy with both the camera and the service...

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Bought these to supplement some old AV cams. Have to say big improvement. Very clear and handle movement pretty well. Those using these as wireless may run into issues with management (cams function ok but cannot log in to make changes or monitor). Found it was related to the router.

When setting these up use DHCP and wired. Setup with the current settings for your Wifi. It worked with hidden SSID and MAC filter. Wifi MAC should be center sicker with login.
Use a different IP to hard code the IP on the cam reboot the cam. Cam is back up on new IP. (Hard code the lease on the router once successful)
Delete the lease on the router and unplug the ethernet cable. (You may need to power the cam back on and off)
Cam should be using wireless now.
I did clear my leases and reboot my router before starting.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: works great as a baby monitor
review_body: Great camera for use as a baby monitor. I can see perfectly in both light and dark, and the audio was just fine once I found out online I needed to have the wi-fi antenna going straight back. I really wish Foscam made an Android app for it. There are paid apps that will work and interact with it, but some can be buggy because they're made as "universal" apps rather than just for this model. Great piece of hardware though and we've been using it over a year now. I'd recommend doing what we did and buying a really cheap old Android phone for $10-15 somewhere and using it as a dedicated baby monitor with the app (condition and speed of the phone doesn't matter if you just need wi-fi and to run one app). I wish we'd thought of this combo from the start.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I have 8 of these cameras and thought everything was great until I needed customer service from Foscam. BE AWARE that if you purchase directly through Foscam that you run the very real risk of losing your money. I paid for my last camera on 12/07/12 and it is now 12/26/12 and I still have not received it. The package was lost in shipment and now Foscam is ignoring my requests for a replacement.

The cameras work well enough but if you need support you are out of luck. Foscam is a very dishonest seller.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: The camera seems to work great - had some trouble with set-up - mostly because I have no idea what I am doing and the directions assume you do - but after a breif hold - maybe 10 minutes? - Sandra took over and got everything going in no time. Thank you Sandra!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
a great price for a very useful at times when environments require monitoring our interest at all distances.
could be improved with an electrical power supply cable longer and at some point with lithium polymer batteries to give autonomy and ease of use

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I purchased 3 each of Foscam models FI8910W and FI8905W. They been in service for over 2 months indoors and outdoors with no issues installing or performance wise. I got what I expected to get and that's a well rounded and somewhat inexpensive home surveillance system.  The star deduction is for poor swivel mounts and lack of decent software to unify a multi-camera system. I bought better mounts at a total cost of $20. I don't use Foscam's software at all. I went with a 3rd party vendor for an additional cost of $50 and everything is just how I want it.  Networking the cameras was easy and remote viewing works fine.  I also got an Android app to remotely view the live feeds for about $2.  I did use the internal server to configure automatic still image email and uploads to my ftp site in addition to what the 3rd party software does.  I do think that people who don't understand networking especially configuring routers would have some difficulty trying to set up multiple cameras, remote viewing, and things like that.  That's just the nature of how all of these things work however.  If a persons only experience with routers is plugging one in to a cable/DSL modem and setting up DHCP they will probably need some help figuring out how to make things work.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Bought this to compliment existing security system. I'm very happy with it. It's very flexible, locate it anywhere it can receive wifi signal, does not need a PC once it's setup. Would be nice if it could make a 360 degree turn, only makes ~270 degree.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
You can buy these in packs of three or more, like I did. These are great little cameras that will work over wireless - even WPA2 - so there is no stepping down to WEP64 or WEP128 to connect like some other IP cameras I've used in the past.

There are so many ways to use these cameras - traditional web browser, one of the iPhone, iPad, or iPod Touch Foscam apps, or email on motion detection. I'm sure there are Android and Windows 8 Phone apps available as well. These work very well in low light conditions too. I've had these cameras in my home, running non-stop for the last five months, and reliability has never been a problem.

Alternatively, they can be wired via Ethernet.

I wish Foscam made an outdoor weatherproof case for these indoor cameras so I could mount them around the outside of my house as well. I know Foscam makes outdoor cameras, but they're more expensive than the indoor camera.

Excellent for security. The picture / video quality is very clear and the two way audio works too - great way to get someone's attention.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: PITA to install if you're a newbie
review_body:
I bought this on a Black Friday sale and was excited to use this in my son's room and be able to see him from my iPhone. I had two video monitors previously and both had crapped out in a matter of months.

I am not a techie by any means and it took forever to install the camera. The directions were horrible. It wouldn't connect wirelessly, we didn't know the log name/pw for our router, it was a mess. I found a YouTube tutorial with step by step directions from user AwkwardHamster who was a great help! Eventually, we logged into the router for port forwarding and I created an account with no-ip.org (free) for DDNS. For some reason it still was not working and it turns out the antennae om the router were pointing sideways so I adjusted them and voila, connection!

I recently bought second camera for my son's play room in the basement. This time, set up was a SNAP since I knew what the heck I was doing now.

It can be frustrating to install, but once you know what you're doing, it's easy. Now I can watch both areas from my phone, computer, etc and my husband can check in from work, too.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

review_body: Customer Rep Ralph Mendez is amazing.  It took a while to get to a rep (5 tries, 20 minute hold times each and then call back), but when I got through it only took 15 minutes to get my camera set-up.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Have used this a little bit and haven't found any negatives aside from build quality. I don't expect years of great performance out of this but I only want it as a baby monitor anyways. Should serve its purpose very well.

Built in speaker is unusable but the microphone seems to work well.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I read a good number of reviews for this camera and knew well what the major complaints were before I bought it. I would like to address a few....

Installation. Installing the camera took less than 30 minutes for me after unboxing. I really don't understand why people were having so many issues. On the Foscam website they have step-by-step instructions on how to set up the camera. Also, there are many YouTube videos with actual users providing tutorials (look up awkwardhamster's videos).

Paying for no-ip? You don't have to pay for no-ip. The free service works fine. Don't buy into their marketing and just got with the free service. I'm not sure about dysdsn though.

Audio quality. I'll admit that the microphone on this camera is crap. Trying to hear anything not close to the camera is pretty much impossible. However, the speaker on the camera is not as bad as people say. I can hear and understand when people talk through it.

Interfaces. So far I've tried the web interface for Chrome, the android web interface, tinyCam pro for both my phone and nexus, and the blackberry browser. All interfaces allowed me to view the stream And adjust the camera. It works great over 4G and 3G and of course wifi.

Overall, you have to remember that this camera is only $90. For that price, it did most everything I expected it to do, as well as I anticipated. I would definitely consider another one in the future.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: great camera just had to figure out to make it save files to hard drive put as a trusted site

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Impossible to configure for access via internet...been trying to figure it out for months now and still need to research more...not for the technically challenged....documentation is a joke and more confusing than stereo instructions....

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
iSpy is the best app I've found to use these with, works perfect. And, if you are savvy you can write a custom script to send email alerts with attached pic, and get the videos uploaded to google drive for free.

Now for the cameras. They work with \\"tinyCam Monitor\\" Android app and my wife's iOS app, sound and mic, so that's definitely a plus. Overall I do like them. Gotta say I'm very disappointed with their performance though, 5FPS MAX on wifi. I've got an Amped R20000G wifi router and get 22-25mbit throughput with all cams off over the 2.4ghz link, 19-21mbit with 1 cam on, and 15-18mbit with two cams on, when testing through my phone. My point here is that I have plenty of bandwidth left over and it's definitely not my network. The whole time I'm testing the FPS on the cams stays right at 5FPS. They don't do 5ghz wifi either, only 2.4ghz, but at least it's wireless N and WPA2 compatible. Shame too, get 65mbit throughput easily from my phone.

Despite their shortcomings in the performance category, the picture is crisp enough I can recognize peoples facing and such at a good 20-30 feet. And for the price, half off if your smart and choose amazon warehouse deals, is pretty dang good for the compatibility and use. I wanted to give them 4 stars, but for the price, compatibility, and my usage I wouldn't be able to find anything better. So 5 stars it is.

*Update 01/05/2012*
I did a lot of tweaking on my wifi and found that the 40mhz spread setting cuts the framerate by about 60%, which is odd cause it should have the opposite effect. The total bandwidth decreases but I guess the cams just aren't compatible with the signal. I dropped it to 20mhz and on wifi my cam's are getting 11fps each, pretty dang happy with that. Plus, since my wifi router has 5ghz radios as well it doesn't affect any of my PCs, I use the 2.4ghz radios exclusively for the cams.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
The IR cut filter makes a big difference. I have the previous model of this cam and the colors on this newer model are a lot better. The audio has also been improved, I don't hear clicking noises on this model like I did with the previous one. The base is a bit bigger but that was not an issue for me.

This is the 4th Foscam I've bought and this one has the best audio/video quality.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

Today, I spoke with them in the morning, and was promised a 5:30pm call back. 5:30pm came and went -- with no call back. The guy called at 5:50pm -- but I was on hold in their darn queue again -- and have been there for 45 minutes -- with NO answer!

ABYSMAL support!

It is a good product if the installation instructions work for you. They did not for me. If they don't work for you, return the camera -- as you'll go days without getting any support from this unprofessional firm.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Kate spent over 50 minutes troubleshooting issues I had with setup and she was perfect. I would recommend this product to anyone looking for a baby monitor that they can use to view over their smart phone.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Once again you get what you pay for
review_body:
This is my review after playing with it for about 2 days.

First impressions - it's bigger than advertised or expected. The unit is about 5\\" high and the base is 4\\" diameter.

Second impression - it's made of cheap looking plastic. I paid $75 for this camera so don't expect much - just stating the facts. If it's dropped - I have no doubt the case will crack. Easy fix - don't drop it right?

As per previous reviewers comments, I set it up via the browser and not the included software.

The setup was relatively easy - but if you're not tech savvy - it would be difficult. In fairness, the included software might be recommended for those folks.

Though a fair about of knowledge is required to set it up, there are certain things that could be made easier. For example, the setup for emails. Easier setup and help there would make it easier.

Now on to the camera itself...the resolution is 640x480 is not great. There's a lag between what's happening in front of the camera and what's shown on the browser. This is locally. If using a remote software over the net, the lag will be more. It's functional, but don't expect to pan it left/right to follow someone around in real-time - not happening.

The browser interface is ok - but as written before, certain features could be made easier. You can use this interface on your mobile browser and see the camera. It works but not usable because the page resets every time you do a pan/tilt action. So most probably will need to buy an app.

The unit came with the network cable (to connect to router) - very helpful! Also, a wall stand.

I bought this as a test device to see how I could implement a security system with a few units. Unfortunately I'll have to keep looking.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Worked correctly on the first hookup
review_body: Excellent Value and Software installation was trouble free. The wireless feature gives location flexiblity. Use my PC and Iphone ot monitor easily.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
OK - I'll try to keep this brief and hopefully will not cover too much of stuff that others have already covered. Here are my two cents:

Camera and software is for the most part excellent (for the price). It does the job as advertised.

The setup to get the camera working on your local wireless network literally will take less than five minutes (even if you are not computer savvy).

The setup to get the camera working OVER THE INTERNET can have some pitfalls if you get sidetracked - I'm going to give you some tips to avoid getting sidetracked - First - DO NOT try to follow the Youtube instructions, I think from Awkward Hamster - it's likely your router is not the same as his, and it's easy to get messed up trying to follow his instructions. Another thing is this (and it's a big one) - DO NOT use the DynDNS service that everybody talks about - it's either no longer free, or they have become very good at hiding the free part of their service. Something AwkwardHamster does not mention is that Foscam offers FREE DDNS service for three years, and it sets up completely automatically through the camera software - TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THIS.

Here's how to avoid problems and get a quick internet connection setup for your FOSCAM camera - Two Ways: One, there is a setup video on the CD that comes with the camera. Follow this to the letter and it is very easy to set up the camera (although they push the DynDNS service for some reason, which baffles me, because you get three years of Foscam DNS FREE OF CHARGE). Also you have to suppress laughing at the horrible accent of the instructor.

Secondly, if you can follow the written setup instructions that come with the camera ( I actually recommend this method ) - and they aren't too difficult - these actually walk you step by step through the entire setup process for the camera.

And yes, once you do it a couple of times it is all easy as pie and it does work as advertised...

Now, the caveat - I have a fair amount of computer experience and would probably be considered an expert by 90% of the computer public - but I tried setting up my camera system according to the Youtube videos, and ended up: Crashing new Windows 8 computer (had to do a Restore on it); crashing Belkin N dual band router (had to do a Restore to Factory Default); did some goofy stuff to my DSL modem re: the internet connection - and a couple of other weird things...

Either follow the video setup instructions or the written setup instructions that come with the camera and you will be fine. Don't be intimidated and if you get stuck or something goes wrong just keep trying and you will get it to work (I got really messed up and just kept working it until I got it up and running, I never called Foscam help or any of that)...

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Works very well as my dog monitor while I am at work. I set up an account with DYNDNS and I am able to access and control my camera anywhere I have internet access on a computer or on my iPhone.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I wanted a camera to use as a baby monitor for our dogs via phone while we are gone but didn't want to spend $250 or more. This IP camera is really the best. It costs way less, it has way more options (incl. moving the camera from your phone or pc) and the picture quality is just great! The night vision is also great quality! There is nothing bad to say about it.

Set up is not bad at all. It might take you a few more minutes if you never did any hardware setup but the installation video that comes with the installation CD is really helpful. You can also add different users ( incl. passwords) and can set them as admin, operator or visitor. I also used a free web address from no-ip so it's easier to remember than the IP address you get.
My family who is thousands of miles away in Europe can also log in without any issues and even operate the camera and direct it. I just love it! I will buy another one or two later on to build a whole security system.

There are also options to set alarms that will be triggered by motion or sound, you can add input and output audio and many more but didn't try those yet!

Would and will buy it again!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Fun watching the dog and cat fight
review_body:
This was really easy to set up, and we did the whole internet connection thing. That was a little more technical to set up, but worth it. We log in when travelling to check on things, and we often see the dog laying on the couch (bad dog!).

The ability to remotely control it from a iPhone is great.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Now, set up is easy if you have the camera in the same house connected to the same wireless network that your computer is connected.  I didn't have any problems with that.  However, if you want to control or watch your camera view from a distance and a different wireless network, then the set up is extremely difficult.  You have to create an external account with a "private" IP address and then modify the settings of your router.  I dont have access to my router settings, that's why it was  impossible to set up the camera and use it the way it should be used.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
After much research, I decided to purchase the Foscam FI8910W camera to use as a baby monitor. Setup was not as bad as some folks have described, although I will admit I do have experience setting up networks and I didn't have any trouble. Documentation was adequate. As of this writing, I was successful in connecting this camera to my network and was able to view images via my iPhone, Galaxy S3, laptops and desktop computer. I haven't attempted to setup internet access yet as it's not a huge concern for me at the moment. I am using it over my WiFi so I'm not far from my child.

Overall a very good camera and I recommend it to anyone who wants to setup for a baby cam or provide video surveillance. I plan on ordering a few more of these cameras to add additional coverage.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
If you're trying to test the remote access (Internet access) feature of the camera, keep in mind that you can't use the public IP address or a DDNS service to connect to the camera from within the local network. You can only do this from a computer (or phone) that is connected to the Internet through a different network.

This may seem like common sense to someone with experience, but I wasted a lot of time trying to troubleshoot a problem that did not exist.

My local router is the standard AT&T combination DSL modem/router, the 2Wire Gateway 2701HG-B.

By the way, for support, you can go to foscam.us rather than to the Chinese site.
