product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Great Wireless Camera once you get it to work ;-)
review_body:
I like this Wireless Camera once I got it up and working.
The first issue I had was installing the program from the CD. It would not properly install on my Win7 64bit PC and only leave an icon to uninstall. Since I'm very technical I setup the camera without the little app. Getting the Camera up and running in wired mode was no problem but switching from wired to wireless was one annoying. I tried for about an hour and after about 25 tries of plugging in the network cord, rebooting, waiting 10 seconds and then removing the network cord finally the camera connected to the wireless network and showed up on my ip scanner. Last issue I had was the sound on the camera. There was a lot of static sound that made the audio unusable. I went to the Foscam Forum and someone was talking about wrapping the antenna in Aluminum foil. I tried that and it did the trick. Now after about 2 hours of installing and troubleshooting the thing I'm pretty happy with our new baby/security camera. And by the way the Infra Red at night works great.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: good camera for wired use only
review_body: After much research, I bought this camera. I have had trouble with vandalism around my property. I now feel like I have been vandalized by foscam. I have been trying to set up a wireless connection for three days now. The camera works great in the wired configuration. (I have Verizon fios internet with an Actiontec router.) However, I bought it specifically for the wireless capabilities. Set up of the wired portion is simple. The wireless installation is something completely different. For reasons unknown to me, I can't get it to work as a wireless camera. I have searched the web for help. I have tried multiple fixes referenced by individuals who have made theirs work. BUT, none of these have worked for me. I find it objectionable to have to pay foscam $39 to set up their camera. If I can't get help soon, the product will be returned for a refund. When foscam updates to a plug and play format, I may consider using their product again. Till then, my recommendation is DON'T BUY FOSCAM PRODUCTS!!!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
First off, I want to say this is the best IP camera I have own. I also own a D-Link DCS--942L for a year now and from specification wise on both cameras, I personally find that foscam has an upper hand on picture quality, user control, and more setting options.

Built quality wise between the Dlink-dsc 942l and foscam 8910w, I personally prefer the Dlink over the foscam. Dlink use a hard plastic body that feels very durable and solid. Foscam has a plastic matte body that feels very nice, but does not feel sturdy and solid as the Dlink. As for security surveillance camera, I feel that the foscam is very big and can not be hidden easily. This is a con for me because let's said that if there was an intruder in my house or someone who is robbing my house they can unplug the camera and it be all over because of the camera large footprint. Dlink body is about 2/3 smaller than the foscam.

I did not have any trouble getting the foscam 9810w camera to work. Setting up the wifi was also a breeze for me also as long you read the manual that came along with the camera. The hardest part was getting the camera to work over the Internet. It took me no more than five hours to get everything to work including getting it to work on my iPhone and my laptop over the Internet.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Great price; works well; a little complicated
review_body: As an IT enthusiat, I found this camera to be packed with features for the money, along with a great warranty and quality build.  Since I wanted to be able to view the camera remotely, I opted for the dynamic DNS hosting service (dyndns.com).  That was a little complex for me, so novice users may need some help from a techy friend.  Overall, this a a nice product for the price!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Very disappointed with the product; the wireless connection is flaky, you never know if it will work or not, and I've had to constantly check the router to find out if it's connected or not;

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I'm very satisfied with the camera. Just followed the easy to follow instructions to first set up the camera using a wired configuration and then switched it over to wireless and it worked like a charm.  Picture quality is very good, night vision quality is excellent, pan and tilt controls work well, overall I am extremely satisfied with the camera.  I originally bought 1 camera to try first  and was so happy with it that I wound up buying 3 more and all 4 of them are working perfectly.  Setting up the remote viewing capability was a little more involved, especially for me since I had never done port forwarding on a router before and had never even heard of a DYNDNS service,, but after watching several tutorials on YouTube and doing some online research on the subject I proceeded to tackle setting up the remote viewing capability and really didn't have any problems.  Now when I'm away from home I can view my cameras from either my laptop or my Android and it works fantastic.  Gives me great peace of mind when I'm away from home to be able to check on my house and my pets whenever I'm away from home, whether I'm out to dinner with friends or away from home on vacation.  The last thing I did was set up the cameras to send an email to my AOL email when I have the motion detection alarm feature turned on and the email system works great. If the alarm is triggered the cameras will take a series of snapshots and email them to me along with the notification that the motion alarm was set off.  For the price of these cameras I think  you get one heck of a bang for your buck.  I plan on buying a couple more of these and then I'll have every room in my home covered.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: sean did a great job with setting up the \\"port forwarding\\" for my business cameras... i recommend Foscam to anyone looking for a hassle free camera system...

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: The initial set up of the camera was very simple.  I was able to log in at home and see the live stream.  Because I have a IP phone router, THEN I have an Airport Extreme (2 routers), the remote set up was more that I could handle.  But I knew someone who helped with that - it took him about 5 minutes. The camera works great.  I am able to log in and see that my kids are home from school.  The picture quality is excellent - better than I expected.  LOVE IT!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: I have 4 of these in my house
review_body: I'm an IT professional, and these were a little confusing to get working at first. You'll need to create an account at a site like dyndns.org to be able to access these away from home (assuming you don't have static IPs). You create a hostname like amazonuser.homeip.net and tell each camera to point to that and to a specific port number. Each cam can point to the same hostname but must use a different port. Four cams would use, for example, port 80, 81, 82, and 83. I look at the cams with a free android app called tinyCam Monitor. With that, I can see all 4 cam views simultaneously on my cell phone screen. You double-click on a view to see that one full screen, and you can control the cam movement with touch or physical controls on your phone. I've been using 3G, and the video feed/controls sometimes crap out a little bit (black screen or unresponsive controls), but 4G works a lot better from what I've seen. These things have great night vision too. I'd buy more if I had a bigger house.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Awesome camera and easy to set up
review_body: We got this one as baby cam and has been working very well. The IR works great and we can see very sharp and clear images. Also like that there are many aps out there to support this device and most are pretty intuitive. The whole set up process (though can't take any credit) seems to be quite straightforward. We love this buy and will turn this into a surveillance camera when the kids outgrows it or he realize the purpose of the camera, which ever comes first.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
We bought this IP camera as a baby monitor and also to monitor our babysitters. It works beautifully. Download the $5.99 App in the Apple Store and you can view your camera remotely. The name of the App is Foscam Pro made by Logic Consulting LLC.

Works great with macs too. I actually used my mac to set it up. Pop the CD in and look for the Mac OSX folder and follow the instructions. Basically, you drag and drop the IP Camera Tool app into your Applications Folder. The IP Camera Tool will scan your network and look for the camera and will show you the camera's IP address. You then use that IP Address to configure your iPhone/iPad app. Note that when the camera is unplugged it picks up a new IP Address (have not figured out how to give it a static IP address yet). You use that IP address to configure the App and you can monitor your baby and your babysitter whether you are in a different room in the house or out and about running errands around town.

The camera has a built in mic so you can hear the baby remotely through your iPhone/iPad (quality is decent). Much like the Angel Care baby monitor. The camera also has a built-in speaker. So you can speak to your iPhone/iPad and it can relay the sound to the camera (if you want it to). Both features are just nice to haves and are not the greatest strength of this product. This product's greatest strength is the ability to see your baby/babysitter regardless of where you are.

Remote viewing works over AT&T's 3G network.

UPDATE - 8/23/2012

I've added two additional cameras in my system for a total of 3. The Foscam Pro app works beautifully. I can see all 3 cameras at the same time on my iPhone and iPad. And if you have an Apple TV, you can AirPlay (mirror) your iPhone/iPad display on your big screen TV in the living room and see all cameras at once (if you have an iPhone 4S and the 3rd generation iPad). The price, performance and the fact that everything works well within the Apple ecosystem makes this IP Camera a true gem. Definetely a highly recommended product.hing works well within the Apple ecosystem makes this IP Camera a true gem. Definetely a highly recommended product.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Great camera with outstanding technical support!
review_body: I was able to set this up in about 20 minutes to confirm that it was working. I needed a little help from technical support and after a short 5 minute wait they were able to remotely get the camera working wireless. I asked for an app to work with either an Ipad/Iphone or Android device and the tech (Jees) suggested the appropriate app for each product (IPcam Viewer)and i was up and running. The technical support rep was knowledgeable and patient. This is a good option for people on budget. Also the audio from the Chrome and Firefox browser was excellent.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Nice camera, but reviews being gamed
review_body:
This IP camera is one of the cheapest out there, which makes it a great purchase for those with basic needs. It is very functional, with great features for the price. I'm actually already to planning purchase another one to use in another room.
Given that there are a number of IP \\"baby monitor\\" cameras with very similar features (clones?) that are double to triple the price, I think buying this camera was a no brainer for me.

But like most budget items, it comes with a number of trade-offs. The primary trade off that I have experienced is that the software is very basic. This means that it falls on the user to figure out how to set up their network and software to get the camera to work appropriately. As a tech savvy person, the set up wasn't a problem at all for me. For others it might be.
It also falls upon the consumer to purchase apps for their mobile/tablet use. There are a variety of apps compatible with this camera, but I have not (yet) found one that completely satisfies my needs. I've defaulted to using the Camviewer app. The only problem is that it doesn't support notifications (but I haven't really found an app that does do this!)
For those who need more service, go for the more expensive \\"full service\\" products. If you can take care of yourself, then this camera is the best bet.

Unfortunately, there are a number of \\"tech support\\" reviews of the camera here which have throughly gamed the rating for this item.
I thus am unable to rate the camera appropriately due to this gaming of the ranking system. My ranking does not reflect the actual quality of the product. (I would probably honestly rate it at 4-5 stars... its not perfect, but for the price? awesome.)

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Picture quality is horrible!  I finally gave up trying to set it up wirelessly.  Customer service is non existent.  Mine would not pan correctly as well.  If you are not well versed in setting up networks you may have some issues.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: just found this out... after spending 1.5 hours on hold to talk with the tech... unable to record to NAS (unless you have software/pc running 24/7) booo.. my sharx cam does this no prob.. thought for sure this unit would.. thought wrong...

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
(Real review from an end user!) These are shockingly good cameras for the price. I have a lot of cameras around my house and they are by far the best. We aren't paranoid and mostly use them for checking in on the pets & kids. My husband works out of town pretty often and he uses it as a fun way to stay connected to the homefront & peek in on what his family is up to. It makes him feel like he's closer to home. :)

The picture is clear & pretty crisp, colors are true, and they seem to be built really well. Pan/Tilt is almost silent & very smooth. (Note: In the UI the P/T speed is faster when the number is lower.) When it's pointed to a bright window it adjusts the lighting so the picture isn't distorted by it. There is a bit more of a fisheye effect on these cameras than the other cams I have, but the quality and true color more than make up for it. The IR view is as good as any of my other cams and is acceptable.

The UI is easy to use and it took me 15 minutes to have two cameras set up & viewable remotely. I am in IT support and have a pretty robust network in my home, so am used to working with webcams & remote viewing setup. If you're new to this sort of thing, plan on it taking longer and enjoy learning something new! I can't speak for the iPhone app since I use LiveCams Pro for remote viewing. I have so many different brands & types of cameras that I prefer to just use one app. I highly recommend the LiveCams app, it's loaded with features and you can adjust a lot of your camera settings directly from the app.

*** As with every other webcam on the planet, you must know how to find open ports & forward them on your router (or know someone who does) if you want to view your cams remotely. Many cams get bad reviews due to this, and it's not the fault of the cam or manufacturer. You will not be able to view any cam of any brand remotely without taking this step! If your internet provider changes your IP address, you will have to makesome adjustments on your remote viewer to access them again. If you can view your camera locally, then there's nothing wrong with it and something just isn't set up right for remote viewing. Think of it as needing to know the address of a house and having the correct key to unlock the door, you can't get in until you have the right combination! :) ***

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Anzen was the tech support person I got connected with. I am still speechless. This guy was sharp, professional and pleasant. He fix the connection problem, took the time to explain to me what he was doing and made me a customer for life. WOW. In 2012 I just haven't experienced great customer support such as this. In fact, this camera surprised me from the time it arrived. When I order it, I was skeptical and I lower my expectations as to the quality of this camera. When it arrived, it looked well put together - no flimsy materials - solid and great looking. Then, based on my previous experiences buying online, I for sure expected the camera to be hard to connect. I was wrong again. It was easy. i followed the instructions and in about 20 mins I had it connected. i got a stuck in setting remote view and call support services, and Ansen got it to work in no time. Great experience.
Douglas

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: great camera with lousy install software
review_body:
this took several more hours than i had planned to get it going. The \\"IP Camera Link\\" app glitched on install, then did not operate correctly (double clicking the path to the camera opens in Microsoft Word instead of IE ???!!!). Quick start instructions were poorly written and next to worthless. I plowed through multiple online FAQ's to find the answer and workaround for a security problem to the unsigned ActiveX certificate (why do lazy and careless software developers think it is okay to waste hours of my life?)
After finally getting the ActiveX thing to go, then open the ports on my wireless router and my broadband router, the camera finally works well and looks great. Remote operation is intuitive and easy - the IR mode for night vision is surprisingly good. Daytime color and picture quality is also good, and autogain works well.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I was unable to set up the camera initially. Following the instructions didn't work. I called Foscam and was connected almost immediately to tech support where I spoke to Harry Foster. He was most helpful and had to try several ideas before the camera worked. The camera seems excellent and I would have given it 5 stars if I didn't have the initial set up problems.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: simply doesn't work, terrible tech support
review_body: I purchased many of these cameras planning to equip my facility for security, but couldn't get just one to work.  Called tech support 7 times, but only got to talk to a live technical person once with heavy accent who didn't have the knowledge to help me setting up FTP connect and promised to call me back, but didn't.  This has been the worst experience I have gone through with any vendor... hands down.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
For the price a great camera that has what most of the more expensive cameras offer. The mobile phone interface is easier to use than others I have owned in the past.
Lost one star for a busy customer service line. Had to call back several times. Once I got through Calvin Harris was my rep and provided very good support in a quick and easy manner.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Bad customers service, it is like no support at all.
review_body: The product itself might be okay. But the installation process is a headache. You can not get a real tech to help you out if you have problem to install. I have tried very hard on my own and it worked once, but then it failed next day and I can never make it work again no matter how many times I tried, how long I push and hold on to the RESET button, it just can't make it work like it is written in the user installation guide. I have no choice but to return it.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Camera broke in 6 months and Foscam won't repair it
review_body:
I bought this camera to be able to check in on my puppy when I'm out of the house. The camera works great. I did some of the set-up myself using the manual provided, but realized later that I should have just called Customer Service to begin with. Anzen was tremendously helpful. He connected my camera to my wireless network, answered all my annoying questions, and helped me to verify that I could access it remotely. It was one of the easiest and least painful tech support phone calls I've ever had. Anzen was a great help!

Update: Unfortunately, I have to change my review about the product and customer service. The camera lasted only six months! The pin on the power cord connecting to the camera plainly just stopped fitting into the back of the camera. For a while, I tried using tape but was only minimally successful. Now, the camera doesn't work at all. I contacted customer service to ask about a repair or replacement. After about a week of back-and-forths, during which they asked for descriptions and pictures of the damage, they informed me that even though I bought it through Amazon it was through an unauthorized retailer, so they couldn't do anything.

So, I spent almost $100 on a camera that lasted six months. It seems a bit sneaky and not very good business to claim that they can do nothing because I allegedly didn't buy it from an authorized retailer. I am definitely not impressed with the quality of the service -- or the quality of the product. The camera is supposed to have a two-year warranty. Mine broke in six months, and the company won't do anything about it.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Excellent Value

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: It works just as promised.  We can view my grandson's room via internet, iPad and iPhone.  The IR is great for at night.  No problems with setup at all.  Plan on getting another one for my granddaughter's room as well.  Great product, reasonably priced.  Recommend it highly.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Ordered 8/7/12, is 8/11/12 and order has not even shipped yet. They say \\"Brand New, in stock and ready for immediate shipment\\", but this is not guaranteed. Ordered from Electronica Direct. Try a different vendor for quicker T/O. Will update. Thanks, A

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Product broke after 4 days of using it
review_body: This product's night vision only lasted 4 days. I tried everything from resetting the camera to upgrading the firmware. I even followed Foscam's instructions on how to reset the IR sensor if it goes out but to no avail. You can tell that the IR led's are on because you can see them when it is dark but they don't work for distances over a foot. Camera is great overall except for the fact that the night vision went out after a few days of use. Hopefully the replacement will last longer than this.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Tech Savvy: Great Camera .. Not Savvy: Expect Frustration
review_body:
Using my iPad, I monitor and/or record my Foscam video for surveillance wherever there's Wifi available. Setup for remote use required router port forwarding (in my case my router is my Qwest Actiontec modem). I bought a hostname from Dyn for $20 and I bought the FoscamPro iPad app for six bucks or so. I then called Foscam technical assistance (a must). The lady took me step-by-step through the setup procedure. She was a very patient woman who seemed to have knowledge on all the various Foxcams, routers and modems on the market. For remote use, she set me up on the LiveCams Pro app (a useful app for $2 or so). I was up and running by the time we finished that one phone call. Setting up on FoscamPro (different company) was pretty intuitive once this other stuff was known and experienced.

That said, I put a LOT of hours of research and trial-by-error leading up to the process noted above. I've laid out what I did just in case some other equally clueless individual out there would like to bypass a lot of agony and frustration.

By the way .. This is a major edit from my original posting (done in frustration) equating my cluelessness to necessary technical jargon and process.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Had a problem seeing two cameras over wireless . . . Harry Foster at tech support sorted it out perfectly. He made a static ip address that allows remote access much easier. Camera has a great resolution and good sound and works very well with ipad app.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Tech Support does not exhist, install software is POS, Aftermarket software is GREAT
review_body:
I will start this review by saying that I have been a software engineer and programmer for over 20 years, so I know my way around a computer and how to configure hardware. The absolute crap Chinese software did not autodetect the camera on my network. Additionally, it did not allow me to connect to the unit or change any configuration manually. I called tech support ... on 3 different times on 3 different days and left a message 4 times after being assured by the operator that I would get a call back.

Finally after the 5th time I refused the call back and got put on support with someone. After trying to determine the problem the engineer determined that my unit was not recognizing DHCP correctly (although all the other networked computers and devices on my network do)so I asked him if we could connect to the device manually using default IP's (this is the normal fail-safe for most items like this camera). Not only did the software not allow this, but the further attempts required me rebooting the entire computer to get the software to prompt me for IP configuration.

This is a camera I can get in China for about $15. This company branded the item and is reselling it. No attention has been made to improve the OS or the Firmware, as the firmware is the exact same as the Chinese brand that I had in Hong Kong. To add insult, the most recent software was \\"unavailable\\" to download off their website. You get what you pay for.

UPDATE - I gave this camera a second chance and they have improved their game a little. Still no support and their website is horrific, but the new firmware is not bad. However, these things still like to reset themselves and return back to their \\"Home\\" position. YOU MUST get the Blue Iris software for this camera. It is fantastic and can link up with several cameras turning this into a very affordable, security and DVR system.

I will also say that I had focusing issues with only one cam, no matter what it was always soft even when I adjusted the ring. Night vision is not half bad but this is just a standard def video feed.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Good for secondary audio system and primary video.
review_body:
Pros:
- Customer support (namely Calvin Harris) stay on and did everything to get me up and running. Turns out I needed to reset my router.
- Works as advertised. Audio and video (with delay) work great on third party apps.
- Easy to access in your browser and move camera remotely.

Cons:
- The package came busted and the instillation disk was cracked and unusable.
- The Mac software download on the Foscam site is unusable.
- The work around for dynamic IP using DYNDNS is no longer free.
- Couldn't get the Firefox VLC plugin to work for audio on my computer.
- Sound and video delay (about 5 seconds for us) using third party apps on tablets and phones.

For those having issues with the U-verse router. My solution was to reset the router and then I could see the camera wireless IP. We will be using ours as a secondary baby monitor (because of the delay) with third party apps on our tablets and phones. We still plan to have an audio only monitor system as our primary.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I use this camera on a closed network (no ip access outside of the local network)as a baby monitor. I can access the feed from my phone, tablet or computer AND I can record from my mobile device. The video quality is great and sound is clear.

My only two gripes are that when speaking back to the camera, the sound that comes out is quiet and there is a ~3 second delay on the video feed. Other than that, very happy.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I had an issue installing the camera software and setup.I spoke with Harry Foster in reference to the issue and he resolved the issue quickly.In addition, he setup remote access.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Bought twin pack Foscam FI8910W (White) Wireless N IP Cameras for just monitoring around home. Easy to setup and with the high gain antennas wireless connection is great even over the internet...if you are using these cameras for security, they are not the best because even though you an detect motion etc, resolution is not where you can detect faces or much details.

Pros:
does the job what it claims...

Cons:
Audio does not work if you use Apple computers...you have to download plugin which is not explained well anywhere!!
Cameras make clicking noise - somewhat lout and it is very random. Not sure what causes that.
Technical support has \\"Press the RESET BUTTON\\" as their solutions to everything...
If you try to return the product because it is faulty (i.e. making clicking noise) then company still charges you 20% restocking fee....even within the first 14 days!!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I will assure you, that you could not spend your money more wisely on a \\"remote\\" camera; for whatever purpose you have in mind, this camera will suffice, hands down.
I've spent thousands of $$ on remote camera systems for various purposes and paid the bucks to have them installed and configured... I'm embarrassed. I'm not a techie, yet I was able to get up and operating with just a little help from Foscam's tech support (from India.)

Essentially, if there is light enough for the human eye to see, this camera will see it too. If the there is not enough light to see it, then the IR on this camera will make it visible. With a little ingenuity, one can create all the peace of mind necessary for most security needs.

I will not reiterate what others have said about the unique values that this camera provides. Plainly put, it is worth very cent.

UPDATE: 8/25/12: I have two of these cameras now, they are 1200 miles apart and I can view and control them simultaneously on my android phone with IP Cam Viewer Lite from the Android app store. The cameras have been working flawless so far; as well as remotely from my computer and smartphone. I bought my cameras directly from Foscam.us to make sure that I would get free support; however, I now understand they will give free support for Amazon purchases too.

Tech Support is there! You may be on hold for awhile, but you will get it..... and yes, it will probably be from India, but I assure you, that it will probably be much better support than you can get from AT&T now a days. I needed Foscam support twice; and you will probably need them sooner or later if you are not tech savvy, so just be patient.

I am 100% satisfied that I got my monies worth.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I just got my camera up and running so time will tell but so far so good.

Similar to many others, I ran into the problem of connecting the camera wirelessly. After hours of failed attempts, I finally called FOSCAM and got connected with Harry Foster from Technical Support. Within minutes, he remoted into my MAC, connected my camera wirelessly, and set up my iphone so that I could view the camera outside of my home network. I ordered three more cameras and hope to be able to connect all of them with the instructions Harry provided. If they work well, I'll update my review and add in the instructions.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Ricky from foscam was very very helpful in helping me to get up and running, the foscam is a great camera , very quiet with a very clean picture  very very happy with this product

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: does not work well with some netgear routers
review_body: I am an experienced computer person and i still ended up calling foscam support because i could not get my netgear router to recognize this camera even when it was plugged directly into a port.  After the foscam tech worked on it for about 30 min, he told me the camera was broken and to return it.  But this was the 2nd camera i had tried and i couldn't believe that both were broken.  So i had a more techy person than me come over and after 1 1/2 hours and using a 2nd router and jumping through many hoops he finally got it working.  And by the way when we plugged it into a Linksys router it worked right away.  Once the camera is working, it is great, but if you have a netgear router be prepared for some extra work, maybe a lot of extra work.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Got this in the mail today so this is an out of box and setup type of review. I will definitely update on longevity or other issues down the road.

Setup -- The instructions flat out did not get me there. My primary problem is that when you go to the device status page it is only showing the MAC address for the wired ethernet, which it is also calling the \\"Device ID\\" and that is a separate issue. I was doing wireless MAC filtering and so I had entered this into my whitelist and it was not the MAC address of the wireless card, thus it never connected. I had to shut off the filter, connect to the router wirelessly, get the wireless MAC from the router, then add that into my filter list, then turn the filter list back on. The only other setup I did was to get the email up and running. That is pretty straightforward if you've ever done it before. I use gmail and it worked a treat with no problems. I also used upnp (easy mode) for the port mapping, doing it \\"the hard way\\" is probably outside most users experience. That took me maybe 30 minutes of futzing around to get done. Not horrible but I've done better. I also have extensive networking experience, I'm a programmer, and in general a super geek so your mileage may vary.

Features -- Love it. I'm coming from using an old logitech quickcam pro 4000 which is still working but I really needed the new features for the area I'm trying to cover. The picture on full resolution is nice and clear, I could easily make a facial ID from it. The ability of the cam to go through a power outage and recover while my computer remains down is a BIG plus. That removes the middleman and a point of failure. I went ahead and splurged and bought the iPhone app FoscamPro almost immediately. It's the more expensive one of the selection but its without a doubt better. It lets me stand and monitor my house with video and sound and the controls are nice on it. Plus I can make a recording and take pictures straight to my phoneso no one can just steal the camera and other stuff and leave no evidence (the motion detection takes care of this immediately but I might want to just get in there and manually control the camera).

Conclusion -- I had expected some mega battle due to all the bad stuff out there. I'm aware they are padding the positive reviews, either directly or by proxy. If they really are getting all those customers to come in and add good reviews then one thing is certain; they must be providing quality service after purchase. The manual needs to be rewritten, the wireless MAC needs to display on the status page, all the MAC addresses should be labeled as such instead of \\"Device ID\\". Other than that, I have no problem as of day 1 of usage.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Foscam FI8910W:  It's okay, but it has issues.
review_body:
In all fairness, I've only had this camera running for a few hours. My impressions thus far:

- The picture is decent quality, though not excellent.

- I got the IR ON/OFF to work by hacking the app. The javascript written for the UI is not cross-browser compliant.

- The software that installs on PC or Mac could really use a decent UI. What is offered is pretty rough.

- The JPEG files generated by the camera do NOT play well with the PHP GD library. I'm unable to generate thumbnail images on the fly because GD complains that the image is not a valid JPEG.

- There really ought to be an API that would allow you to write your own applications for the camera. There's already an unexposed API to some degree, but an exposed and published on would be cool.

- Like many other reviewers here, I find the casing light. I have this camera outside, although it's under the roof of one of my outbuildings. We'll see how it holds up.

- Alerts should allow for more granular control.

- Wireless works, but the wireless scan didn't pick up the LAN. Further, wireless should support more security protocols.

- The default alert sensitivity of '10' will almost never be suitable. I found '7' to be a more reasonable setting.

- Overall, not a bad camera for the price, but it's certainly not the finest piece of equipment.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Easy to setup and works great at night
review_body:
I live in Baltimore where crime has been a major problem. After being broken in twice, I decided to purchase this relatively inexpensive security camera to monitor my home while I was on a trip. At first, I was worried about the wireless setup, since I do not have any experience in setting up server or network. However, the setup turned out to be surprisingly easy, well, at least within my home network. However, just like a lot of the reviewers, I got stuck on the remote access setup. After a lot of trouble shooting, I realized that it is because I didn't setup the port forward correctly. In my house, I have a Linksys wireless router connected to a wireless cable modem, which was provided by my internet service provider. I placed these two routers in separate rooms, so that I can have strong signals everywhere in my house. The problem is that I used the Linksys router to configure port forwarding, instead of my primary wireless cable modem, so that every time I try to access my IP camera (which is essentially a server) using my DYNDNS address, I was being routed to the wrong location. To solve this problem, I reboot the camera by having it connected to the wireless cable modem, and use the wireless cable modem to setup the port forwarding. Problem solved!! I also heard about you can turn your wireless cable modem on \\"bridge mode\\", which is essentially degrade your wireless cable modem to just a modem without the wireless function, and then set up the port forwarding on your wireless router (e.g. Linksys). Either way would work! The port forward is really not that hard to set up, and the little booklet that comes with the camera did a decent job on illustrating each step. Once I realized where I did wrong, it took me only 10 minutes to complete the remote access setup. To test whether you have the camera correctly setup, simply turn off the wireless function on your 3G or 4G device (e.g. iphone, ipad, ...) and use the cellular data to connect to the camera by entering your dyndns address in a web browser. If you can see the live stream video, then you are all set.

Here are some random notes:

1. AwkwardHamster on YouTube did a nice step-by-step illustration on foscam setup for both within and outside of home network.

2. If you are an iPad user, there are some great foscam apps for download. If you simply use a web browser, you won't be able to use the joystick function to point the camera to a specific location.

3. some old wireless cable modems (e.g. Zhone, model: 6218-I2-200 0CL) do not have port forward function, in this case, you need to call your Internet service provider and request a replacement (should be free of charge, only shipping cost).

4. Some wireless cable modem refer to the port forwarding function as \\"virtual server\\", you should be able to find it under NAT or Gaming.

5. Some reviews complaint that the DYNDNS Host service is not free of charge, which is not true. You need to sign up for their 14-day free trial, and give them your credit card number. After you setup the hostname, just cancel the subscription within the trial period, and you still get to keep one hostname free of charge. Your hostname should connect to the external IP address of your home network, which is the IP you found using the whatismyip webside (do not use any proxy).

6. Don't forget to change the default username (\\"admin\\") and password (no password), otherwise, anybody who knows your dyndns address can access to your camera.

__________________________________________________________________
A summary of step-by-step remote access setup using dynamic IP:

1. Get an account on DYNDNS site and get a free hostname (yes, you need to sign up for the trial and give them your credit card, but you can cancel the subscription within the trial period and still get to keep one hostname). Your service type should be \\"host with IPaddress\\". DynDNS site will automatically detect your external IP. If not, just go to whatismyip site and get your external ip address from them.

2. Log in to your router: in most cases, type 192.168.1.1 or 192.168.0.1 (if you have more than two wireless routers, use the one from your internet service provider). You can find the default username and password from the router manual or you can google it on the internet. The default is often either \\"admin\\" or \\"user\\" for both username and password.

3. Log in to your camera. You can do this by using the IP camera tool in the CD or type in the IP that your router assign to your camera in a web browser. It usually begins with 192.168.1.X

3. On the menu, go to \\"Device Management\\", then \\"Basic Network Setting\\". Make sure you have the \\"Obtain IP from DHCP server\\" and \\"Network Lamp\\" checked. As for the port, I just use the default \\"80\\", but I heard some routers save that port for other stuff, so you might want to change it to 8080 or other numbers. The port number you set up here will determine the specific port that your camera will use and you will need that information when you set up port forwarding.

4. On the camera menu, go to DDNS service settings, fill out your DYNDNS account information and your hostname, then \\"submit\\", and wait for the 30s reboot patiently. Go to your camera menu again, and \\"Device Status\\", if it shows \\"DynDns Succeed\\", then you are good to continue. Note that it might take some time (5 minutes) for your DynDns account to take effect.

5. Go to your wireless router menu again (192.168.1.1), then go to port forwarding (or virtual server). Both the external and internal ports should match to the port number you set up in the previous step (e.g. 80). For the protocol, choose \\"both\\" if you are given an option between TCP or UDP. If not, just choose TCP.

6. To test out the remote access, you must use a computer outside of your home network or use your 3G/4G device with cellular data (remember to shut off the wireless!!) or use your computer with a proxy to mask your external router IP. Open up a web browser and key in your DYNDNS address followed by a colon [ : ] and your port number (e.g. 80).

7. If you are within the home network, you must use the camera IP and correct port (e.g. 192.168.1.4:80) to access your camera.

Hope this helps!!address\\". DynDNS site will automatically detect your external IP. If not, just go to whatismyip site and get your external ip address from them.

2. Log in to your router: in most cases, type 192.168.1.1 or 192.168.0.1 (if you have more than two wireless routers, use the one from your internet service provider). You can find the default username and password from the router manual or you can google it on the internet. The default is often either \\"admin\\" or \\"user\\" for both username and password.

3. Log in to your camera. You can do this by using the IP camera tool in the CD or type in the IP that your router assign to your camera in a web browser. It usually begins with 192.168.1.X

3. On the menu, go to \\"Device Management\\", then \\"Basic Network Setting\\". Make sure you have the \\"Obtain IP from DHCP server\\" and \\"Network Lamp\\" checked. As for the port, I just use the default \\"80\\", but I heard some routers save that port for other stuff, so you might want to change it to 8080 or other numbers. The port number you set up here will determine the specific port that your camera will use and you will need that information when you set up port forwarding.

4. On the camera menu, go to DDNS service settings, fill out your DYNDNS account information and your hostname, then \\"submit\\", and wait for the 30s reboot patiently. Go to your camera menu again, and \\"Device Status\\", if it shows \\"DynDns Succeed\\", then you are good to continue. Note that it might take some time (5 minutes) for your DynDns account to take effect.

5. Go to your wireless router menu again (192.168.1.1), then go to port forwarding (or virtual server). Both the external and internal ports should match to the port number you set up in the previous step (e.g. 80). For the protocol, choose \\"both\\" if you are given an option between TCP or UDP. If not, just choose TCP.

6. To test out the remote access, you must use a computer outside of your home network or use your 3G/4G device with cellular data (remember to shut off the wireless!!) or use your computer with a proxy to mask your external router IP. Open up a web browser and key in your DYNDNS address followed by a colon [ : ] and your port number (e.g. 80).

7. If you are within the home network, you must use the camera IP and correct port (e.g. 192.168.1.4:80) to access your camera.

Hope this helps!!

review_body: I've had this camera for about 8 months now.  It was a great price and does everything that I expected.  Works great on my android phone if you use IP Cam Viewer App.  I had a little trouble setting it up to work remotely, but after calling Foscam, they were able to fix the problem for me with no questions asked.  Don't waste your time trying to do network stuff if you don't have any previous hands on experience with it.  After spending countless hours thinking that I could figure it out myself, I finally had to call Foscam for assistance.  They fixed it, remotely, in a few minutes.  Wished I would have called them sooner and saved tons of time.  I had to call them a second time when I added a Sprint AirRave to my network.  For some reason, this device blocked my camera, again, from being viewed remotely.  I called Foscam again, spoke to an employee named Sean, and he, again, fixed the problem in only a few minutes.  Although the device is had to set up if you don't have networking knowledge, I am very impressed at the support by Foscam.  Good product, Good Support.  I recommend it.

review_headline: Requires Cal Tech Phd to install
review_body: There is nothing more frustrating than purchasing an item, trying to install it and thinking all through out the process you're doing something wrong. After finally throwing in the towel to get the wireless feature set up, I took a look at what other reviewers had to say. Even those who gave the product high marks and several who had IT/Technical backgrounds commented on the fact that install was, I will be kind and say, challenging... It was great to see many reviewers post \\"work arounds\\" that could be performed to remedy user issues - hats of to those individuals!! Based on user comments of the company's tech support team its clear that Foscam is paying the wrong people to support it's product. I think it's also very important to know that it requires you to purchase an annual DYNDNS subscription for $20.00. This charge is automatically renewed for you and if you do not accept those terms you cannot purchase the service. As others have stated, it simply looked to good to be true and it was.

I purchased the Foscam pro app for my iPad and iPhone and it works perfectly. Now I can check my home security from a remote location. This app allows you to take clear pictures and video.

For an inexpensive camera, it works extremely well.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Good camera for the price but FPS is too low for me
review_body:
Amazon doesn't show me as a verified buyer of this product because I bought a two pack kit with the 9dB antennas included. Look for that product and you will see that I did own this product because I posted the same review for it. I just know that more people buy the single camera and I wanted them to find my review. I hope this helps with your decision making!

For the price of these cameras, they work pretty well. I didn't have any issues setting them up but I am an IT professional (bachelor's degree in CIT) and I am very familiar with networking. I thought the included instructions were good enough to allow most people to set these up without assistance but if you have trouble, there are many how-to articles that can be easily found online. The cameras have a very solid construction. I bought two of these in a set with the larger 9dB antennas included. I ended up not using the larger antennas - well because they are far larger than I expected them to be (probably 8-9 inches long). I have a ~1,300 square foot home and didn't have any issues with signal when using the standard antennas that are about 1/3 the size of the larger ones. The two way audio on the cameras was only OK. It seemed to be better for listening than talking through the camera - which was fine for me because one of the cameras was intended use was just for a baby monitor. The audio didn't work so well though when the IR was on. The IR lights must generate a signal interference that is picked up by the mic on the camera because when the IR was on, there was a constant noise when listening through the camera. The image quality over all was excellent in both day and night modes. The only issue I had was the IR is activated automatically by a photo sensor that detects the amount of ambient light present in the room. You can manually (through software)turn this off when it comes on automatically but I was not able to turn it on if the photo sensor detected too much light in the room and hadn't turned it on for you. This bothered me because at the in between level of the photo sensor turning on the IR mode for low light operation versus daylight operation, I was sure that I could have gotten a better image if I could have manually turned it on sooner. The biggest problem for me with these cameras was the FPS. This camera uses MJPEG for video compression. This method of compression is not efficient at all and creates very large file sizes. In order to view the feed remotely, this large file size has to be transmitted. I am not for sure if the large file sizes are truly the cause of the very low FPS I got on both cameras or if it was some other limitation but I am pretty certain that I wasn't getting the expected 15 FPS (VGA - 640x480 resolution) or the 30 FPS (QVGA - 320x240 resolution). I didn't have a way to measure my actual FPS but my video feeds were very jerky and more like time elapsed still images (which is actually what MJPEG is). I would guess that I was getting at best 1/2 the FPS that was advertised. I suspect that the transmittal of the large video size was also affecting the sound quality because so much bandwidth was consumed by the video that little was left for audio. These cameras also only work on up to wireless G networks that have a max 54Mpbs throughput. With all this said, even though I have rated these with 4 stars, I am returning them. I am replacing them with the Foscam FI8608W IP cams. These are the newer model in this lineup. They support H.264 video compression, which can reduce video file size by up to 80% over MJPEG. The FI8608W model also has wireless N support (600Mbps), a memory card slot that supports up to 32GB cards for recording, and it has a faster processor. I expect all of this to provide me with a significant improvement in both video, audio, and recording. The FI8608W models are ~$45 more though but I think that is justifiable with the enhancements. I forgot to mention, something that I wondered about the FI8910W model when I was thinking about ordering them was about the software for remote viewing. It is very functional and you can create three types of log on accounts for people that you want to allow to view/operate the cameras. You can have administrators, operators, and viewers. Admins can do anything. Operators can view the cameras and use the PTZ functions to adjust where the camera points. Viewers can just log in and see what the camera is currently pointing at. The software for the FI8910W does easily integrate with up to 9 cameras. The app IP Cam Viewer ($3.99 on the Apple App Store) from Robert Chou which is mentioned by several other reviewers really does work well for accessing the cameras.

UPDATE:
As I originally stated, I replaced these cameras with the FI8608W camers. I purchased them off from Amazon.com as well - so you can find my review of that camera online as well. Please read about my experience with the 8608 cameras before making your decision. The hardware for the 8608 is improved but the software was broken with the new firmware and web GUI interface. Depending on what you value as important, the 8910 model may be the better option for you.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
First, I am not a tech person. I have average understanding of routers and firewalls and the such, but by reading the advice written here from other Amazon customers, I was able to get my camera up and running on our wireless network, and remotely accessible via my iPhone and computer, within an hour. This camera is not a \\"plug and play\\" and requires a bit of tweaking, but it is relatively straight forward and I found more than plenty of information among the reviews here and on a Google search to help me. If you know how to access your router on your home network, you should be able to set this camera up.

The camera works great. The screen resolution is pretty good. We use this as a video monitor to see what our toddler is doing in his room after we put him down for the night. The infrared on this camera is so good that it pretty much lights up his room, and the resolution is sufficient enough that we can see him breathing in near total darkness (camera is about 10 feet away from the bed in a 15x13 foot room.) The ability to pan and tilt remotely is great. We're so happy with it that we're buying 2 more to use in the living room and as a security camera for the front door.

It's odd that some of the commenters will give this camera a low rating just because they couldn't figure out how to set it up. It's like proclaiming that a particular sports car is terrible just because they couldn't figure out how to use the stick shift.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Inexpensive bundle of technology but lacking intuitive setup
review_body:
First off let me say I really like my FOSCAM camera. I am the owner of a Samsung security DVR system with 8 cameras and I have an HD webcam set up in the house to watch our puppy. Both of these systems have remote admin and viewing set up so I have lived the torture of seting up port fowarding, Wifi and firewall changes, powerline network adaptors and a slew of other technical hurdles the marketing people don't mention when you look at these things. The FOSCAM wasn't the largest learning curve but it did provide a few WTH? moments.

The FOSCAM .US website is pretty good with tutorials and the forums make up for some of the particulars of unique routers that the tutorials leave out. I have AT&T Uverse and it presents its own odd requirements when setting up port forwarding but I was able to find others that had already solved or at least asked the same questions. You will need an open ethernet port to set this baby up, and you might be forced to change the Wifi security settings in order to get it to work wirelessly. An above average understanding of networking will help (a lot) especially if you don't want to open up your wireless network completely. One thing to mention here - the FOSCAM has a MAC address for its wired connection and another one for its wireless connection. This alone caused me about an hour of head scratching before I found that nugget of information in the forums.

The software the unit comes with does an adequate job and includes some advanced features for security such as motion detection, image capture, notification/alerts and FTP upload of stills. If you want to see and manipulate the camera via your smart phone there are dozens of apps for both the iPhone and Android systems, even a couple free ones. I use IPCam Viewer and have all my systems viewable from one app. The camera has a pretty good speaker and microphone for two way communication but Ive found when using cell data the transmissions are garbled. If Im within Wifi coverage you can make out about 75% of what is said - maybe 1 word out of 50 though with 3G cell data.

Helpful hint for motion alerts: you can normally use an email address to text your phone, I have AT&T and an iPhone so I would enter my 10 digit phone number followed by @ txt.att.net and when the system detects movement I will get a text message (not email) telling me so.

The night characteristics of this camera are OUTSTANDING. I'll upload a couple pictures with and without the IR illuminator to demonstrate.

One big negative; the camera appears to freeze every so often. Ive read from many people that it's a wifi issue with the camera itself. It's a temporary thing, lasting maybe 3-5 seconds then the live picture comes back. Ive begun to experiment with placement and changing wifi channels but so far nothing appears to fix it. I might try an Apple Airport Express setup up and attach the FOSCAM to the Express via Cat5 just to see if the radio in the FOSCAM is the culprit. If so the system might go back... I don't want to use a $100 Apple device to fix a $95 wireless camera.

I do recommend this camera. Having purchased several other cams this is the only one that has so many desired features and a support community to help figure out your unique setup. For under a $100 this thing is a good deal and gets the job done, just dont think you are getting a \\"plug and play\\" device when purchasing it.m within Wifi coverage you can make out about 75% of what is said - maybe 1 word out of 50 though with 3G cell data.

Helpful hint for motion alerts: you can normally use an email address to text your phone, I have AT&T and an iPhone so I would enter my 10 digit phone number followed by @ txt.att.net and when the system detects movement I will get a text message (not email) telling me so.

The night characteristics of this camera are OUTSTANDING. I'll upload a couple pictures with and without the IR illuminator to demonstrate.

One big negative; the camera appears to freeze every so often. Ive read from many people that it's a wifi issue with the camera itself. It's a temporary thing, lasting maybe 3-5 seconds then the live picture comes back. Ive begun to experiment with placement and changing wifi channels but so far nothing appears to fix it. I might try an Apple Airport Express setup up and attach the FOSCAM to the Express via Cat5 just to see if the radio in the FOSCAM is the culprit. If so the system might go back... I don't want to use a $100 Apple device to fix a $95 wireless camera.

I do recommend this camera. Having purchased several other cams this is the only one that has so many desired features and a support community to help figure out your unique setup. For under a $100 this thing is a good deal and gets the job done, just dont think you are getting a \\"plug and play\\" device when purchasing it.

review_headline: Works as described, good support, model 8608
review_body: Ralph Mendez helped my setup issue. I followed the manual last night when I got the product, and all worked fine with my android table. I was having hard time with my PC with both Mozilla and IE. I called in. It was quick time setup issue. The default quick time is set for udp , not tcp port 80. If you go to quick time preference and edit the advance section for protocol, it works with their built in software....quicktime>edit>preference>advanced>transport setup>custom>tcp port 80 fixed my issue.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Overall a good camera, particularly for the price
review_body:
I tired several different cameras before this one (dlink d-cam being one) I was a bit hesitant to order but, in the end i'm so glad i did! I started out by just buying this Foscam & one Dlink Camera. I actually thought I was going to like the Dlink much more at first when I set them up given the ease at which the Dlink camera started up & synced. Although the Foscam did require a bit more knowledge on networking (of which I might add.. i have none!) I did manage to figure it out after a successful tech-support call.

If you want to access these cameras ( I actually ended up returning the Dlink and buying a second Foscam) outside of your network, you must learn how to forward an IP address. It really isn't as scary as it sounds for those of you who haven't done it before. Don't shy away from this camera if you don't have a clue how to set up a forwarding of an IP address. There are plenty of sites online to walk you through it, as well as the tech-support for Foscam does a direct link to your computer and can set it up for you remotely.

The reasons I chose this camera over the others are

#1, the remote movement. I don't have to have it pointed in only one small location all the time. I can move it at any time I wish remotely, from anywhere I am.

#2, it had a wider angle lens than the Dlink cameras which allows me to see more at one time

#3, it has a much higher quality image (even when set at a lower resolution) than the other cameras. Even at a lower resolution, the image it's self is clearer, and has MUCH better nighttime vision than some others i've tried.

#4, it works nicely with 3rd party software for recording and uploading, no glitches, just works... \\"it plays nice with others\\"

in conclusion.. i give it a 4 instead of a 5, just do to the complication of getting it set up.. but.. in the process i've learned how to do something that turns out wasn't hard at all!.. just something I hadn't learned how to do for fear that it would actually be hard.. and it wasn't .. just time consuming right at first... now all is wonderful and I couldn't be happier with my choice. I've had them outside (simi-covered) for 6 months now & still working great!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Nice Cam, here is the workaround if you have Vonage
review_body:
Okay, so I got the cam working pretty quickly on the local network but was racking my brains out on how to access it from the outside world. You see Vonage VDV22-VD sits between your cable modem and my netgear router and blocks everything. Here's the kicker, it's IP is 192.168.15.1 and my router's IP range is 192.168.1.2 - 192.168.1.254.1. VDV22-VD only allows you to port forward in the 192.168.15.x range (I tried DMZ to the foscam IP in my router and that didn't work). So here's what I did, I went to vonage admin page at 192.168.15.1 , user & pass are both 'router' , basic settings > local network setup in the vonage router and change the IP to from 192.168.15.1 to 192.168.1.2 (change the range from 3-254). Now turn off everything and re-wire like this:

Cable modem > Regular router > VDV22-VD, PC. Fire everything up and it should work given the range in your router is set from .2-.254

BTW the best app on android to manage foscam remotely is TinyCam IMO, haven't really looked at ios apps just yet.

review_body: I just received this camera and it works great.  It took me 20 minutes to get it setup and connected to the wireless.  There are alot of negative reviews, most are because people do not know how to open up their household router/firewall to gain external access.  These complaints should not be directed toward this product as it is their firewall that is doing what it's supposed to do.  This is like not knowing how to drive and blaming a car manufacturer.  The instructions do include how to configure port forwarding in your firewall, however, there are hundreds of different router/firewall devices out there.  A 10 page "quick install" manual cannot possibly cover every scenario.  If you're looking on gaining access to your camera from the internet, learn how to do it or get some assistance on how to do it.
