product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Works great.  Installation is a bit of work, but do able.
review_body:
This Wireless camera works great and allows us to monitor our Condo at the Beach. Pictures are sharp enough at 640x480 and has full motion Video with sound. The basic Software in the Camera provides good functionality with remote access from any web Browser. The Camera's internal Setup is menu driven and allows you to set the network connections, move the camera, turn on Auto-motion Detection, shoot 5 pictures and then upload them to your email automatically.

I also purchased \\"Foscam Pro\\" for my iPhone for immediate accesswith full functionality. It looks great on my iPad with the larger screen. We use the two-way audio to hear and announce something like: \\"Hello - This is the Security Office. Please identify yourself.\\" We get peace of mind with no monthly fees from a security company.

The installation procedure is a bit complex as noted in other reviews. Fortunately the setup can be mastered by following the online guides. Three of them and each is pretty good. One Lesson for each of the major steps. First, you plug the Camera into your Network to run Setup. Second, you add your wireless IP Address so you can unplug your network cable. Third, you setup the advanced features for email alerts, network settings, port forwarding, which are optional features. Each of the 3 Segments has instructions on their US website. They even did one better by posting separate Network install procedures for 10 of the top Routers making it easy for most computer novices to complete. Plus, their Phone Support guys are great. My call back time was about 30 minutes later. They can easily help with any remote setup problems over the phone on their 1-800 number.

Watch a good video introduction on YouTube from the AckwardHampster.
Just search for: \\"Foscam 8910 Setup\\" or \\"AckwardHampster\\"

Cheers and good luck mate. Some of you may need it... :-)

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Good, but the Foscam FI8608W is better
review_body:
The condensed version:
The Foscom FI8910W is a great value considering its features and price point. If features pan, tilt, day/night, all the features you have read about elsewhere. But there is a new kid on the block. It has smoother playback and much smaller file sizes. It's called the Foscam FI8608W. Identical to the FI8910W, but adds H.264 compression and a SD card slot.

Is it worth it?

Longer version:

First off, a little background. I have needed to replace the office security system for a while. It's an 8 camera analog piece of junk and I've been looking for a good IP solution to pop up. A few weeks ago I came across the FI8910W on amazon which gets awesome reviews. After a few days of research I ordered three cameras to test, the Foscam FI8608W, Foscam FI8910W and eSKY 5900. After testing each one, I am going to pick a favorite, buy 7 more and probably return the other two.

Lets do a quick run down on the cameras.
- Foscam FI8910W $85, very popular, Pan & Tilt, Day/night, WiFi, two way audio ip camera
- Foscam FI8608W $140, newest, same as FI8910W but adds H.264 compression and SD slot
- eSKY 5900 $95 with same hardware specs as FI8608W! But not as popular, not as much info floating around the interwebs either.

I'm using Blue Iris management software so the first thing I needed to do was add the cameras to the system. I used the camera detection software provided with each camera to get the IP addresses, then added them to Blue Iris and started comparing the differences.

I started with the eSKY 5900 first. I wanted this one to work because it had all the features of the FI8608W for $45 less. But I learned quickly that the pan and tilt are not supported in Blue Iris so I had to ditch it early on. It looks to be a good camera, I used the built in webserver and free management software for about 20 minutes, it was perfectly acceptable. The video was just as good as the foscams, pan and tilt worked fine in the web admin. I also liked that the microphone was under the camera lens so it points in the same direction of the camera (the foscam's don't). Although I didn't test the audio to compare if it made a difference or not.

Next I tested the FI8910W side by side with the FI8608W. Fortunately both Foscam are fully supported by Blue Iris. Mainly, I wanted to compare file sizes and video quality because the main benefit of the FI8608W is H.264 compression. What is H.264 you say? Well I'm glad you asked!

It's a compression algorithm, a fancy way of saying squeezing videos to take up less space. If you're a late 90's or early naughty's kid, you may remember when MP3's became popular. MP3 is a compression algorithm too, its just for audio files. Back then, a store bought album on CD-ROM would fit 15 to 17 songs max, but CD-ROM with MP3s can fit hundreds of songs. H.264 is MP3 for video. Smaller video files means more bang for buck out of your hard drive space. It also means less network traffic and smaller files for your server to render.

Back to the comparison. Both cameras are setup in an identical fashion. Same frame rate (10fps), sensitivity, audio etc. I made several clips of my dog, me waving my arms, me walking in front of the cameras etc and compared the output files. And the results were pretty clear, the H.264 makes a substantial difference. The video is a lot smoother, and there is less delay. In fact, I dropped the FI8608W down to 5 frames per second and it looked better than the FI8910W at 10 frames per second. And file sizes, oh yeah, the file sizes are much smaller. With both cameras at 10 fps i would guess an average of 50% file size reduction. Drop the FI8608W down to 5fps, compare it to the FI8910W at 10 fps, (the FI8608W still visually looks better) and you'll get a 70% reduction in file size on average. So if you have enough storage for 2 weeks with FI8910W's, with FI8608W you'll get 6 weeks!

I also compared the web admin software and iPhone compatibilities. The FI8608W pulls ahead here too. Most notably, the FI8608W supports pan and tilt on the iphone where the FI8910W does not. Also, you can set the frame rate for the FI8608W in the web admin but not in the FI8910W. This allows you to control it much better in external management applications like Blue Iris. One thing I didn't like about the FI8608W, was I couldn't disable \\"go to center on boot\\" like the FI8910W allows. So basically if the camera reboots, I have to pan and tilt it back where I want. Not a huge deal but I think it may be fixed in a later firmware rev.

Conclusion:

So out of the three cameras I tested over the last few days the FI8608W is the most expensive at $140, but for my needs it is well worth the extra $55. I wanted the eSKY 5900 to work but it was not fully compatible with my management software, if pan and tilt are supported in the future in Blue Iris I may check it out again. The FI8910W is perfectly acceptable for a baby cam, single cam security system or as part of a multi cam security system in an area with low activity. I need 8 cameras monitoring a busy office with as long an archive as possible, so H.264 has a big impact. Network bandwidth consumption and smooth playback are also important. So for 7 of the 8 cameras I am willing to spend the extra $55 to upgrade to the FI8608W's. However, I am going to keep the FI8910W for a data closet cam that will get very little activity. In this case the H.264 is not worth it.

I'm going to buy one of the FI8608W's directly off Foscam's website so I can get support, but the other 5 will be from amazon because they are $20 cheaper. That way I can get support on the \\"go to center on boot\\" and ask general firmware questions etc. Also, I am going to buy AIR802 PASSPOE-03's power over Ethernet splitters so I don't have to deal with external power supplies. They are only $6 and well worth it if youlack a near by power outlet or don't want someone to be able to unplug your camera.

Anyhow I hope all this rambling helps someone. I enjoy tinkering around with technology and wanted to share what I learned!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Great Feature Set, but NOT SECURE for Remote Viewing
review_body: Great set of features, but don't recommend using this as a security camera. Remote viewing requires a web client to access the camera from over the Internet over HTTP (no SSL / TLS or HTTPS option is available). This means the username and password used to authenticate over the web with the camera are clearly visible and any images sent from the camera can be snooped. Someone able to intercept these would also have access to the camera, able to control it or configure it if admin account. Wifi password is in the clear in admin account so this could be breached. Any images you access remotely over the Internet could be snooped ... could be a privacy issue depending on what you have your camera pointed at (or what some intruder points the camera at). DynDNS ([....]) service is required if you have a dynamic IP, and is not free, but costs $20 per year.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
You can find other cameras for similar or lower price. But what you can't find is the technical support.
I tried before with a Easy Camera and it was a terrible experience. I returned the camera. I spent a whole day without being able to install remote internet access.
I think this is the main problem with almost all IP cameras. BUT foscam offers you free technical support.
I called and they were busy, so I left my number. 30 minutes later Sandra call me and accessed remotely my computer. She managed to fix the problem in less than 10 min.
Remarkable. Note that you need to buy the camera directly from foscam (or some authorized dealers) to get this support.

Pros: good price, fantastic technical support
The technical suport only is worth paying the extra for this camera.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
The GOOD: daytime video is clear. Comes with ftp function for \\"video recording\\", the price.

The Bad: if you set indoor facing out like behind a window its worthless, the infrared or nightvision leds causes a glare which reflects back into the video causing you to lose all visibility outside.

Extremely fussy if you set motion sensor notification and ftp recording simultaneously. i set ftp recording every 3 seconds and motion sensor notification. what happens is if motion sensor is triggered an email is sent every two seconds (my setting) until motion stops i end up losing video segments of 10 seconds or greater.

Likes to reboot, most changes require the cam to reboot and go back on center.

software: this does not come with any live/streaming recording software.

The Ugly.

Power cable is not very long not a lot of flexibility for positioning around windows with blinds as the base of device is bulky.

IE compatibility is limited as IE does not play nice with the foscam activeX add-on ( to be fair this is the case with many cctv appliances).

review_body: Foscam has excellent tech support! Got one for work and one for home and both needed assistance and both were satisfied within 30 minutes of the call!  I plan on buying 4 more. Use it on my ipad/iphone/ipod and are very good.  Had difficulty port forwarding on the first one and for some reason had more difficulty accessing my 2wire and SEAN at Foscam tech support was great! So far they are 2 for 2 in helping me get it up and running! Love it!  Update: June 11,2015 Have 11 foscams for 3 different locations and these are working great for what I need. Other than audio not being fluid in sound (goes out like 1 second every 4 seconds) it's great. Do have to say that they are not made well for being in direct sunlight.  I have one on the inside window looking out into front yard and the surface of the camera is tacky/sticky from the heat I guess but works fine. Plan on getting a couple more.  Update April 7, 2016 Have a total of 12 foscams for 3 different locations and these still are working great!! Audio has been a little better after getting faster internet but still not as fluid but good enough.  I am very pleased with them so.  Wished they had some that had a wider angle though.  Other than that I would highly recommend this camera, especially now that it's cheaper.  I don't plan on getting any newer models but plan on getting another one of these.  "Don't fix what ain't broken."

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Still has plenty of bugs to work out
review_body:
I'm not a network engineer, but I'm close and after spending 7+ hours working on the installation of this camera, I'm returning it. I eventually got most of the feature set to work but the few features that are not working properly are deal killers for me. If you want to use this inside one network (camera and viewing application) it works fine cabled. It turns out there are a few different versions of this camera, all with the same part number (FI8910W), and mine happens to be one of the versions that has known problems with IR-CUT and wireless operations. The user interfaces (both application and via web browser) are \\"good enough\\" but not definitely not where they could be.

If you are buying this camera to function as a baby monitor, it will work fine. Anything more than that though (e.g. remote monitoring through internet using Android phone, motion detection recording and alerts, etc.), and it's clunky at best in my opinion.

If you're wondering, I spent many hours on the Foscam forum and searching internet for solutions to the hurdles I hit during setup. Bottom line, I'm returning this camera. If you're not very comfortable with things like port forwarding, DDNS, setting up static IP addresses, and firmware updates, this camera's setup is not for you. I'm guessing most IP cameras are like this and the whole genre of IP cameras is not there yet for the general user population.

review_headline: Foscam FI9805W wireless camera - Technical Support was good once I got through via telephone
review_body:
I have contacted Foscam for several issues regards FI9805W wireless camera, when I first purchased the camera I couldn't get the wireless to work, after several emails and many failed attempts to contact Foscam I ended having to use the camera via a LAN cable, as Foscam were unable to resolve the problem.

More recently, the camera stopped working all together. I emailed the technical team several times with the issue. I found that respond from the technical team was very slow, Foscam took on average 2 weeks respond back each time I emailed them. Foscam do NOT have a UK technical support, and therefore I had to call the US for any support (rather expensive), when I did call the US I kept getting the message 'you are in the queue', and kept me hanging on for ages. Today (11/07/2012) I got through to the Technical team in the US via telephone and spoke to Ralph Mendez, the technical support agent, who was very good and has now got my camera working via wireless. So in summary, for technical support when I got through to Foscam the service is very good, however via email it is very poor.

In terms of the camera, one of the downfall I see is that the viewing angle is very narrow and secondly, on a sunny day the images come out white, because of the infra red.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

To Management,

Anzen Dcruz was most gracious and helpful. I cannot express my appreciation enough for what he did in helping me configure my newly installed FI8905W camera. Not only did he get it to finally connect to my network but configured Dual Port Forwarding (both router and modem) so I can access the camera from anywhere in the world. That was so cool. He's an asset and a real plus for the company. I can't thank him enough for getting me through what I would call a near breakdown.

Best Regards,

Richard

review_body: I purchased this tepidly to use as a baby monitor.  I had purchased a competing D-Link 942-L, which had a horrid delay as well as no pan/tilt features.  Overall, this product is far superior, easier to install (with a modicum of knowledge of IP) and works well.  The one issue I had was getting the camera to connect from outside this intranet.  Ralph Mendez from cust support was excellent in his diagnostics and repaired this problem by simply changing the port from 8080 to 8090.  I would certainly recommend this for moderately tech savy consumers who want more flexibility at a cheaper price than off-the-shelf baby monitors.  I cannot comment on long-term use, as this is still the second day of ownership.  BTW, I have about a 1-2 second delay with audio, with a relatively low frame rate.  Performance without audio is markedly silky and smooth.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Works like a champ! Great Value~!!!!
review_body:
Got this camera a couple days ago and it's had near flawless performance. I bought it to monitor my vehicle (As I caught some guys about to break in a few weeks ago), but the camera doesn't work too well through a window at night (The Infrared lights cause too much glare and don't reach far enough to be effective). One Idea I came up with is to buy an outdoor \\"IR Illuminator\\" (Many models are sold her on amazon), and to setup the Illuminator to point to my vehicle, and for my camera to have it's IR lights off... this way I imagine I would be able to avoid glare and still have plenty of illumination. I'll edit my review if I decide to go this route to let everyone know my results.

For now my camera monitors a bedroom, and works very well at doing so.

The Setup...

The camera was available right after I plugged in the Ethernet cable, and the software was easy to install and as far as I can tell it simply locates the IP address of the camera - Not really needed for those who are familiar with their Router GUI and are able to identify the IP address of all attached devices.

The first thing I did after I plugged in the Ethernet cable was to login and browse through the features - As I'm sure nearly everyone does the first time they connect. I had some issues with Internet Explorer login mode (As I should have expected :-p ), IE wouldn't let me install the plugin no matter how I adjusted the Internet settings. I should note that I tried the Chrome login mode first, but as I later found out this failed because my pop-up blocker was blocking the login.

Once I worked that issue out I was able to browse the various camera settings and features. Wifi connected instantly without a hitch.

Like other have said, getting the camera on the internet can be a bit tricky. People who are not patient or who are technically incompetent should not buy this camera expecting everything to work right out of the box. It's a little complicated to get the camera online because there are many different ways that internet is transmitted, there are many different ISP methods, many different router types, etc.

I have comcast which conveniently utilizes static IP's (IP's that don't change), so I didn't need to mess with DynDNS settings. The camera's default HTTP port 80 worked for me as well since comcast allows this. Basically all I had to do was to enable uPnP on my camera and router... which automatically sends any external port 80 requests to the internal IP address of my router where the camera is connected to(through port 80... which is the HTTP port anyways), so I don't have to specify my port number when I try to access my camera via internet (ex: 89.231.34.223:8090). To put it simply... you just need to either port forward all external port 80 requests (or whatever port you set your camera to under \\"Basic Network Settings\\" > \\"Http Port\\")to your internal ip address where your camera sits (ex: 192.168.1.7). I should also add that if you do happen to modify your camera's Http port then you can no longer access the camera through LAN, and you would then need to specify the appropriate port number (ex: if you set your camera's port to 8090 then your LAN ip address would need to be something like 192.168.1.7:8090).

One final thing on getting your camera setup for web use... you should also set your camera's IP address to be static (non-changing) by creating a rule under your router's DHCP settings. This will prevent you from not being able to access your camera after it's IP lease has expired.

The good news is that once it's setup right you'll never need to change a thing (unless of course your setup changes).

I love the features of this camera! You really get a great deal!!!
For example, you can provide temporary access to someone by creating a temporary login in the camera's settings. The alarm feature is worth the price of the camera alone!!!You receive an email within seconds of someone entering the view of the camera! You can also specify 4 email addresses to send the motion alarm alerts and snapshots to, and I configured mine to send me a text message every time the alarm goes off! (Most text message accounts can be accessed via email... you can find out your text email address by sending yourself an email through your text messenger). So... I get the motion snapshots sent instantly to my phone and I know right away if I need to respond to the situation.

The infrared turns on automatically so you never have to worry about it. There are also other features which may come in handy... such as FTP uploads, and integration with the MSN messenger.

The camera works quite well with 3rd party programs, various iphone/ipad, and android/tablet ip applications (ip cam viewer is what I've tried).

The camera his highly accurate! It updates times through online time servers. The alarm can by set by the hour, and it starts working the second it's set to be enabled.

The brand and quality are very good, but I wish they would offer some more premium models in the $150 - $250 range. Therefore...

Features I wish FOSCAM would incorporate in another camera (and that I would be willing to pay more for):
-Optical Zoom! at least 10x would be sweeeeet! Plus at least the option of digital zoom in the stock software.
-High resolution (true 720P!)
-Wireless N (current models only offer wireless G)
-The ability to record video to a computer or server... not just snapshots
...and possibly a Pan/Tilt/Zoom/wifi model that is made for outdoor use.

Getting set up on a hardwire network with the instructions provided was do-able, but not for a novice.
Getting set up on wireless was not possible.
Called Foscam support and although lines were busy - they actually called back.
The Tech named Anzen was excellent. he took control of our laptop and walked thru the wireless setup.
And then went thru the remote access set up. He explained and answered questions as he went along.
Not doable by anyone less than an IT professional. don't try it yourself - its no use.
We have yet to use the full capability - but so far so good.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I can't help but think that Foscam is carpet-bombing this less-than-stellar product with great reviews. Here are a few problems I've encountered so far:

1) The setup is a nightmare. The user interface is somewhere between pathetic and laughable - a mishmash of software bits that you have to construct like a jigsaw puzzle. It's long, painful and aggravating.

2) The motion detection only works if you have the iPhone app OPEN. Otherwise, not so much.

3) When motion detection is on (even if the app isn't open) it sucks your phone battery down like a drunk at happy hour.

4) And the kicker is that it ISN'T WIRELESS. So far it only works with a ethernet cable.

All in all this is a substandard product that is the purest form of bad design.

review_body: The camera is nice with great features but the software to connect remotely is very difficult. The support forum and material are too technical. The user has to connect the camera's remote network settings  and configure your router manually. I have some networking experience and I can't imagine for consumers without a lot of experience to configure this.  After spending a few hours configuring the share key, port, IP address and signing up a $29/year DNS (Foscam says it was free), the camera is frozen and is not working properly.  It also compromises my network router.  I am returning this product.  Very disappointing.  Make sure you have someone who is good at network configuration before buying this product or you would have to spend many hours configuring this product.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Ok for resolution but not great. Log file in camera has the wrong date.
review_body:
Somewhat easy to set up. Some of the software you have to get on your own. The software for the camera itself is very small and shady in my opinion. You log in to it with a browser. The infra red has settings change and a relay clicks loud. There are bright LED's on the back. One (network traffic - green) you can shut off. The other is red. There is a red glow with the infra red LEDs as well. Kind of gives it away. Also it has a light sensor and switches back and forth with infra red on and off. It is like setting up a router in a way. Has many features but I haven't got them to work quite yet but want to. FTP, EMAIL, ... How you get it through a firewall is another issue. Has motion detection which is pretty neat. It is frame by frame NOT PIR. I haven't got that to work on the camera itself but with other software I found. There is an alert feature but doesn't seem to work for me. I've checked it and doesn't seem to do what I want. Upload file on motion or something but maybe you have to set it up with FTP or something. The date and time of the log file in the camera doesn't seem to work as well. When checking your location it seems to always jump away from it as well (EAS). I guess you can sync it with some time online web sites for time. Even if the time is set the log file still reports some other date.

Can't get it to work with IE. It could be router, firewall, AV, or other software needed. Have to isolate it or turn all the other stuff off and try to get it to work.

Thought you could use it to see from inside to outside but that doesn't seem to work too well. It is more for indoor use I think. The night vision in pitch black works great. Again the LED's are very noticeable as well as a switching noise if going from day light to night. When it first initializes it takes forever to rotate. It does this rotation sequence every time you reboot/change a setting. Also has a count down to wait for a reboot. Like come on now. The swing motor speed is adjustable. While turning, it is very quiet. Reminds me of those neat telescopes. The exterior is rubber like and flat black almost looking like a stealth something. The shinny LED's, clicking noise, red glow of infra red gives it away as well as the bright LED's on the back. The native resolution is something like 640x.. So you get a small image window. If you ever tried positioning a camera though that can be a tough job to get it just right. Has a few presets as well. Those are handy but only has 8 of them. goto preset 1 or something and boom it jumps there. There is a setup manual and then a user manual on a disk. It would have been nice if printed but doesn't come like that. The setup documentation is a quick lesson to get it going.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Decent Product Crippled By Horrible Software
review_body:
Horrible, horrible software overwhelms what should be an attractive product with good hardware. The software is so bad that it will drive you to drink and have flashbacks of whatever computer you were using in the late 90s.

Pros:
-Pretty good picture
-Relatively easy to get working on your own network
-Hardware offers great range of features including pan & tilt

Cons:
-The software is pretty much impossible to figure out, even if you are generally good with electronics
-The documentation and manual are worse than the software. Not only is there very little direction but it is very poorly written and often out of date.
-For instance, the documentation for setting up the remote access refers to a free, 3rd party DNS provider that no longer offers the services described

Overall: OK for using on your own network but don't get it hoping for remote access unless you plan to devote AT LEAST THREE PLUS HOURS to setting it up. It's probably not worth it.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: What's with all the fake reviews?
review_body:
I can't understand why we have all these fake reviews with 5 stars on how the tech rep (Harry, Sandra, Ricky, ralphie, etc.) are so great. Of all that I went through, none have reviewed any other product, ever.

This is all from some paid service to clean up the vendor's reputation. Can Amazon please clean up all these fake false reviews.

He also got it operating wirelessly so I am able to move my camera around the house.  I am very happy with my Foscam FI8910W camera and extremely grateful to Harry!

review_headline: Great for the money .. better than the earlier --- 18W model

This new Foscam is much better than the earlier model ending with XXXXXX-18W

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Great for the Price, WiFi module doesn't work well
review_body:
The FI8910W delivers a clear picture in both day and night conditions. The addition of the IR Cut Filter over the earlier Foscam models has definitely improved daytime color reproduction. Pan/tilt works well, though I do frequently find myself wishing for a zoom. At this price point, true zoom simply doesn't exist.

The only real downside to the FI8910W and the other Foscam cameras I have used is that the wireless connection is unreliable. If you use the camera's wireless adapter to connect to the camera, it will drop randomly (as much as twice a day) and require a power cycle to reconnect. Using a wireless bridge like the WNCE2001 or just a regular wired connection yields much better reliability. Newer model FI8910Ws that have a new Wireless N module are working their way into the supply chain. I am waiting a bit for these to be more common before ordering additional cameras in hopes that the new module is more reliable as well.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Pretty Good Cam - Wireless bad, direct ethernet good
review_body:
Update: 1/6/15

If you use the wireless you might find you are:
1. rebooting it regularly
2. motion captures are lost during long periods
3. you don't have reliable access remotely.

Since I wrote the review below, I've been using this camera 24/7 as described. Early on it kept falling off the network and I had to re-boot it regularly, so I bought an antenna extender and that helped a lot. It only stopped responding occasionally for a few months. But little by little, almost too gradual to notice, it fell off the network and I made the trek downstairs to re-boot it.

I was getting so frustrated that I considered buying a remote power device that could be controlled wirelessly, but after re-booting, it would work fine for a couple of days and I'd think it was all OK. Today, however, it falls off the net at least every few days and up to several times a day. So I've had to order a different brand.

This problem has been known for years now; you can see the reports on Foscam's forum pages and on Amazon's reviews. When the camera is on the network, it works well and does everything I want. But I've lost hours of motion captures because the camera falls off the network in the middle of the night, or when I'm not home, etc. It's just not reliable enough for security or monitoring something you consider important.

Leaving other network devices like tablets or smartphones near the camera indicate that the WiFi signal is strong, and those devices stay connected. More to the point, if the camera loses the network temporarily, it should re-connect when it can on its own and not require a reboot. Smartphones, tablets, and most modern devices all do that.

Since writing the above, I've bought a TP-LINK Powerline Nano adapter kit and hooked up the camera directly with wireless disabled. What a difference! The camera has not dropped off the network even once in the last month! We had a neighborhood power outage from a storm for a few hours and the camera came up with the power, connected and capturing images. It was as if the power outage hadn't happened.

My conclusion is that unless you have a very strong wireless signal with no interfering neighbors or static, you might consider either running a wire, or adding a powerline network. This camera has been running for about two and a half years now and is still doing great -- as long as it's connected to the network.

---------------------------- End of update

I installed an FI8910W in our basement to keep an eye on our colony of three rescued cats. I'm a software and network engineer so I had no problem getting it working. Also, I carefully read the manual and instructions on the foscam.us site and found them accurate and complete.

I'm using the built-in motion detector to capture images when there's activity and send them to my web site. We get about 1,000-2,000 pictures every day to review, but we run through them quickly in a couple of minutes, which makes the motion look like an old Charlie Chaplin movie. And we can stop and review any time while doing that.

There's plenty of control over the duration and timing of the motion capture process, and the built-in FTP client works quickly in sending the images. Each capture is about 35 kB in size and 640x480 in dimension.

The room is about 25 feet square and the 640x480 picture looks good, but if you blow it up for detail you soon lose resolution and it's hard to make out small features. But for 640x480 it looks quite good. The resolution is a bit better during bright daylight conditions, but the infra-red night vision is still good. It auto-switches when the light fades, and it's a bit dark just before the switch. The infra-red system lights up the far wall at 25 feet with no problem and covers the entire area of view. The night-vision picture is black and white, where the daylight picture contains goodcolor.

The cats' eyes don't react to the infra-red, they can't see it, so their pupils are wide open and they look like little very bright headlights on a clearly visible black-and-white picture. We all know cats do well in the dark, but it's amazing to see just how comfortable they are. The seem to see everything and can run and play just as well in dark as in light.

I've built a web page that displays the video to make it easy for others to view, and I get great comments with it.

There are a lot of good 3rd-party programs that are easier to use and present the streaming video better, both on desktops and in Android and iOS portable systems. But the server in the camera is quite usable if you don't want to get fancy.

You can set up the camera to accept logins at three levels, administrator, operator, and user. The user can only watch, the operator can pan and tilt the camera, and the administrator has full control. This is all built into the camera's firmware.

As for reliability, the camera is on 24/7 and runs without a hitch for long periods. Every week or so, however, it drops off our network for some reason and I need to go down and reboot it by recycling the AC power. I don't think this is a flaw in the camera but in our network or ISP, but I can't find the cause.

Making substantial changes to the configuration is easy, but forces a re-boot of the camera. You can, however, set it up so that after every re-boot the camera will return to a specific position. This makes maintenance very easy.

My router allows dynamic domain name service, and I use a free service so the video can be seen from anywhere. That allows my web page to pick it up easily, and I can look in from anywhere with my phone, ebook reader, and tablets.

I looked at a number of other cameras and carefully read the reviews, specifications, and went to the company web sites. In my opinion, I'd say this Foscam FI8910W is the best and most versatile camera for the money. You'll need a little computer expertise or a good ability to follow directions carefully, or a good friend to get it set up. But after that it's easy to maintain and use.bright headlights on a clearly visible black-and-white picture. We all know cats do well in the dark, but it's amazing to see just how comfortable they are. The seem to see everything and can run and play just as well in dark as in light. I've built a web page that displays the video to make it easy for others to view, and I get great comments with it. There are a lot of good 3rd-party programs that are easier to use and present the streaming video better, both on desktops and in Android and iOS portable systems. But the server in the camera is quite usable if you don't want to get fancy. You can set up the camera to accept logins at three levels, administrator, operator, and user. The user can only watch, the operator can pan and tilt the camera, and the administrator has full control. This is all built into the camera's firmware. As for reliability, the camera is on 24/7 and runs without a hitch for long periods. Every week or so, however, it drops off our network for some reason and I need to go down and reboot it by recycling the AC power. I don't think this is a flaw in the camera but in our network or ISP, but I can't find the cause. Making substantial changes to the configuration is easy, but forces a re-boot of the camera. You can, however, set it up so that after every re-boot the camera will return to a specific position. This makes maintenance very easy. My router allows dynamic domain name service, and I use a free service so the video can be seen from anywhere. That allows my web page to pick it up easily, and I can look in from anywhere with my phone, ebook reader, and tablets. I looked at a number of other cameras and carefully read the reviews, specifications, and went to the company web sites. In my opinion, I'd say this Foscam FI8910W is the best and most versatile camera for the money. You'll need a little computer expertise or a good ability to follow directions carefully, or a good friend to get it set up. But after that it's easy to maintain and use.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: This is my second Foscam camera. I have an F18918W I purchased 1.5 years ago and recently purchased the newer model F18910W. Although the 8918 has done a fine job and the picture is very sharp and clear, it did not render color very well. Most greens showed up as purple due to the IR function. The night viewing on both cameras is fantastic with automatic IR functioning as the light becomes too low. The new 8910 has corrected this problem perfectly! All colors in daylight render perfectly! Greens are green, reds are red and blues are blue. The user interface is very robust and allows many functions, too many to list. It also works wireless as well as it does with a wired connection. I have an Android phone app (There are many to choose from)which allows me to view both cameras from my phone, this feature too works perfectly. I would suggest that sending the image over the internet to be viewed on any computer is slightly complex for one who is not computer/router knowledgable. This is where Mr. Jees from Foscam comes in. If you call product support and speek to him he will walk you through the setup and you will be up and runninng in no time. Of course there are higher quality cameras and systems avaliable, but I muust say for the price of this camera (which is really a system in itself) you can't do any better!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I purchased a Model F18910W IP camera, and I have had such a fun time with it. The basic set up was fairly easy, setting it up through my router. I had to update my router software before I could get the wireless setup to work. I monitor it with an IPhone app, and I found that easy to set up. I would like more detailed documentation sent with the camera.

I was having a problem with it always changing my IP, so I called customer support at Foscam, spoke to Sean, and I had a very successful interaction with him... he answered all of my questions (I had three).

(1) I was not able to set all of the settings through Safari, and he helped me adjust the Internet Explorer settings, so I could go into Administrator Use (only visable on IE)... on the camera and set the storage location for my pictures and videos.
(2) He also had me change a setting so now I no longer have a dynamic IP, and I don't have to constantly reset my iPhone app.
(3) He was also able to guide me through the setting that has the camera return to the preset location after reboot... It would reboot, then not return to the location I had preset for the camera...but it is set now.

My experience with Sean and customer support was very positive. He guided me through the settings that I needed, and I would not hesitate to call again... I am using the camera to see what wildlife are devouring my tomato plants! I have some good pictures of a raccoon...but few tomato plants remain :) Mary

review_body:
The remote installation was professionally done and was quite painless. I would not hesitate to recommend Foscam for security cameras.

However, after writing this review and checking the operation, I could not connect to my camera through the internet. I downgraded to one star. I am now waiting for a reply from Foscam. Stay tuned.....

6/21/2012 Harit called back today and determined that the problem was that there was a wireless access point also in the system that was needing to be set up. At least, that is what I got out of the conversation. He worked for quite a while on the problem and I finally can view remotely. The camera and controlls are quite good and the picture is good. I just don't see how an average person with no IT experience could get one to work through an IP address without paying the $39.99 to have a remote installation done.

review_headline: Easy to set up - but need to reconfigure whenever power lost
review_body:
Update 11/8/2012 Lowering from 5 to 4 stars. The one thing I don't like about it is that you have to reconfigure your router everytime the power goes out. Because the wifi router assigns it a new IP, so you have to
1) Run the \\"IP Camera Tool\\" to see the new IP
2) Change the bookmark on your home computer so it goes there
3) Go to the router and update the firewall settings
the settings on whatever you use to monitor it each time.

Now that I have done it a bunch of times, it only takes 5 minutes, but it is still annoying.
--

Easy to set up - but I have technical background. It might be difficult to set up for people without a technical background. The tilt feature is cool. I was able to connect via a browser, via a free iphone app (that has zooming), and via a free android app (that didn't have zooming - although maybe other free android apps have zooming?)

I haven't done the email alert yet. I will update after I try that.

The IR filter feature seems to work well. I can see clearly in a variety of light and I am suprised at how well it works in low light.

When buying this I was debating between it and the Panasonic, which has the N wifi (this has the G). The N wifi allows faster refreshes and better resolution. But I went with this since people said it was easier to set up. I was able to set up easily, but I could see a non-technical person having a lot of difficulty setting it up.

review_headline: Nightmare to set up but works great now
review_body: After spending hours trying to set my 3 new cameras up, finally had to contact customer support.  Very helpful gentleman named Anzen got them set up, or so we thought.  Later tried to view them from my Iphone and could not connect.  On home computer, could only view one of them.  Tried customer support but no answer, probably closed for weekend.Whoever these people are whose reviews say they are a breeze to hook up clearly have a lot of tech experience and know all the computer lingo in the installation manual which is not explained to the rest of us.  For instance, \\"If port 80 doesn't work, try changing the port\\" but no explanation for the lay person as to how to do it!  After a few more hours of shooting in the dark, finally got it all up and running.  A few more hours on top of that to figure out all the settings, set up video recording, etc., none of which were explained well in the manual.  Satisfied now, but way frustrated earlier.

review_headline: Poor soldering quality, work less than 8 month and dies
review_body: Foscam work ok for 6-8 month then start rebooting. Customer support 'nice' but useless, shipping cost will be $60+. Camera hand soldered using degrading cheap component (capacitors) not like large factory used by D-Link or Apple or Dell. Should not cost more than $50 considering assembly quality and component quality used.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
The FOSCM 8810 is, indeed, impressive. There are two important \\"lessons learned\\" that could be construed as \\"implied tasks.\\"

1. Before ordering the product, make sure that RFC-1483 Bridged Ethernet is NOT being used. If so, contact your local internet provider for either a static IP or a work-around. If you're RFC-1483 bridging to your ISP, then your cam will never be seen from the outside.

2. Know that you won't see your camera from the \\"outside,\\" from within your own LAN. Use a 3G/4G smartphone or friend on another network to view it for testing.

Many thanks to Mr. Smith at FOSCAM Houston Tech Support, for highly professional and detailed advice and assistance with some last minute troubleshooting.
His advice saved me hours of additional work vis a vis my network.

Yes, I will order another 8810.

Jack

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Does What It's Supposed to Do
review_body: I don't know a lot about IP cameras, but this one works well by itself, and plays well with Synology Surveillance Station, and the price is right. Some aspects of manual setup are poorly explained in the Help info, but Foscam's support is good both through their Knowledge Base and in the User Forum. I was very annoyed by the camera's little start-up dance which ended pointing at the ceiling until I figured out I could \\"Preset\\" my preferred shot and have it return to it, after, for instance, a power failure. My only issues with it are: 1) the resolution, but I was aware of what I was buying, and 2) the higher bandwidth requirement that comes with an MPEG-only camera, and I knew that too. There is a newer more expensive model that addresses #2.

review_headline: Perfect for using as a Baby Monitor
review_body:
I tried the D-link before this due to the D-link being Wireless-N compatible and the Foscam being only Wireless-G. Using this as a Baby monitor I was worried about video lag. Turned out the D-link had a severe lag when using the d-link app and seemed very buggy so I got the foscam. Lag is very little ( same as any baby monitor 1-2 sec) and it has pan and tilt which comes in handy. Very happy with this product.

Wish I would of gotten this one when my son was born instead of a Baby Monitor that was overpriced just because it was labeled a baby monitor. Much better picture quality and features for the price.

review_headline: hard to contact technical support, but steve was helpful
review_body: I have had the product for 2 days and appears to be a sound product. Setting up the camera on my internal network was straight forward and simple. However, I am an IT professional and had difficulty setting up the remote access via the internet.  The quick reference guide/instructions were dated and not helpful. The instructions inform you to set-up a free dynamic dns account which is no longer free from dyndns.com. I finally put my pride aside and contacted the technical support.  It was very hard to get someone to answer the phone.  I made numerous calls over a 40 minute period with the phone ringing with no answer.  Finally, I reached a person by the name of Steve.  Once I got a hold of him he was EXTREMELY helpful.  He had my camera online and working within 25 minutes.  Steve was also able to put me in contact with a free dynamic dns service as well.  I would have gave the product and technical support 5 stars if the documentation was more helpful and my call was answered on the first try.  Overall a good product and Steve was of great help!

review_headline: Foscam F18910W - Awesome product AND Awesome Service!!
review_body: I have purchased many items from Amazon over the years, but this is only the 2nd review that I've ever written. I felt the need to review because both the product and the support from Foscom are FIRST RATE! I purchased this item on 6/5/12 from Amazon and received it on 6/11/12. After reading reviews on different camera's, I knew that this one would meet my needs. I set it up by myself so that it worked on my home network. But I had difficulty setting up to be able to use on my android app (IP Cam Viewer) and also from viewing from outside of my network. So I called tech support and I was fortunate to talk to \\"Jees.\\" (I hope I spelled his name correctly.) He sent me an email with a link to click on so that he could remote in to my PC. He finished setting everything up perfectly in about 10 minutes. It's not often that you can find and awesome product with awesome technical support, but that's exactly what I got with this camera. I would HIGHLY RECOMMEND this camera to anyone and I also recommend Foscam support.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Camera has been good but the custer service has been great. Ricky, a customer service rep saved this purchase. I was on the brink of returning it. The DNS service that the mfg suggests is no longer a free service. The cost is about $20/yr. Ricky was able to find a free service (no-ip.com) that allowed me to view my camera at any time regardless of my dynamic ip address at no cost. He also spent a good hour helping me set my camera's up and provided a good basic tutorial of the camera. Thanks Ricky!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
The Good: Ricky in customer support was great in assisting me with the setup of the cameras. Love the clear pic, the matt black color, the night vision feature and the value.
When I had to return one of the cams, a new one was shipped as promised. The 2-year warranty is definitely worth purchasing it directly from the manufacturer.

The not so good: Would be the icing on the cake, if the camera had a zoom function. This should be standard on any security cam. Secondly, certain features (recording function, audio and split screen for multiple cams) only work with IE and not Safari (Mac). I was surprised to find that out only AFTER I had purchased the product. Should be advertised by Foscam to avoid confusion.

Overall: Would purchase this product again. Thank you.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I've been really pleased with this camera. I'm not that knowledgeable when it comes to networking and especially port forwarding so it took me awhile to get this thing up and running the way I intended. (Approx 2 hours) As others have said the directions are lacking.

I have it hooked up now to my WiFi and also have it setup so I can access it via the web from anywhere. I can see a ton of uses for this thing from security, pets, kids, elderly, etc.

Has a good picture, very good color, 2-way audio is cool but I've found that only works when using IE. I like the motion alarm settings and being able to have it send an email containing a series of stills. (Although I did end up with 60 emails the first morning since I managed to get wind chimes in the picture when I set it up the night before!) The IR works really nice indoors but keep in mind that if you have it set up to look out a window at night the IR will just cause a bright reflection in the glass and you won't be able to see anything.

I had the camera setup very quickly on my LAN but had troubles when it came to following the directions for accessing via the web. The directions point you to a DNS service (which I understand) but I couldn't find where I could set up a free account as the directions implied.....so finally after about an hour of searching I came across this:[...] After watching this guys videos on his setup I went with no-ip.org and got everything set up for access via the web real quickly after that.

This is where my one complaint comes from. If Foscam is directing you use a particular DNS service then they really should provide better support on their website and be proactive in letting customers know where to turn or do instructional videos similar to the guy I found on Youtube (Props to him!)

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

Setting up to remote view took an hour on the phone with customer service, Anzen was very patient and extremely helpful. I love being able to Monitor my dogs in their room whenever and wherever I am. BUT the camera resets itself A LOT, now I don't know if it's my wireless setup or not but it's a real pain to keep working when I have to fiddle with the IP string all the time and even sometimes unplug the camera and replug it back in to get it working again but as I said it might be my wireless signal, which I am in the process of oomphing up and hopefully that will solve the resetting issue. The camera image is very clear and I like being able to remotely move the camera angle and even have some sound. All in all I would buy the camera again I just wish the system were more stable and didn't take constant fiddling to keep it working.

review_headline: Great camera, if you are tech savvy
review_body: I bought the camera to monitor my nanny and children at home while I was at work.  I didn't want a camera that needed a lot of wires to hook up and could be placed anywhere in the house.  There is an instruction manual that comes with the camera.  I followed those instructions exactly.  However, the camera did not work remotely.  After a little help from my brother, I found that I had to make sure the port numbers all matched up (in the single port fowarding on my router and Basic network settings on the camera setup) and that the IP address for the camera was correct (I had to look this up on my router settings).  Once I figured those out, the system worked perfectly and I use the IP Cam viewer app on my Android phone to view it.  All I have to do is have an outlet to plug the camera in and I can put it anywhere.  I love this so much that I am purchasing 3 more for my house.  But if you are not tech savvy or do not know how to access or change your router settings, this may not be the device for you.

review_headline: Integrates well with home security on Mac/EvoCam/Indigo
review_body:
I received 2 of these cameras to replace old TrentNet wireless cameras in my home security system. Set up was a breeze.

EvoCam controls and records the cameras and Indigo provides the interface to home security. When motion is detected by wireless sensors, Indigo instructs EvoCam to point all cameras to the affected area.

I've ordered 2 more cameras to complete the coverage.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: We purchased 3 F18910Ws directly from Foscam USA for our home.  The instructions and video (on web site) were pretty clear (and I understand more tech support soon on the web site). However, I needed some help with port forwarding and e-mail alarm settings.  I called Foscam tech support and was assisted by Ralph M., who was both patient and an expert.  Both my issues were resolved in one phone call, including tests of the settings, using remote access to my computer.  We are impressed by the smooth mechanical rotation, the good video quality and the \\"value\\" of the camera for the cost.  I am also impressed by the camera's ability to \\"see\\" in very low light situations.  A great product.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Recommend the camera.  I am using it for a child monitor and so far it works great.  Had trouble setting it up at first but called tech support and spoke with Anzen and he was able to fix it with in a few minutes.  I recomend the camera.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Happy Customer - for the most part
review_body:
I was thrilled to bits when I finally got this working. It wasn't very easy to setup. For me, it wasn't immediately apparent that there were two mac addresses for the one item. One MAC address was for the wired nic and the other was for the wireless nic. The MAC address for the wireless nic was in tiny print and my old eyes had trouble reading it!

I ordered two more of these so that should speak to whether or not I'm satisfied!

In order to make the camera work, I had to replace my old router. I had a friend disagree that
it could be the router until I replaced it and things started working just fine. Apparently old
routers (5+ years old) don't support newer technology very well.

I can view my pups while I am away from home on my Android phone which is awesome.

The provided documentation isn't the greatest. I got a lot of good advice right here
in the reviews section and also on the Foscam website itself.

Pros:
I amazed at the quality of the IR output
Everything works great once you get it setup (for the most part)

Cons:
Not easy for the \\"average\\" person to setup. Fortunately, my degree is in computer science
so I'm not average from a technical stand point.
Worked great until I put the camera on the provided mount and tilted it so I could
see the area better. Now the camera horizontal control occasionally jams.
The delivered 3 levels of security are a bit limited. I'd love to see a
security level that allowed for pan/tilt control without also allowing for
changes to the camera settings.
The sound is not great, but I can live with that. I didn't buy the camera for
its sound quality.

review_body:
I bought this camera for home. I have been a looking for a product like this for a long time.

The product is excellent for the cost of $130. Tech support was excellent too - thanks to Anzen Dcruz.

Tech Issue: If you have a VoIP box (Allvoi, Vonage etc) in between modem and router, the port forwarding won't work. Unless port forwarding works, you won't remote access to the camera from outside your home WAN network.

Solution: Remove the VoIP box and connect model directly to the router. Once remote access is working, connect the VoIP box to the router (i.e. ethernet cable from router to your VoIP instrument for the internet phone to work as well).

Gabe

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I have 4 of these now plus 2 Panasonic BL-C230A's. Each has its strengths.
The advantages of the Foscam are:

1-Great range of motion - 270 degrees L and R.
2-Decent IR night vision out to 25 feet or so. Works in complete darkness.
3-Microphone feature so you can talk (and listen) through its speakers. Panasonic can only listen-no mike.
4-Relatively easy setup.
5-Good prices available.

Disadvantages of the Foscam:

1-No internal memory to store images/video. Panasonic can store 400 or more frames of motion triggered frames to its internal memory for playback any time via cellphone, computer, etc. Only options with the Foscam are emailing the images or uploading them to an FTP site (the Panasonic also allows these 2 options). If you have multiple cameras, uploading these streams can put a serious hit on your broadband performance.

2-No provided free DNS service for dynamic IP users. You have to purchase a yearly subscription to dyndns.com in order to keep your dynamic IP address changes up to date automatically - a must if you are accessing the camera remotely and do not want to keep a computer running at the camera site. Panasonic provides its own free DNS service with its cameras. Either DNS service works fine, but Panasonic's is free and comes with the camera.

3-Although the settings options available on the Foscam are adequate, the options you can set on Panasonic are much more extensive (especailly with respect to alarm trigger settings). Of course, this can make the Panasonic a little more daunting to set up for novice users.

Conclusions: I like both cameras, but for security where night vision and range of motion are important, for my applications, the Foscam wins.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Do not buy this Foscam camera if you are interested in the two way audio. There are other vendors with less expensive products if you don't need the two way audio and the two way audio on the Foscam is horrible (actually doesn't work). The microphone on the Foscam works, but there is a lot of static when you use the camera wirelessly. The speaker in the camera is totally unworkable for me so far and I work with computer technology for a living. To make matters worse, their technical support is horrendous. I work in technical support myself, so I sent them a very detailed email outlining the audio problems I was encountering and everything I had tried to remedy the problem. I got back a three line email suggesting obvious things that had they read my email they would've known weren't applicable or I had already tried them. Moreover in their reply, they told me that there was no problem with my camera and it must be something else. How the lazy support technician could unilaterally decide that my camera wasn't possibly broken, was an amazing display of ignorance on their part. Although it is possible that the unit I got is defective, I now am more convinced that it is a flawed product design. I determined that by digging on the internet and found out that these audio problems have been discussed many times, including in Foscam's own technical forum's yet the Foscam technical support people claimed ignorance that the problems even exist. I've since seen posts going back over more than a year talking about these problems in various Foscam models. So I have the camera up and running and as far as a the video goes it works fine, but I've had to accept the fact that there will be no two way audio. Being in the computer industry myself, I know technology like this can have its quirks and require some work to run smoothly. So the fact that the audio didn't work out of the box as advertised didn't bother me nearly as much as the crappy support from the company did. Moreover,from what I read on Foscam's own technical forum, it appears as though there is no solution for this problem. So now I must buy another camera for the two way audio application I needed and it WON'T be a Foscam.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Could never get to camera over internet
review_body:
Viewing and controlling the camera remotely over the internet is very much dependent on your ISP, your modem and WIFI router. I'm not computer illiterate, have a EE masters and after many hours of dealing with my ISP and my WIFI router tech support I failed. Port forwarding is required for this camera to work over the internet. Most ISP's dymanically assign IP addresses which then requires the services of a website to \\"track\\" your IP address. Getting the house of cards through my router and modem (which also has a router embedded)resulted in a less than reliable connection to the camera from the internet. Within my home network the camera worked fine. Foscam's tech support was absolutely no, zero, help. Many many hours and much frustration later, I punted.
This product has the potential to be great......if Foscam set up a free server like DropCam. They don't.
Bottomline: unless your ISP situation is truly uncomplicated this camera is not for you.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I have 4 of these cameras now. They have a perfect video angle for an average size room. Its really cool to click an icon on my smart phone and see my entire house in live view. That is worth $400 to me.(Foscam has an app for these) I have caught and sent to prison two boys robbing my house while I was at work. They were thought to be responsible for over 30 break-ins before they had the misfortune to try and ripp me off. You have zero argument with the judge when video playback shows you in the act. The infrared is perfect for night time viewing. I simply could not imagine not having these cameras.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I ordered this camera since I really wanted to see what the cat is up to while my fiancee and I are at work.

As expected, it seems like he just sleeps.

$110 on Amazon got me wifi, pan/tilt and IR night vision.

The unit shipped with an install disc(tossed) AC Adaptor, ethernet cord, power cord and mounting bracket. The unit has ethernet, wifi, power and audio in/out jacks(3.5mm.)

Install was quick and easy. Plug the ethernet into my router and once I found the IP I was on the admin page. No disc required. Connecting to my wifi was a little funny, at first it didn't find my network. I think it may have been something to do with all the wireless access points near me. It eventually did after refreshing one more time and I was connected without wires.

The web interface is pretty simplistic. Admin options, set a password, FTP upload etc. It serves its purpose and is fine.

The picture quality is great. Its way better than my 8 year old Logitech webcam. Surprisingly the inferred works great too. It turns on automatically. The pan and tilt moves somewhat jerkingly but functions just fine. To make up for that it's super quiet. I can't even hear it when it moves. The image quality...pretty darn good!

The audio doesn't work on my mac. They say install the VLC plug-in. Wrong, search some more, people are reporting the VLC plug-in does not work. I found this to be the case. I can get the audio to stream over VLC itself, but not two-way as advertised. I guess I'll try the two way audio from work on my PC.

The cam works great with pretty well with webcamXP. Put in the IP and your credentials and the devices is added to your camera pool. The only issue I have found is you cannot inverse the pan/tilt controls which would come in handy as my camera is mounted upside down.

Now of course to get this viewable from the web you will need to setup the correct port mappings to your device.

Overall I'm happy with this device. I kind of wish it had a zoom but for the price It's supoer neat! I hope the Mr. Derp doesn't mind me checking up on him!/>
Overall I'm happy with this device. I kind of wish it had a zoom but for the price It's supoer neat! I hope the Mr. Derp doesn't mind me checking up on him!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: It's a bit to get through the set up, but once you do, it's great. It's a lot of fun.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Although the included documentation is minimal, the Foscam webpage contains everything you'll need to get the camera up and running in no time.  I had an issue with the function of the IR-cut filter, but my call was answered quickly (<2 min), and the tech's suggestion my problem.  (Be sure to purchase this product through the company's official Amazon store to receive phone/email support!)  I've gotten two emails from the company since, following up to make sure I was happy.  And I am... image quality is quite good, WiFi connectivity is solid, and the IR performance is great.  I had no trouble connecting to my wireless router, establishing user accounts and a DDNS address.  One minor issue is the limited embedded support for DDNS providers -- you'll have to make do with the three currently in the firmware.  Even downloaded a free Android app (IP Cam Viewer Lite)which allows me to view/control the camera from my smartphone.  Given all the stories I've read regarding customers having difficulties setting up IP cameras, I would highly recommend this product.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Night Vision is the best feature
review_body:
I have several IP Cameras, mostly from Panasonic (a couple of different models). I wanted to have night vision capability so I tried the Foscam F18910W. It's OK. Only a couple of features are better than the Panasonic's. First is that the Foscam has night vision which uses infra red LEDs for a light source and it' can be turned off. Second is that the PTZ has a greater range. It didn't take me long to get the cam setup but I have a lot of experience doing that sort of thing. Some of the instructions were a bit cryptic in the manual as were some of the setting labels from the camera itself.

With brand \\"P\\" you can determine how many images are FTP'd before and after a trigger (motion) event so that you can see what triggered it. You don't have that capability with these. With brand \\"P\\" you can FTP images on a timer schedule (say every 10 minutes). You can't with these. Your limited to the port numbers you can use, do not go above port number 32767 if you want to view more than one camera in an IE browser page using the multi-device settings.

There are more differences which brand \\"P\\" is better and has more flexibility.

All-in-all the Foscam is not a bad camera and depending on how your going to be using it it may be fine for you. For what I wanted (night vision) it does well but these are not my primary cams, for that I'll stick with brand \\"P\\".

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Camera Is Not Secure and Foscam Support Non Existent
review_body:
I bought three of these cameras less than a month ago and the only good thing is 360 degrees pan/tilt.

Cons

1. Wireless Range is poor and it uses Wireless G. Well now they are shipping this exact same model with Wireless N, and if you bought this previously with Wireless G like I did, which was less than a month ago, this is their response from their e-mail team.

\\"
The manufacturer continues to improve product features with new technologies several times a year. Originally the FI8910W was launched with 802.11b/g and six months later new design and production has released the FI8910W with 802.11b/g/n. The manufacturer will not upgrade the camera to the latest model. But we can speak to the manufacturer if they'll except trade-ins of used models to offer a better price on new models.
\\"

This makes no sense, it's the exact same model and price, yet some people get Wireless G and some Wireless N ridiculous.

2. Their 2 year replacement policy is just a marketing scheme.

3. Now to the Security part, do you know the password and username you transmit to login to the see camera are broadcast in plain text!!! Anyone with some know how can get access to it and jeopardize your \\"Security\\" camera.

My advice, avoid this company and camera, look out for the D-link DCS-932L for sale, that's a good camera, only con about it has no 360 tilt.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Not terribly impressive but works reasonably well
review_body: I have tried several IP cameras including the previous, similar model from Foscam.  These work reasonably well with decent image quality given that its only 640x480.  The web interface is pretty typical and resembles that of all other IP cameras I've used.  PTZ controls are ok, but really wish you could adjust the movement speed on the view page itself without having to go into separate configuration pages.  It can be difficult to make fine position adjustments (such as for setting the position memories) except in lower speeds but can be annoying waiting for a lower speed to pan a great distance.  The camera resets itself occasionally but seems to always come back up within a few seconds and has been fairly reliable for 24x7 usage.  This Foscam FI8910W is extremely similar to the Foscam FI8918W.  Other than the slightly nicer external housing with matte finish I don't see any real difference between the two except that this one is quite a bit more expensive.  Wish I had bought two of the others instead.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Bottom line: this is my first camera purchase so I have no experience with any other products but I am completely satisfied and can sleep well after recommending that anyone whose needs are comperable to mine will be happy with this cameras price, quality, operation, warranty and support. I purchased this, my first camera, to keep an eye on my pets while away from home. I had one minor issue getting the activeX control installed on my computer (with windows XP and IE8) but a call to tech support quickly resolved the issue, The camera has met or exceeded all my expectations and works great for my specific needs. The free DynDns account (I have a dynamic IP address) allows access from any computer and using the Foscam app on my HTC EVO (Andriod) phone works great. There is a slight delay panning the camera remotely from computer or phone but that is a function of my slow (3meg) internet connection at home and not the camera's fault. Foscam gives a warranty and tech support but their website says thats only if you purchase directly from them or an approved dealer/shipper which I did. I had it shipped from Foscam through Amazon.
