product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I purchased this IP security camera to use while away on vacation so I could \\"check in\\" on my house to give me peace of mind. I purchased the camera directly from Foscam because I wanted the full support and not the problems with support that I had read about here on Amazon. I have a Motorola NVG510 cable modem and thought there might be a problem with setup. I let Foscam support wirelessly control my PC (they did not charge me, and I stated that I did not want to pay $40.00 for their help) to set up the camera and watched what settings were changed. I had tried to set up the camera myself and I did it all correctly except for changing one setting which was enabling TCP for the camera, not both if you aren't sure. The way to set this up using the NVG510 is to create a NAT gaming profile labeled \\"Foscam\\" and use port 8090 then host that port which leaves it open. You need to be outside of your own network in order to see it at the address which is your fixed IP address and the port number that you have opened for the camera. You don't need a DynDNS if you have the NVG510 and AT&T U-Verse, it is a static connection that doesn't change - it is always the same IP address - just write down the number for future reference. There isn't any support for the Motorola cable modem from AT&T and people make a much bigger deal out of setting this up because there isn't accurate information available. You don't need a separate LAN or ethernet or any more network equipment.

Now, for the review of the camera itself: it doesn't seem to work properly at all other than being a remote viewing device. It takes pictures when there isn't any motion, and most of the time when there is motion it doesn't take pictures at all. When I turn my light on in the living room, the camera comes to life and starts clicking and taking pictures. In reviewing the snapshots e-mailed to me, a lot of them are empty of any persons (me) walking by it. The sensitivity setting is on 10 which is the setting the Foscam rep set it at. I left it on that setting because I don't have any animals or children that might trigger it. When I was away and accessed the camera over the internet, I could not get it to pan around unless I used the horizontal or vertical patrol function. So I am almost wishing at this point that I had not purchased this camera. I might change this review after I work with it a bit longer, but it seemed to be working at first now it works when it feels like it. I will try rebooting it frequently to see if that makes a difference.

The picture quality is very good and clear, the color is what you would expect from a camera of this price - I am not making a movie so the colors don't need to be perfect - they are very close and the light blue walls and pictures are the right colors. I was able to look around my living room and see that my stereo and TV were still there which made me feel less anxious while I was away from home for a week.

However, I am not happy at all with the fact that the camera is not reliable at all for the motion detection function which is a major reason I purchased it.

Video is very clear, the Pan and tilt functions work great and are silent on the camera.  Audio is 'ok' at best but enough for what i need the unit for.  My only real complain is the Foscam Support... it is non existent.  I had one issue during setup so I called support, waited 10 - 15  minutes on hold and then was prompted to leave a voice message and they'd get back to me.  I left a message and sent an email to support.  3 days later.. haven't heard from either avenue.  A quick run through of the forums on the Foscam site leads me to believe this is very common.  Anyway I was able to resolve the issue with the help of a friend and everything is going along swimmingly.  I will be adding more camera's sooner than later.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: This camera is great. It came within a week as promised. I wasn't there to receive the package, the delivery guy called me and said he would come back the next day and he did. He came at 7:30 am to make sure I got it before work. I'm in IT but I was torn between the reviews on here. Some people saying it was extremely easy to setup and some people claiming to  be IT experts that took 4 days to set it up. I gathered all of my resources together (paper manual, foscam website instructions, the pdf instructions from Foscam, and the Amazon reviews) and proceeded with caution. It took me about an hour to setup but if I did one now it would take 5 mins. If you have ever messed around with a router configuration and you know how to follow written instructions, then you'll be able to setup this camera. I did NOT have to subscribe to any ddns website or any of that crap. If you follow the instructions under support on Foscam's site, step by step, you will be good. Also, download the PDF instructions from Foscam, the paper manual started off good but then progressed into broken English. The website instructions seemed to be written better and had screen shots. The first 2 parts of setup were extremely easy. Plug the camera into the router and power (cables included), Install the software and open it up. The camera's IP is listed there. At first it didn't work but Windows prompted me to install an Active X control, once I did I got video. The \\"hard\\" part of setting it up to access from the outside world, just took some sniffing around. Their site has instructions for all the big name routers but I have a no name Zytel that they didnt have instructions for. I followed the instructions, they said \\"Go through the options on your router until you find an option that says \\"Virtual Server\\", \\"Port Forwarding\\", or \\"Port Mapping\\" mine happened to be under \\"NAT\\" on my router. I used the screenshot as a reference and went through every setting on my router until I found something that looked like the screenshot. You set the camera to use a port other than 80 (they suggest 8090), and then in the router, you enter the camera's ip address and port that you're using (ingoing and outgoing the same). At first this wasn't working for me, but then I noticed that my router was UPnP ready but the camera UPnP setting was unchecked, so I checked it and it worked! So once this is setup, you go to whatsmyip.com and find out the IP of your modem. Once you have your WAN ip you can type it with the port from anywhere in the world to connect to your camera (eg 63.63.10.1:8090. The camera also has a setting that will email you the IP if it changes! I have a Droid so I went right into the app store and surprisingly there are a bunch of free apps that you can use, and they work! The infared night vision works really well, I've been seeing white orbs dancing around my apt in the dark (not crazy, I took video of it) not sure what that is all about. I just started messing with the audio, it's not the best in the world but it works and it's $100 camera. I'm still messing with the settings and I can keep going all night but I highly suggest this camera. It has more functions than cameras that cost 3 times as much (from what I read). And don't listen to all that BS about not buying it from Amazon, if you look on Foscam's website, Amazon is listed under trusted sellers. It cost the same on the website as it does Amazon anyway.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I ordered this camera because my friend showed me what his camera could do. He has the older FI18918W model and i wanted to add security cameras to my house. I ended up getting this model since it is the newest model with a new IR-cut filter. Setting up the camera for wired and wireless was pretty easy but getting access from outside of your network was a little confusing. DYNDNS and port forwarding were foreign to me and i had to google a lot of stuff to set that part up. You need to sign up for DYNDNS.ORG (14 day free trial) then cancel before the 14 days and you get to keep and use 1 domain name for free. Functions of this camera is good for the price. I would even pay a little more if they would increase the camera resolution. Night vision and motion sensor with email notification is awesome. Email notifications also include 5-6 snapshots of when motion was detected. My friend with the older model saw my camera video and said that the colors are better than the older model so he ordered 2 new cameras. I liked mine so much that i ordered another camera also. Great bang for the buck!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: This camera has a defect that Foscam.us will not fix. Their support is awful. Find another camera
review_body:
This device is distributed by Foscam Digital Technologies LLC (...). They are a \\"company\\" in the sense that they have a website and they sell these cameras. Aside from that, I don't think they are a real company as they provide laughably horrible support and in regards to this camera, it has a design defect that Foscam knows about but will not fix nor will they correct the misinformation in their marketing materials.

This device is marketed has having both 2-way audio and wireless, but these 2 functions do not work together. You can not use 2-way audio when the device is setup to work wirelessly.

Note that some users have said that they can get the audio to be \\"not horrible\\" by removing the antenna (Foscam will tell you to do this as well), but this doesn't fix the issue and it severely limits the range of the wireless functionality. This is not a fix.

Foscam.us doesn't answer their phone. They don't return messages. And they will stop returning emails once they know you have this issue.

Also be aware that the internals of this device can be found in many other cameras. You will be better served buying a non-Foscam device.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I have a few wireless IP cameras, and so far this Foscam FI8910W is working really well. I have it placed by the window looking out the front of the house. Since I have it on the inside, I've turned off its IR so at night there's no reflection of the IR. I have a patio light on so it works just fine with that at night.

These cameras are relatively easy to set up if you're network savvy. The setup process goes something like this:

1. plug the camera into your wired network and power on
2. log into your router to see what IP address it picked up
3. type in that IP in your browser
4. type \\"admin\\" for username and leave the password field blank to log in
5. make your necessary configuration changes (add password, configure wireless, etc.) and save
6. once configured, unplug wired connection, power-cycle the camera, make sure it's accessible wirelessly, then place camera in desired location

The configuration process is about 5 minutes for me. I spend more time trying to figure out where I want to place the camera for maximum coverage. If I need another camera, I wouldn't hesitate buying this same camera again.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I bought 4 of these cameras to function as part of security system and baby monitoring on our house.  They have excellent reviews, aren't extremely hard to setup up given the plethora of web information, and for the most part function as claimed.  3 major problems, which would lead me to NEVER buy another Foscam camera: 1) the audio on all 4 are terrible - there is absolutley no way you could solely use these cameras as a baby monitor  2) the wifi reception is so poor it is impossible to rely on.  One minute they are working very well, the next you can't connect to them.  This issue is only resolved when you unplug the camera to reset (which is useless if you aren't home or don't want to sneak into your child's room).  I've tried the larger antena, eventually replaced my router and even added 3 access points with no real change.  The only solution the company gave me was to use them wired.  These leads to the biggest problem 3) The support has been TERRIBLE, even though I paid extra to get them from the true Foscam DLL company.  Technical support is in India and their only explanation for problems was to blame my router.  One camera was clearly defective with a dead pixel line and it was apparently still the router's fault.  Numerous phone calls after many failed \\"we will call you back in 2 hours\\" resulted in them finally issuing an RMA# (note there is no RMA process detailed on the foscam website), and I still had to call almost daily to see when they were going to ship the replacement camera to me.  2 months later and finally the replacement has appeared, but they are still holding out on reimbursing the defective camera's shipping cost as they had promissed.  You can tell a company has no interest in support when they give you random names as reference for the calls - I'm referring to you Robert/Jake/Charles - the exact same support person in India (yes I've had to call them that many times!)

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Camera has a great picture for the money, I am having a little trouble making it work wirelessly, but have not tried customer support yet.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Excellent product....One thing I noticed though is....
review_body:
This is an excellent product in my opinion, especially for the price. There is just one thing that I've experienced in the last few days that is just a \\"little\\" frustrating. It probably will boil down to a setting or something that I've missed, or maybe it could be something to do with needing a small adjustment in the firmware, who knows. Anyway, every once in a while I'll go into my computer room to check on things in the monitored area, move my mouse to wake up the monitor and check out the camera, and the camera will have reset (or something) and the angle of the lense is totally off and \\"not\\" viewing/monitoring the area that I had it set to monitor in the first place. I'm still searching for a reason that I possibly could have control over and in a while will be contacting Foscam to see what they have to say about it. All in all though, a good camera.

Perhaps someone could discuss with me here somewhere what this minor problem could be and how to get the camera working properly ALL OF THE TIME? Anyone have any ideas as to what the problem may be?

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I use this camera everyday to see my baby. I live in Brazil and travel a lot. I have the program in my Samsung Galaxy SII and watch my baby from everywhere, clearly with a good image even totally dark

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I have used Foscam cameras for some time, though this is my first purchase of this specific model. So far, it has worked flawlessly, but one disappointment is that I cannot slow down the frame rate from full speed, like the older models. Having said that, the performance of the camera is good and the price/value is excellent. I would buy more of these in the future, if/when needed.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I finally thought I found a simple solution to keeping on I on things while was away, or so I thought! The software didn't work, I tried on multible computers. I downloaded the program and installed it and it worked for a couple of hours then stopped. After multiple resets and many hours I gave up and sent it back. I'll never gets those hours back!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I have a Logitech Alert camera system and like it, but the Logitech's website is often down or slow, so trying to view my cam on my iPhone is sometimes problematic. So, after some research I picked up a Foscam F18910W. Love it! Streaming over the internet is way faster than the Logitech Alert and has many more features. It's worked flawlessly with my WiFi setup on an Airport Extreme router.

Pros:
* Streaming over the internet is fast -- use a web browser or mobile app
* Tilt/Pan functions work great
* There are a lot of good iPhone apps that work with the camera
* Setup was pretty simple
* User management is easy
* It has IR lights and an IR filter for viewing at night
* 2 way speakers allow you to hear audio from the camera and talk through the cam's speakers

Cons:
× The web interface is functional but really, really ugly -- avoid if you can. Use an app instead.
× The web interface is supposed to work with IE and Firefox, but the Firefox interface is somewhat broken.
× I went to the foscam website to see if there were any firmware updates -- they forced me to give them my email address with the disclaimer that I am agreeing to receive marketing materials as well as firmware download instructions. This really _really_ annoyed me and is why they lost 1 star. Not cool Foscam. There is no reason for you not to provide a direct download link. After signing up for the spam emails only _then_ did I find out there were no firmeware upgrades. I almost took off 2 stars for that crap.
× There are a lot of iPhone apps that work with the camera, but surprisingly Foscam doesn't make one. Not a huge deal as there are some really good iOS apps that can do the job. I'd prefer if Foscam would provide the software though.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: if this is considered "good" then I don't want to see "bad"
review_body:
don't get me wrong, this is not a bad camera. I was just hoping for more for the price. You're basically paying a premium for the fact that it is a wireless, motorized camera - NOT because of the camera's performance or picture! If you say \\"but that's cheap for such a camera!\\" then you need to understand the shortcomings - especially when you can buy a 4-camera setup WITH DVR for under $200 nowadays - same resolution and with NV too! Maybe if I had used this camera for a different purpose than security monitoring I would have felt differently...

The setup went well, and within a few minutes I was up and running. Had to reset the camera a couple times to get it recognized, which the manual does not mention to do. The interface? Dated. A little clumsy. NO DVR or motion capture of any sort (not even as a snapshot). They want you to buy separate Blue Iris monitoring software, which is an added expense. I could not find any other software to work with this camera for DVR monitoring, and the Blue Iris is...not the best.

Want to monitor the camera from over the internet? Good luck! First you need to register a domain - I used [...] which is free. If you've never setup a domain before this step can be confusing, and then the real fun begins when you try and setup your router and camera for remote access. Built computers before? Pretty good at software? Then try your skills with this setup! And then? You don't get streaming video on your phone. Just snapshots. Maybe I did it wrong - I will be the first to admit it. But man, this camera was hard as HELL to setup for remote access, and really not worth the effort.

Night vision? Works great. Indoors. Only indoors. If you use this for a nanny cam, or maybe for watching an entryway, it would work well. The ability to pan and scan is great, and the ability to look around a room is cool as hell.

Want to use it outdoors? Forget it. The camera is obviously not weatherproof, so you have to have it looking out through a window. The problem with this, and with any other NV camera, is the infrared emitters reflect back off the glass, effectively blinding the camera! All you see is a white picture, like looking into a constant camera flash. It works ok if you open the window and look through the screen, although here in the northeast that means about half the year you can't leave that window open, so for half a year you don't have night vision.

NV distance. They state up to 8m, which I believe is accurate. That's around 25 feet, at the edge of which you really can't see past. This means the effective range for any kind of detail with the NV is maybe 10 feet - just enough to see something or someone that is directly in front of the camera. You were hoping it would kind of lighten up the yard/driveway/whatever, so you can kind of see the whole thing? Like it is a moonlit night? No way. Not happening. Buy a separate infrared emitter system. But then that brings up...

Picture quality. When I first started using the camera I was impressed! The filter does a good job of fixing color issues, and the picture is clear and colorful. BUT you gotta remember that this camera is 640x480, and you WILL NOT be able to make out details. Even up close. Not kidding. Oh sure, you will be able to tell what make of car that is, or be able to tell who that person you've seen before is, but if you want a license number, or a clear description of a person other than \\"a guy\\" then this resolution is not for you. If you say \\"but that's a good resolution for a camera in this price range!\\" then why can I buy a $30 camera that has the same resolution? Why is it webcams come in 1280x720 or higher, for less money? Yeah yeah yeah pick apart my argument, I still think if you need a security camera then you need a higher resolution.

Problems with the unit. I had this mounted in my kitchen window looking out at the yard, so I could see who is walking up to thehouse. Even though the camera was behind the blinds (which were closed) and facing out, every time the kitchen light is on there is enough ambient light to hit the sensor and turn off the NV at night. If someone is outside when the light is on, I won't know it, so I only have NV if nobody is in the kitchen at night. I feel the sensor is too sensitive. Then, at least with my unit, the camera would reset by itself several times a day. Caused by router dropouts? Power surges? Who can say! All I know is it would stop working, and it would pan/tilt constantly - almost as if it had been just turned on - except it won't stop moving until it is rebooted. Finally - and this complaint might be for any wireless camera - my router would get overloaded trying to keep up with the stream from the camera, and my overall internet speed would drop to near nothing. As soon as I would switch off the camera everything would go back to normal.

I have had the camera for about a month and a half before writing this review, but within the first month (and after having it shut down and reset itself as I mentioned above about 100 times) I said enough is enough. I asked for an RMA. I was told \\"no RMA's unless you call tech support and it is needed\\". Wow. In an age where most major retailers take returns no questions asked, and since I feel like I have had a legitimately bad experience, I was not expecting this. The camera was not purchased from Amazon, rather from one of their resellers, and I feel this is bad customer service. This isn't a complaint about the camera itself, but instead a warning to make sure you buy from someone you can deal with easily - especially since the price I paid is the same as if I bought it from Foscam!

Worth it? Maybe. Think what you will use it for first.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
I have been using this camera to monitor construction work on a property 100 miles away. In general, I have been pleased. But it is a very steep climb, to learn to use the thing. More than one reviewer has said it takes a networking expert to get it to work. And I guess I agree that it would take an expert to get everything working correctly. The manual(s) is/are pretty miserable. Yet the camera appears (at least) to be a fine piece of equipment. This is what I have and have not been able to make work correctly: I can view my project from 100 miles via the internet, and I can traverse the camera up, down, and sideways remotely. The IR works great in the dark, if you want to watch your cat prowl around. I can record to a hard drive, but it is unreliable over longer periods of time. It often just quits recording, for reasons unknown. Sometime it records for hours. Sometimes it quits after a few minutes. Sometimes the camera resets itself and goes through some sort of test cycle, for no apparent reason - halting the recording. Sometimes it changes its local IP address and can't be reset remotely. I have not found the motion detection feature to be useful. If you set it to not detect water ripples or trees moving, it misses important action. It will send you an email, if motion is detected. So I imagine this could work well, if the background were totally motionless, such as interior monitoring. At some point it quit working with passwords. I haven't gotten the \\"patrol\\" features to work right. The function to \\"remember\\" and return to fixed positions has never worked. I have a feeling that, with a great manual, it would be a great camera. But I have reached my limit, having gotten it to do just a few basic things, sort of correctly. To use it \\"remotely\\" you must open a port through your fire wall. I don't know how hazardous this is, so I am careful to remove all computers from the network while the port is open. I seem to have a \\"sticky\\" IP address, so I have not bothered to get a fixed IP from my ISP, or do that other thing the manual attempts to explain. So far, no problem. I feel that this would be a fantastic gadget, able to do all sorts of useful things, if the software and manual were just a little better.

OK, a year or so later... I have learned that I should set the local IP address to some value higher than 100, such as 101 or 102, etc. My WIFI router reserves the right to mess with any IP lower than 100. This may vary from router to router. Once I set the IP address to 101, I had no problem having the camera go off line. I have also bought 3 more cameras of the lower price Wansview variety. The video quality and internal software are not quite as nice, but they are fine for my purchases. For reasons unknown, the Wansview cameras are a little quicker to respond remotely. In general, I have been happy with both models, but they take considerable playing around to get them working.

Oh, yes, and as I note in the other review, the Wansview camera comes with a totally blank software disc. So it helped me to have the disc from my Foscam camera.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Well, it indeed works. I was bit skeptical of this camera when I bought it hence kept the packaging around incase I have to return. But once it was setup (after 5 hours of hard labor), it worked like a charm.

I would recommend this camera but only if you have the patience to set it up.

There is a setup video which is helpful, the only issue is that it assumes a lot and has gaps. Hence buy it only if you know how to set it up.

The two-way voice, I couldnt get it to work. I guess it needs another 5 hours of my time :--)

I can control this camera using my iPhone and can control its movement. The video quality is awesome. I would give this camera a 4 star. Taking away one-star as they can do better with setup instructions.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: If you are searching for a reliable network cam look no further. I have tried all the x10 products and 4 other network cams and this is by far the best. It is relativly easy to set up and they just work. The iphone software and computer interface is clean and easy to understand. I finally did get them viewable on the interent after some help from tech support. It actually was not that hard... you just have to pay attention to what you are doing.  Ill give you some advice. When they tell you to do \\"port forwarding\\", do not use the \\"range\\" option...... do each one indiviudaly. so in your router you will put in the ip address of the cam, then assign a port number. 8090 is a good place to start. So your cam will then be something like this if you are within network. 192.168.1.125:8090.  If outside, you need to get your router ip addess then the port number. So something like this. [...]  Besides all that tech geek stuff, you will like the cameras. You can change the scan speed to very slow to surprisingly FAST or anywhere inbetween. and the range pan and tilt range is incredible. You will never feel like \\"i wish it could go a little farther\\".  You can also have the ir lights come on automatically when it gets dark or you can control them manually. Visability is great at night. May be more than 7 meters which is too far to see much detail anyway. Pic is clear day and night although the color is a little weak, however it does have auto iris control which is great cuz it adjusts instantly to bright light or shade. I have had mine outside under eaves for over 6 months with 0 problems.  Oh and i almost forgot. You can talk through them and listen to feedback which is great. No extra speakers or anything required. This is priceless... especially when the kids are outside doing something they shouldnt be!!!  SIgn up at Foscams website because they occasionally (like every month) have sales which *can* be a discount sometimes.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: This Camera has stunning video.  Images look just like you were there. I bought three of these and they easily connected to my network.  Installation on a Apple Mac was simple.  I use these with the iCam app.  When any motion is detected, I immediately receive a text message and can view the cameras on my iPhone and  the saved data which is sent to my Dropbox.

I bought previous versions of the Foscam cameras and this is by far the best one I've gotten from them. The IR cutoff filter does make a huge difference in the color quality. The wide angle lens makes it a lot easier to monitor objects from a closer distance and full room views.
Awesome camera update.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I bought this camera as a solution to a baby monitor, although it is a bit more expensive than a traditional monitor the FOSCAM IP Control 2 app for only 3.99 on iTunes has allowed me to hook my camera's up to my iPhone and iPad all using the iCloud. This makes it easy to check on my children from wherever I may be. It gives me a piece of mind knowing i can watch them even at work. Great all around product i love where the technology is going.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Looks good, but could use some improvements
review_body:
I purchased the black version a few days ago. I have two Panasonic IP cameras that I've used for over 5 years. They still work perfectly, but they lack night vision. They're also wired cameras, and I wanted a wireless unit for some locations where I don't have an Ethernet jack conveniently located.

I'm not sure how sturdy this is. I guess time will tell. The pan / tilt has a little play, and I'm not sure what would happen if I were to force it to move when powered off. Needless to say I'm unwilling to subject my new toy to destructive testing.

The black surface has a soft, velvety feel to it, not the slick smooth plastic I was expecting. I hope it won't be a dust magnet. Time will tell.

The package came with the camera, a mounting bracket with screws and drywall anchor, an Ethernet cable, the antenna (detached, attaching it takes about 5 seconds), power supply, a CD and two sheets of quick start guide (MacOS and Windows). The CD contains the reference manual and quick start guide (MS Word format), an installation video, and the IP Camera Utility.

I plugged everything in, fired up the IP Camera install (which required me to reboot my Windows box), and it did not detect my camera. No matter. I fired up Fing on my Android tablet, which quickly found the camera. Some routers can tell you what devices are on your network as well. Armed with the IP address, I connect to it and I'm greeted by the login page. I'm using Firefox at this point.

Just about every configuration change, including adding user, or changing password, requires the camera to reboot. This is silly, but I can live with that. Once everything is set up, I won't be changing configurations every day.

There are 3 types of user accounts : administrator, operator, and visitor. Visitors cannot change the pan / tilt setting, but they can switch on audio (listen, talk, or both). Operators can do everything a visitor can, as well as control the camera. An administrator can change the configuration of the camera.

This is where I ran into my first problem with Firefox. In Firefox, I can listen to what the camera picks up, but I cannot speak through the camera. I also don't see Visitor settings that I see in Internet Explorer - turning on the On Screen Display (date / time) and other such settings.

An Operator can turn the IR on or off, but you have no control over the IR Cut Filter. There's a very audible click as it cuts in or out. If you happen to position the light just so, with IR turned on, you can hear it cut in and out every few seconds.

The audio is not great - there is a fair bit of static, but I can make out speech if the speaker talks slowly. It's probably more useful for picking up noise than for use as an intercom.

Testing within my home LAN, there is very little delay (less than 0.2 seconds) with audio turned off. When audio is turned on, both video and audio is delayed by about 1.5 seconds. Speaking through the camera (sending my voice from browser to camera), my voice is delayed by less than 1 second (probably around 0.6 seconds).

Picture quality is good, considering that it is 640 x 480 and not HD. Audio is OK, movement is rather silent. The frequent reboots during configuration, flaky IP Camera Tool (not needed if you know how to get the IP of the camera by other means), and the missing features in Firefox is why I took away 1 star from my rating. Hopefully the Firefox and reboot issues will be fixed by future firmware releases. As of April 1st 2012, there is no firmware updates available for this camera.

I couldn't edit my seller feedback, so I'm including the information here.

PhotoPLUS was not listed as an official reseller on Foscam's website, so I sent them an email. They confirmed that PhotoPLUS is indeed an authorized reseller.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Bought this F18910W camera for wireless use.  Overlooked the numerous online feedback on wifi issues.  Found out the hard way that wifi is very problematic.  Initially connected the camera via wifi but after disconnecting it for relocation, the camera refuses to connect via wifi.  A very tech savvy person with solid network background, I have tried every single option both on the camera and via multiple routers and my experience is the same as most others online.  After 4 days of trying to connect via wifi, I gave up and ran a wire to the camera instead.  The wired connection works and despite my woes with wifi, this camera, once it holds up, is a good buy compared to many other options out there.  I'm not a fan of CMOS cameras but this one looks just as great as my CCD ones.  Downloaded FoscamPro for iphone and everything works generally well except for an occasional audio distortion.  Overall, I'm happy with this camera for the build, features, and functionality at such a low cost despite the wifi issues.  If you are looking for a wifi camera, forget this one, otherwise it is a great deal as a wired camera.  One last note, there are many imitation cameras looking the same but mine was from Foscam.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Hi purchased the new Foscam 18910 WiFi camera after buying and then retiring a completive brand that was defective out of the box.......

Short story: I installed the camera s per the printed instructions and set up the wifi capability immediately...no problems at all and I'm on an Apple system with an Apple Extreme Airport wifi system in the house. This is the biggest PLUS in that many of these cams have to be tweaked to cooperate with Apple......

Advice: Ignore the printed instruction manual and go to the Foscam website which is 10X more concise and well written...although I was able to use the printed instructions, the website is far better and less intimidating.

I am in the process now of inputing settings to allow my to see the cam from outside of the house......the website, while asking that you understand some IP terminology, also gives links to various sites for setting up your own domain name which is required.....

Customer Support, off the website, is there if needed.......all in all, I love the cam and will add at least one more to our home for cat monitoring....

UPDATE: I just set the cam up using the \\"port forwarding\\" instructions from the Foscam website and the performance is fantastic....really not that bad to do the install once the domain name was set up and the online instructions were pretty straight forward, far better than those in the print copy included in the box.

Bottom line: you cannot go wrong with Foscam. I just ordered a second camera!! GREAT product!

Steve

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: Edit: I am this to one star because of a severe security risk associated with the new Foscam cameras. They now connect to a P2P network and send your data to the Chinese company that makes them. This model does not, just the new ones, but fair warning seems necessary.    [...]    I would rate this camera as medium to somewhat difficult to install. This from someone who has been a computer tech for close to 30 years.    The first thing I figured out was that I needed to print out the manual that comes on the CD. The quick install pamphlet is good, but limited. You do need both to install the camera.    One thing that they tell you to do is go to [...] and get a free domain name to use when you connect remotely. The problem is that company doesn't provide free domain names. The other options for domain names given in a list they provide in the software seem to be non-existent. At least I think that's what they're telling me... It's confusing and poorly explained.    I'm currently connecting with the IP address, and it has worked from a location outside my internal network. I'm going to try using our domain supplied by Microsoft for our Windows Home Server. [...]. If it works, I'm set. If not, I'm looking for a place to get one. I'm not overly interested in purchasing a domain name just for the cameras. Of course if the IP address works consistently I don't have to.    Their port forwarding screen and explanation are confusing, but it's port forwarding so what would anyone expect? I still don't understand why every explanation I find regarding this task confuses it more than necessary.    As for the camera itself, I am very impressed. The pan and tilt range is excellent, the resolution is clear at 640x480, the color is crisp, and you can adjust the brightness and contrast. I think it has the ability to save settings based on what you choose, but I haven't tested that yet. Infrared is automatic when the light level gets low and is a clear image.    It will email alerts(it can be turned on and off easily) and I have set up and tested this feature. It works well within limits, but I can't get it to successfully send a message to my wife's Gmail account even though it sends one to mine. This feature needs a better explanation in the documentation. It attaches six snapshots to the email, and you can get a bunch of emails with constant movement! I know this because I forgot to turn it off once after testing. Oops! The picture quality in the email is excellent.    I have set up our smart phones (Android) access the camera and it works fairly well. The biggest negative is the speed of the connection, but that's the cell phone service. Picture quality is pretty good and you can control the pan, tilt etc from the phone. An app download is required. This is the one I use: IP Cam Viewer Free. There is a full version with quite a few features that are not in the free. I may be buying that one once things settle down on the PC side. $4.00    I downloaded a plugin:[...] that captures the audio and it works, but is a bit noisy. I've read that static can be caused by the wireless antenna and the power cord among other things and that experimentation should resolve the issues. I did notice that it really picked up the the tick-tock from our mantel clock.    The lack of the ability to get a domain name as explained, along with the apparent lack of concern about this on the part of Foscam, as well as the problems with sending email are the reasons for four stars instead of five.    I will be purchasing more of these cameras in spite of these problems.    Edit: I figured out the email for Gmail. There is this choice in the mail settings:    \\"Gmail only support TLS at port 465 and support STARTTLS at port 25/587.\\"    I initially used STARTTLS at port 25 and it wouldn't work. Changing it to TLS at port 465 resolved the problem.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: I purchased this camera to use in my horse barn for foaling season and I couldn't be happier!! It does not zoom in but I knew that before I purchased it and I don't need this function anyway. It was very easy to install and I take my laptop to bed and can check the horses any time I wish....saves me some sleep. Great Product!!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
Considering that you are paying less than $100 for a wireless IP Camera that provides PT (no Zoom), infrared night vision, motion detection, and automatic email of alarm photos, there is very little one can criticize about this camera. Yes, it's tricky to set-up if you have never done port-forwarding before and yes, the frame rate and resolution are both a little low, and the audio is crap, but remember that you paid less than $100 for this thing. If you need audio, higher frame rates and better resolution, you should buy a more expensive IP camera.

As far as setup goes, if you understand networking and port-forwarding, these are my recommendations:

1) Do NOT install the software on the CD.
2) Connect the camera by Cat-5 wire to your router.
3) Login to your router (via browser) and find the IP address assigned to your camera.
4) Login to the camera at that IP address (via browser) and IMMEDIATELY turn OFF the DHCP.
5) Give your camera a fixed IP address on your network and fill in the subnet mask with what you normally use.
6) The Gateway and DNS fields should normally be the IP address of your router.
7) Fill in the SSID, encryption type, and share key used by your wireless network.
8) Pick a 4 digit number to use for the HTTP port number. (I have no idea what \\"Network Lamp\\" is so I left it checked.)
9) Disconnect the Cat-5 cable and re-boot the camera.
10) Re-login to the camera at the new fixed IP address to verify that everything's working.
11) Login to your router and set a port-forwarding entry to map to the fixed IP address and HTTP port you gave your camera.
12) Use the \\"What's My IP\\" site to find your outside IP address.
13) Enter your outside IP address and HTTP port number into a browser and verify that you can get into the camera from outside your house.
14) You're done.

UPDATE #1:
Under the Mail Service Settings there is a checkbox named \\"Report Internet IP by Mail\\". If you check this, when you ISP gives you a new external IP address or when the camera reboots because of a power failure, the camera will email you the current external IP address and port! A very nice feature for those of us who prefer not to use DDNS services.

UPDATE #2:
The best app I've found for viewing IP camera feeds on a smartphone or tablet is IP Cam Viewer by Robert Chou.

UPDATE #3:
While I am still pleased with my FosCams, two things have happened recently that make me wonder about the business practices of FosCam. First, out of the blue they have raised the price $10. Second, FosCam.us is given me the run-around about an RMA to return a camera I purchased directly from FosCam. If you do decide to purchase a FosCam camera, buy it through Amazon. Amazon will not give you the run-around over a return. FosCam seems to be money-grubbing and anti-customer.ternet IP by Mail\\". If you check this, when you ISP gives you a new external IP address or when the camera reboots because of a power failure, the camera will email you the current external IP address and port! A very nice feature for those of us who prefer not to use DDNS services.

UPDATE #2:
The best app I've found for viewing IP camera feeds on a smartphone or tablet is IP Cam Viewer by Robert Chou.

UPDATE #3:

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
The camera works flawlessly, the picture is crystal clear, the night vision awesome.
Setting it up attached to a cable is straightforward. Make it wireless and accessable from outside your network, much more difficult.
The IP Camera Tool didn't work, but the workaround is simple once you know.
Just type the camera IP address into your URL search (192.168.11.144) and the Monitoring System should come right up.
You will need to be able to get into your router. Again, typing this address into your URL search and it should come right up: 192.168.1.1
In your router, (I'll use CISCO as an example) you will need to go to the Wireless tab, Basic Wireless Settings, and check Manual and Enable SSID Broadcast. Wireless Security tab should be WPA2 Personal and your passphrase (password) must match the password in the camera.
In the Administrator tab of the Real-Time IP Camera Monitoring System you need to go to Basic Network Settings and manually type in the IP Address of the camera, and the following numbers: Subnet Mast 255.255.255.0 Gateway 192.168.1.1 DNS Server 192.168.1.1 Http Port 80 Network Lamp (checked). How to get the IP Address of the camera? Here it is: 192.168.1.144. Then Wireless LAN Settings and click the scan button and then pick your router from the list. The SSID must match your router SSID, the Encryption is WPA2 Personal (AES) and the share key is the same as the passphrase or password of the router (above). Now, the last thing will to be set up Port Forwarding to see your wireless camera from some net connection outside of your own router. To do this you go back into the router and find Single Port Forwarding. In Cisco its under Gaming. There you assign an application name, like My Cam, type 80 for the External and Internal Port, and in that line's IP Address add 144 so it reads 192.168.1.144 and Enable it by checking a box.
All this done, unplug the camera from the router and in your URL search type the camera's IP address and it should work: 192.168.1.144. Outside of your network you can see it by typing your IP Address (you can get it from your router (or Google What Is My ISP) then add a colon and your port number which we above gave as 80. So it could be: xx.xx.xxx.xx:80.
What is important is that the places in your router and in the camera Administration list I've mentioned all need to be addressed and most of the numbers and i.d.s must match across the router and the camera.
Its a great camera. Good luck, and if need be just call FOSCAM. There phone number is: 800-930-0949.
Hey, what do you think? This was helpful???
(Purchased at Amazon)

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body: So this is a follow up to my initial review of this camera after being in service a little over a month and having had the chance to access the unit via wifi and 3G.  So far this VCam has performed flawlessly.  After the growing pains I had to go thru to get things up and running via DNS, it has been smooth sailing.  On a recent vacation I had 2 of my neighbors  watching my home while I was away on my email alert list.  They had no problem receiving and viewing the test video I sent them.  They also advised they planned to purchase these units themselves.  A tip on Presets, out of the box presets are set to disable, so they don't work.  I went thru a period of frustration trying to get presets going until I finally discovered this.  Go to the PTZ setting and enable them and you will be fine on presets.  I highly recommend these units.  It is great peace of mind to be able to check on things at home from anywhere!

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
This is my first Foscam and I choose it because of its relatively cheap price. Installation was not a problem with the exception of setting the password for the admin account. If you use certain special characters such as exclamation mark, the camera accepts your password but you can never login to the web interface again. It caused me to reset the camera back to factory settings multiple times, until I figured out the problem.

Here are the problems I experienced:
- The camera locks-up after 9+ continuous hours of operation for reasons I couldn't figure out. This is a big problem if you are using the camera as a security camera. When the camera locks up, you lose the ability to see what's going on until you have physical access to the camera to reboot it by unplugging and re-plugging. Upon reset, everything comes back normal for another 9+ hours.
- The IR led cannot be kept OFF. You can set it off once in the UI but when the camera reboots, it goes back to the default operation, which turns on the IR led automatically in low light conditions. This is a problem if you are monitoring outside in front of a window. When the IR comes on, the reflection from the window blocks the entire view of the camera. They should have created an option to keep the IR led off.
- The power cable supplied is too short. If you want to put the camera high up, for example on your fireplace mantle, for a better vantage point you need an extension cord.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
For the price and specifications stated, this camera seemed too good to be true. Sadly it was too good to be true. My basic need for a surveillance camera includes the 2-way audio capability. I would not have purchased it had I known that after the past three upgrades to this product, the audio problems have yet to be addressed. This is my second try with FOSCAM, I had hoped that they had improved the audio by now. Sadly, it looks like they have greatly improved the video quality and ignored the audio problems. I guess most buyers are not concerned with audio quality as most of Amazons reviews have been good. It would help if they would state the cameras audio specifications to a level that someone who needs the 2-way capability could decide whether or not to buy this camera. It's a shame that I had to order and test the unit to find that again the audio quality was extremely poor. Talking to FOSCAM.US on this problem is like talking to a brick wall!

PROS: video quality has greatly improved due to the addition of an IR cut filter. Otherwise the camera is much the same as earlier versions (pan, tilt, etc.) which are acceptable.

CONS:
1. Audio reception had terrible ringing and produced 5 to 6 repeats (echo's) of everything said.
2. Transmission of my voice via my computer to the unit over my LAN/WAN seemed OK but weak.
3. When both the headset icon and the mike icon were activated simultaneously they produced a pinging and bad background noise from the cameras' speaker. This problem alone would allow anyone to locate where the surveillance camera was located.
4. If others have found the 2-way audio acceptable then FOSCAM has a significant quality control problem.

RECOMMENDATION: I firmly believe that Amazon should discontinue selling this camera until FOSCAM can provide evidence that one of its features (2-way audio) has been corrected and now usable. Selling a product with an obvious fault as this is simply notacceptable. If FOSCAM cannot correct the audio problem; a suggested fix for FOSCAM is to remove the 2-way audio circuits from future cameras and remove from their literature that it has a 2-way audio capability.

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_headline: Good camera but a little tricky to set up on web
review_body:
[**Updated now with 2nd camera over internet, see below for information on multiple camera set up with dyndns **]

I bought this over the cheaper, but older model (FI8918w) based on the reviews saying this had a better picture. So far I am sufficiently pleased that I will look into getting some more to cover more of the house.

* Setting up the camera.
The camera is very easy to set up as a wifi camera, by following the written instructions and the video that comes on the installation disk.
The process involves plugging the camera into your router, installing the software and getting the camera recognized on the network and then unplugging the network cable and logging the camera into your wireless network. All fairly plain sailing, and this allows you to play around with the camera settings, and get used to its operation.

Setting up the camera for web access is a little more difficult. The video on the disk is a useful primer, but the best place to go for help is foscam.us forums. In the end it took me a few hours of frustration (and reading), but I am sure this can be alleviated by considering the following points:
1. The DNS service at dyndns.org is no longer free, but will give a 14-day trial after which the service is $20 per year.
2. I am a Verizon Fios customer and it took me some time to identify that you should NOT allocate port 80 to the camera. It seems that Verizon blocks this port according to one post I read. I allocated port 8090 for this first camera and it worked fine as soon as I did this.
3. The Fios router is easy to set up for port-forwarding - it's a hyperlink on the main menu which takes you into the Advanced Options.
4. Be patient. You often have to repeat actions on the camera and allow it to reboot a few times before it will show \\"success\\" on DNS forwarding.

* Operating the camera.
There are several camera parameters that can be changed, such as picture size, frame rate, brightness and contrast. The IR works well and can be turned on and off remotely.
The camera has motion detection, with user sensitivity settings. When in alarm mode the camera can be set to record to your main network PC drive and also take still photos and email them directly to you.
The camera has 2-way audio although there is a distinct lag between network and speaker. There is some audio feedback which I managed to alleviate by rotating the camera aerial (wifi antenna) so this it faces flat. I read somewhere that this is due to the way these aerials are coiled inside the wand so that the signal is better from the sides that the wand top, which seems counter-intuitive, but my point is that you should play with the aerial (wifi antenna) position before getting too angry with it :-)

Overall I would say this is a good buy at under $100 and gives good pictures. Now that I have set it up I shall be getting some more, so I guess that says it all. The software will allow up to 9 cameras to be connected.

I deduct one star as I had to do a fair amount of research, and there really is no need for this. I would think this should be set up in under an hour with the right guidance.

[Update 24 March 2012]
* Multiple Cameras
I bought a second camera and set it up on the network very easily, simply using the IP Camera Tool already installed for the first camera and even the network cable that I had left in the back of the router. Camera #2 was picked up and identified and then I added it to the wifi network as with camera #1.
Getting access over the internet was a bit more tricky, although once I had read through the foscam.us forum posts and started thinking properly it was fairly straightforward.
I assigned port 8091 to camera #2 (remember to keep away from port 80, as mentioned above) and then copied all the settings from camera #1 to camera#2 in the DDNS Server settings and Mail Service Settings menu (except port number, obviously).

* Hint for using presets:
If you want to use the preset camera positions you MUST first uncheck the \\"disable preset\\" box in the PTZ menu under Administrator. Then, if you check \\"goto preset on boot\\" whenever the camera reboots it will start up in the preset position you last left it in. This of course assumes you have set the preset in the first place under the Operator menu (!) As an aside I don't know why they call it PTZ, as there is no zoom function on this model :-(

* Now for the internet:
In the Multi-Device Settings it is important NOT to use the local IP address of the camera (e.g. 192.168.1.11) but instead use the the DDNS web address, in my case [...], when completing the host field.
Once done this all works pretty well, and successfully emails me from either camera when motion is detected and records a video to my PC's HDD.

Next step, removing the PC as video storage by either using NAS or FTP directly from the router...ept port number, obviously).

* Hint for using presets:
If you want to use the preset camera positions you MUST first uncheck the \\"disable preset\\" box in the PTZ menu under Administrator. Then, if you check \\"goto preset on boot\\" whenever the camera reboots it will start up in the preset position you last left it in. This of course assumes you have set the preset in the first place under the Operator menu (!) As an aside I don't know why they call it PTZ, as there is no zoom function on this model :-(

* Now for the internet:
In the Multi-Device Settings it is important NOT to use the local IP address of the camera (e.g. 192.168.1.11) but instead use the the DDNS web address, in my case [...], when completing the host field.
Once done this all works pretty well, and successfully emails me from either camera when motion is detected and records a video to my PC's HDD.

Next step, removing the PC as video storage by either using NAS or FTP directly from the router...

product_title: Foscam FI8910W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with IR-Cut Filter for True Color Images - 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) NEWEST MODEL
review_body:
